Title: Application domains for synchrotron radiation sources of various energies
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malek, Chantal Khan, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States; Saile, Volker, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation, its production and some applications are presented with special regards to the main characteristics needed by most users and the various options for generating synchrotron light from bending magnets, undulators, and wigglers. In parallel to the development of various generations of increasingly powerful synchrotron light sources, compact and simply designed synchrotrons have been built for maximum x-ray output and uptime for industrial use or as smaller regional facilities. The use of synchrotron radiation for industry-related applications has increased continuously during the past 10 years and the demands in some fields like x-ray protein crystallography are expected to grow dramatically.
Index Keywords: Magnets; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; X rays; Undulators; Wigglers; Microelectronics

Authors: Miller R.B., Ballard E.O., Barr G.W., Bowman D.W., Cochrane J.C., Davis H.A., Elizondo J.M., Gribble R.F., Griego J.R., Hicks R.D., Hinckley W.B., Hosack K.W., Nielsen K.E., Parker J.V., Parsons M.O.
Title: Atlas pulsed power facility for high energy density physics experiments
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, R.B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Ballard, E.O., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Barr, G.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bowman, D.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Cochrane, J.C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Davis, H.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Elizondo, J.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gribble, R.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Griego, J.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Hicks, R.D., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Hinckley, W.B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Hosack, K.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Nielsen, K.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Parker, J.V., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Parsons, M.O., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The Atlas facility, now under construction at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), will provide a unique capability for performing high-energy-density experiments in support of weapon-physics and basic-research programs. It is intended to be an international user facility, providing opportunities for researchers from national laboratories and academic institutions around the world. Emphasizing hydrodynamic experiments, Atlas will provide the capability for achieving steady shock pressures exceeding 10-Mbar in a volume of several cubic centimeters. In addition, the kinetic energy associated with solid liner implosion velocities exceeding 12 km/s is sufficient to drive dense, hydrodynamic targets into the ionized regime, permitting the study of complex issues associated with strongly-coupled plasmas. The primary element of Atlas is a 23-MJ capacitor bank, comprised of 96 separate Marx generators housed in 12 separate oil-filled tanks, surrounding a central target chamber. Each tank will house two, independently-removable maintenance units, with each maintenance unit consisting of four Marx modules. Each Marx module has four capacitors that can each be charged to a maximum of 60 kilovolts. When railgap switches are triggered, the Marx modules erect to a maximum of 240 kV. The parallel discharge of these 96 Marx modules will deliver a 30-MA current pulse with a 4-5-μs risetime to a cylindrical, imploding liner via 24 vertical, tri-plate, oil-insulated transmission lines. An experimental program for testing and certifying all Marx and transmission line components has been completed. A complete maintenance module and its associated transmission line (the First Article) are now under construction and testing. The current Atlas schedule calls for construction of the machine to be complete by August, 2000. Acceptance testing is scheduled to begin in November, 2000, leading to initial operations in January, 2001.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric discharges; Electric generators; Electric lines; Electric switches; Marx generators; Railgap switches; Electric power systems

Authors: Shirai T., Sugimura T., Iwashita Y., Fujita H., Tonguu H., Noda A., Inoue M.
Title: First beam circulation test of an electron storage/stretcher ring, KSR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, T., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Sugimura, T., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Iwashita, Y., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Fujita, H., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Tonguu, H., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Noda, A., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Inoue, M., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: In Kyoto University, we are constructing a compact electron storage/stretcher ring (KSR). The circumference is 25.7 m and the maximum beam energy is 300 MeV. The electron beam is injected from a 100 MeV linac through the doubly achromatic transport line. The beam test of the injection line was finished and the beam size and the dispersion were measured. The results are consistent with the design calculation. The beam current is 100 mA and the energy spread is +/-0.5% (FWHM). KSR uses the 1-turn injection scheme. The bump orbit is created by the perturbation magnet for the injection. The test of the bump magnet was carried out.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electron beams; Electron ring accelerators; Achromatic transport lines; Electron storage/stretcher ring; Storage rings

Authors: Brandt D., Herr W., Meddahi M., Verdier A.
Title: Is LEP beam-beam limited at its highest energy?
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Brandt, D., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Herr, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Meddahi, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Verdier, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The operation of LEP at 45.6 GeV was limited by beam-beam effects and the vertical beam-beam parameter ξy never exceeded 0.045. At the highest energy of 94.5 GeV, the increased damping allows higher beam-beam parameters ξy. Values above 0.07 in the vertical plane averaged over four experiments have been obtained frequently with peak values up to 0.075 in a single experiment. Although the maximum intensity in LEP is presently limited by technical considerations, some observations indicate that the beam-beam limit is close and the question of the maximum possible values can be raised. These observations are shown in this paper and possible consequences are presented. The optimum operation of LEP in the neighbourhood of the beam-beam limit is discussed.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Damping; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Electron-positron storage rings; Storage rings

Authors: Lo C.H., Anderson M.D.
Title: Economic dispatch and optimal sizing of battery energy storage systems in utility load-leveling operations
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65401, United States; IEEE
Authors with affiliations: Lo, C.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65401, United States, IEEE; Anderson, M.D., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO 65401, United States, IEEE
Abstract: Battery energy storage (BES) systems show promise of savings for both the utility and the customer. An algorithm combining multi-pass dynamic programming (MPDP) with a time-shift technique has been developed for two purposes: economic dispatch of BES and finding optimal BES power and energy capacities in a power system. Due to the daily cyclic nature of the load curve, a 168-hour load curve is decomposed into seven 24-hour subsections for easy management. Each subsection is treated independently. Decomposition can save computation time and computer memory. A time-shift technique provides better starting state values and improves the finding process of the MPDP approach. The Kansas City Power and Light system is used as an example to test this algorithm. The results obtained in this research have been compared with those from EPRI's DYNASTORE with reasonable discrepancy.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cost effectiveness; Data storage equipment; Dynamic programming; Electric batteries; Electric load dispatching; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Industrial economics; Response time (computer systems); Battery energy storage system; Economic dispatch; Energy capacity; Load curve; Load leveling; Multipass dynamic programming; Time shift technique; Electric energy storage

Authors: Decker F.-J., Iverson R.H., Smith H., Zelanzny M.S.
Title: SLAC linac during the PEP-II era
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Decker, F.-J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Iverson, R.H., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Smith, H., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Zelanzny, M.S., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The 3 km long linac of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC) has for many years provided low emittance beams for the SLC collider. With the beginning of the operation of the B-Factory, PEP-II, the linac will now serve primarily as an injector for the low (LER) and high energy rings (HER) of PEP-II. The different beams are stabilized by a new regional linac energy management (LEM) program, which keeps the magnet strengths and therefore the deflections constant at each of the four extraction points. They are at 3.1 GeV (positrons for LER), 9 GeV (electrons for HER), 25 GeV (electrons for the positron production), and 28.5 GeV (electrons for other purposes such as test beams, plasma experiments, and iris destruction tests). Since many components of the accelerator can be configured on each pulse, it is possible to run these beams with different intensities, bunch length, energies, rates, etc. Only the quadrupole magnet strengths are fixed, producing different lattices for different energy beams, which must be matched at extraction from the linac. Since PEP-II injection does not require all of the full 120 Hz rate, it is possible to run other experiments at the same time. That might include an extension of the SLC run or a high charge, fixed target experiment, which will require some additional pulsed magnets.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Positrons; Storage rings; Quadrupole magnets; Linear accelerators

Authors: Chung S.M., Park C.D., Gu S.H., Kwon M.
Title: Beam-gas lifetime in a low emittance, medium-energy storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Pohang Univ of Science and, Technology, Kyungbuk, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Chung, S.M., Pohang Univ of Science and, Technology, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Park, C.D., Pohang Univ of Science and, Technology, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Gu, S.H., Pohang Univ of Science and, Technology, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Kwon, M., Pohang Univ of Science and, Technology, Kyungbuk, South Korea
Abstract: In order to understand the beam-lifetime limiting process in a medium-energy machine like the 2 GeV Pohang Light Source, the beam-gas scattering effects have been measured by using helium gas and the effects of the transverse aperture height on the lifetime have also been examined by using a beam scraper. It is found that for a medium to large gap vacuum chamber the lifetime is mainly limited by Touschek effect at the machine operating pressure, low 10-9 Torr. For a very small gap undulator, however, the beam-gas scattering makes substantial contribution to the beam lifetime even at approximately 1×10-9 Torr because of Coulomb scattering.
Index Keywords: Elementary particle sources; Vacuum technology; Beam scrapers; Beam-gas lifetime; Coulomb scattering; Storage rings

Authors: Hahn H., Dunbar A., Pal C.I., Sanders R.T., Tsoupas N., Tuozzolo J.E.
Title: RHIC beam abort kicker system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BNL, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, H., BNL, Upton, United States; Dunbar, A., BNL, Upton, United States; Pal, C.I., BNL, Upton, United States; Sanders, R.T., BNL, Upton, United States; Tsoupas, N., BNL, Upton, United States; Tuozzolo, J.E., BNL, Upton, United States
Abstract: The energy stored in the RHIC beam is about 200 kJ per ring at design energy and intensity. To prevent quenching of the superconducting magnets or material damage, the beam will be safely disposed of by an internal beam abort system, which includes the kicker magnets, the pulsed power supplies, and the dump absorber. Disposal of heavy ions, such as gold, imposes design constraints more severe than those for proton beams of equal intensity. In order to minimize the thermal shock in the carbon-fiber dump block, the bunches must be laterally dispersed. The nominal horizontal beam deflection angle is required to vary from approximately 1.7 to 2.5 mrad, which is obtained from five 1.22 m long kicker modules operating at a magnetic field of approximately 3.5 T. The kickers are constructed as window frame magnets with an 50.8 by 76.2 mm aperture and are operated in the ring vacuum. The pulsed power supplies run at 33 kV and deliver the 12.8 μs long pulse. The peak current required is approximately 21 kA and the 50% modulation is generated by means of a pulse forming network with non-uniform characteristic impedance.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Magnetic field effects; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Relativistic heavy ion colliders; Stored beam energy; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Fisher Chad, Lesieutre George
Title: Health monitoring of high energy density rotor for use in spacecraft applications
Affiliations: Applied Material Technologies, Inc, Santa Ana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fisher, Chad, Applied Material Technologies, Inc, Santa Ana, United States; Lesieutre, George, Applied Material Technologies, Inc, Santa Ana, United States
Abstract: Flywheel energy storage (FES) systems have demonstrated the potential to store very high amounts of energy with minimum weight when compared to chemical battery systems. A high energy density flywheel is needed in order to achieve a lightweight design that is competitive with chemical battery systems, however, there are major concerns regarding the safety of operation and the structural integrity of critical components, such as the rim, hub, and shaft. The stresses at high speeds (up to 80,000 rpm) can be very high and cause fiber breakage, matrix microcracking, debonding, and delamination, which lead to premature failure of the rotor design. The consequences of failures of the rotor are a major concern regarding the implementation of a flywheel energy storage system for a spacecraft system and therefore a design approach that includes the use of health monitoring is necessary in order to ensure fail-safe operation.
Index Keywords: Delamination; Energy storage; Failure (mechanical); Fibers; Flywheels; Microcracking; Reliability; Space applications; Spacecraft; Stresses; Debonding; Fiber breakage; Flywheel energy storage systems; Health monitoring; High energy density rotor; Matrix microcracking; Rotors

Authors: Snow S.D., Morton D.K., Ware A.G., Rahl T.E., Smith N.L.
Title: Analytical evaluation of preliminary drop tests performed to develop a robust design for the standardized DOE spent nuclear fuel canister
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snow, S.D., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Morton, D.K., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Ware, A.G., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Rahl, T.E., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Smith, N.L., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) has developed a design concept for a set of standard canisters for the handling, interim storage, transportation, and disposal in the national repository, of DOE spent nuclear fuel (SNF). The standardized DOE SNF canister has to be capable of handling virtually all of the DOE SNF in a variety of potential storage and transportation systems. It must also be acceptable to the repository, based on current and anticipated future requirements. This expected usage mandates a robust design. The canister design has four unique geometries, with lengths of approximately 10 feet or 15 feet, and an outside nominal diameter of 18 inches or 24 inches. The canister has been developed to withstand a drop from 30 feet onto a rigid (flat) surface, sustaining only minor damage - but no rupture - to the pressure (containment) boundary. The majority of the end drop-induced damage is confined to the skirt and lifting/stiffening ring components, which can be removed if desired after an accidental drop. A canister, with its skirt and stiffening ring removed after an accidental drop, can continue to be used in service with appropriate operational steps being taken. Features of the design concept have been proven through drop testing and finite element analyses of smaller test specimens. Finite element analyses also validated the canister design for drops onto a rigid (flat) surface for a variety of canister orientations at impact, from vertical to 45 degrees off vertical. Actual 30-foot drop testing has also been performed to verify the final design, though limited to just two full-scale test canister drops. In each case, the analytical models accurately predicted the canister response.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Containers; Finite element method; Mathematical models; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Spent nuclear fuel canisters; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Asaka T., Hanaki H., Hori T., Kobayashi T., Mizuno A., Sakaki H., Suzuki S., Taniuchi T., Yanagida K., Yokomizo H., Yoshikawa H.
Title: Stability of the RF system at the SPring-8 linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Asaka, T., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Hanaki, H., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Hori, T., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Kobayashi, T., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Mizuno, A., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Sakaki, H., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Suzuki, S., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Taniuchi, T., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Yanagida, K., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Yokomizo, H., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan; Yoshikawa, H., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: The stability of the beam energy and energy spread at both the 1-GeV S-band linac and the 8-GeV synchrotron ring are crucial factors for determining the injection time for the storage ring. Since the linac has a lot of high-power RF equipment, any drift of the output power and phase from the various type of RF equipment will affect the beam energy in beam operation. We measured the output power and phase stability for many types of RF equipment. In order to investigate the drift of the RF parameters in the klystrons, which can be influenced by outside factors, the cooling water temperature and the environmental temperature were also measured. It turns out that the phase of klystrons coincide with the cooling water temperature drift. Although controlled by an air conditioning, the room temperature can vary about 4.0 °C in the course of a day, affecting the high-power klystron drive system. After improvements of the air conditioning control system and the cooling water system for the klystron cavities, a beam current stability was reduced to 0.7% (1σ) from 9.0% (1σ) in beam operation.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling water; Klystrons; Storage rings; Synchrotrons; Temperature measurement; Synchrotron rings; Linear accelerators

Authors: Masselos K., Catthoor F., Goutis C.E., DeMan H.
Title: Performance-oriented use methodology of power optimizing code transformations for multimedia applications realized on programmable multimedia processors
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: Univ of Patras, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Masselos, K., Univ of Patras, Greece; Catthoor, F., Univ of Patras, Greece; Goutis, C.E., Univ of Patras, Greece; DeMan, H., Univ of Patras, Greece
Abstract: The data storage and transfers related power consumption, which forms an important part of the total system power consumption, should be reduced in realizations of multimedia applications on programmable multimedia processors. In earlier work, we have formalized a methodology to achieve this. This methodology is based on the application of a number of power optimizing code transformations to a system-level description of the target application. Our script has recently been extended explicitly to take into consideration the required performance (in number of execution cycles), which is the overriding constraint in real-time multimedia applications. In this paper, we focus on a systematic use methodology that allows to apply this script in practice in a manual way on a complex application, including the necessary local design iterations. Experimental results from a real-life data-dominated application demonstrate that the application of the proposed systematic approach leads to significant power and performance gains compared to reference designs.
Index Keywords: Data transfer; Energy utilization; Iterative methods; Optimization; Real time systems; Signal encoding; Storage allocation (computer); Video signal processing; Programmable multimedia processors; Multimedia systems

Authors: Burkhardt H., Muller A.-S., Wenninger J.
Title: Energy loss measurements at LEP2
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Burkhardt, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Muller, A.-S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wenninger, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The accurate measurement of the W Boson mass at LEP requires to determine the beam energy to the highest possible precision. Present schemes rely on accurate energy determinations in the range from 40 to 60 GeV using resonant depolarization and on precise extrapolations to high energy. Several methods based on measurements of the energy loss due to synchrotron radiation have been studied. Different approaches such as the study of the damping time of transverse oscillations, the radio frequency sawtooth and the dependence of the synchrotron tune on the total accelerating voltage are described and results are discussed.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Damping; Electron beams; Oscillations; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Synchrotron radiation; Energy sawtooth; Storage rings

Authors: Arduini G., Assmann R., Bailey R., Burkhardt H., Butterworth A., Collier P., Cornelis K., Faugier A., Jonker M., Lamont M., Meddahi M., Morpurgo G., Raimondi P., Roy G., Uythoven J., Wenninger J.
Title: Overview of LEP operation in 1998
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Arduini, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Assmann, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bailey, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Burkhardt, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Butterworth, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Collier, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Cornelis, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Faugier, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Jonker, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lamont, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Meddahi, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Morpurgo, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Raimondi, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Roy, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Uythoven, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wenninger, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: After the installation of 32 additional RF cavities in the 1997-1998 shutdown LEP was operated at a beam energy of 94.5 GeV. The total integrated luminosity for the year 1998 clearly surpassed its target and reached 198 pb-1. Vertical beam-beam tuneshifts of more than 0.07 were obtained. The performance did not seem to be beam-beam limited, but the total beam current was limited by power dissipation problems to around 6 mA. A high phase advance optics (102°, 90°), with a smaller natural emittance, was used for regular operation in 1998. This contributed to the excellent performance of LEP, together with the further reduction of both the horizontal and vertical beta function at the interaction points. No dynamic aperture problems were encountered.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electric currents; Electric losses; Electron beams; Functions; Positrons; Beam currents; Beta functions; Luminosity; Storage rings

Authors: Wienands U., Anderson S., Assmann R., Bharadwaj V., Cai Y., Clendenin J., Corredoura P., Decker F.J., Donald M., Ecklund S., Emma P., Erickson R., Fox J., Fieguth T., Fisher A.
Title: Beam commissioning of the PEP-II High Energy Ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wienands, U., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Anderson, S., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Assmann, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Bharadwaj, V., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Cai, Y., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Clendenin, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Corredoura, P., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Decker, F.J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Donald, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Ecklund, S., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Emma, P., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Erickson, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Fox, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Fieguth, T., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Fisher, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The PEP-II High Energy Ring (HER), a 9 GeV electron storage ring, has been in commissioning since spring 1997. Initial beam commissioning activities focused on systems checkout and commissioning and on determining the behaviour of the machine systems at high beam currents. This phase culminated with the accumulation of 0.75 A of stored beam - sufficient to achieve design luminosity - in January 1998 after 3.5 months of beam time. Collisions with the 3 GeV positron beam of the Low Energy Ring (LER) were achieved in Summer of 1998. At high beam currents, collective instabilities have been seen. Since then, commissioning activities for the HER have shifted in focus towards characterization of the machine and a rigorous program to understand the machine and the beam dynamics is presently underway.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electric currents; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Electron storage rings; Storage rings

Authors: Khouzam K.Y.
Title: Technical and economic assessment of utility interactive PV systems for domestic applications in South East Queensland
Affiliations: Queensland University of Technology, Research Concentration in Electrical Energy, School of Electrical and Electronic Systems Engineering, 2 George St., Brisbane, QLD 4000, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Khouzam, K.Y., Queensland University of Technology, Research Concentration in Electrical Energy, School of Electrical and Electronic Systems Engineering, 2 George St., Brisbane, QLD 4000, Australia
Abstract: Electric utilities in Australia have been developing policies to stimulate interest and permit the purchase of electricity generated by renewable energy sources such as photovoltaic systems (PV). Studies show that under current conditions, it is technically feasible to introduce small-scale, grid connected, roof-top photovoltaic generation systems with or without battery storage. Economic analysis show that the electricity tariff structure for PV and other renewables requires a major change to allow a reasonable and an acceptable pay-back period if PV is to become an attractive economic investment to private owners. The technical policy developed by the utility should be reviewed to better match the operational characteristics of PV and inverter systems.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric power generation; Electric utilities; Industrial economics; Public policy; Purchasing; Utility interactive photovoltaic (PV) systems; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Galakhov I.V., Garanin S.G., Kirillov G.A, Murugov V.M., Sukharev S.A.
Title: Capacitor bank of 120 MJ, 22 kV for high-power Nd-glass laser of ISKRA-6 facility: Conceptual design
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Galakhov, I.V., Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Garanin, S.G., Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Kirillov, G.A, Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Murugov, V.M., Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Sukharev, S.A., Russian Federal Nuclear Cent -, VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: Conceptual design of the capacitor bank with about 120 MJ energy storage and 22 kV operational voltage is presented. This capacitor bank will be used to drive the xenon flashlamps for pumping of Nd-glass laser amplifiers which are included in the facility ISKRA-6. Possible components and circuit of the bank module are discussed.
Index Keywords: Glass; Neodymium lasers; Pumping (laser); Capacitor banks; Capacitor storage

Authors: Celanovic Nikola, Lee Dong-Ho, Peng Dengming, Borojevic Dusan, Lee Fred C.
Title: Control design of three-level voltage source inverter for SMES power conditioning system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Celanovic, Nikola, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Lee, Dong-Ho, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Peng, Dengming, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Borojevic, Dusan, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Lee, Fred C., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the control design of the power processing system for Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES). The proposed SMES power-processing system consists of series connection of a three-level voltage source inverter and a three-level chopper. The control design enables stable high-bandwidth control of power transfer to and from the SMES coil. The issues of series connection of converters are discussed. Theoretical analysis of the controller design and experimental results are presented.
Index Keywords: Power conditioning system; Superconductive magnetic energy storage; Voltage source inverter; Choppers (circuits); Control system synthesis; Electric coils; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Power converters; Electric power systems

Authors: Kazimi M.S., Todreas N.E.
Title: Nuclear power economic performance: Challenges and opportunities
Source title: Annual Review of Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kazimi, M.S., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States; Todreas, N.E., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307, United States
Abstract: In the last decade, the economics of existing nuclear power plants have improved in the United States and worldwide. Further economic improvements could be realized by better management of planned outages, understanding of unplanned outages, resource sharing among several plants, and more efficient use of nuclear fuel. Dry spent-fuel storage has removed the limitation of on-site storage caused by the limited size of the originally designed storage pools. However, delays and uncertainty about the date by which the national U.S. program will receive the spent fuel have significant financial penalties that could be mitigated if a central interim facility were established to receive spent fuel. Furthermore, a higher incentive for spent-fuel minimization could be obtained if the waste fees were based on spent-fuel volume rather than on electricity sales. Introducing thorium into the fuel cycle has the potential to improve the economics of the fuel cycle while reducing the volume of spent fuel and improving its proliferation resistance.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Environmental protection; Fuel storage; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive wastes; Spent fuels; Waste utilization; Economic performance; Nuclear energy

Authors: Keller R.
Title: Ion-source and low-energy beam-transport issues for H- accelerators
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, R., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: H- ions are being used in high-energy accelerators and spallation neutron-sources because of the efficiency with which they can be converted into protons at high energy, a mechanism utilized in schemes that provide injection into a ring by means of charge. This paper discusses new trends and recent developments in the field of H- plasma generators, extraction systems, and Low-Energy Beam-Transport (LEBT) systems, with emphasis on low-emittance systems delivering beams in the 50-mA range.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Hydrogen; Ion beams; Ion sources; Negative ions; Neutron sources; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Plasma sources; Plasma generators; Spallation neutron sources; Storage rings

Authors: Danilov V., Galambos J., Jeon D., Holmes J., Olsen D., Fitzgerald D., Macek R., Plum M., Griffin J., Burov A.
Title: Study on the possibility to increase the PSR E-P instability threshold
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Danilov, V., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Galambos, J., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Jeon, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Holmes, J., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Olsen, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Fitzgerald, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Macek, R., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Plum, M., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Griffin, J., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Burov, A., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: The Proton Storage Ring (PSR) has a fast intensity-limiting instability, which may result from an electron cloud interaction with the circulating proton beam leading to a transverse mode coupling instability. Multipacting may also be very important. A PSR beam experiment is proposed with an available 150-350 MHz RF cavity. This cavity would produce a high frequency longitudinal density ripple on the proton bunch which could reduce the e-p instability by two mechanisms: (1) a approximately 350 MHz ripple could clear electrons by creating an unstable parametric resonance between the electrons and protons, and (2) a approximately 150 MHz ripple could reduce multipacting by reducing the electron energy at the vacuum chamber.
Index Keywords: Protons; Vacuum technology; Electron-proton instability; Proton storage ring (PSR); Storage rings

Authors: Cooper R.A., MacDougall F.W., Ennis J.B., Cochrane J.C., Reass W.A., Parsons W.M.
Title: High energy, low inductance, high current fiberglass energy storage capacitor for the Atlas machine Marx modules
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, R.A., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States; MacDougall, F.W., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States; Ennis, J.B., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States; Cochrane, J.C., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States; Reass, W.A., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States; Parsons, W.M., Maxwell Energy Products, San Diego, United States
Abstract: The Los Alamos National Laboratory's Atlas Marx design team envisioned a double ended plastic case 60 kV, 15 nH, 650 kA, energy storage capacitor. A design specification was established and submitted to various vendors. Maxwell Energy Products drew from its development of large fiberglass case, high voltage, low inductance `FASTCAP' capacitors manufactured for Maxwell Technologies' ACE II, ACE III and ACE IV machines. This paper discusses the LANL specification and Maxwell Energy Products' successful design, Model No. 39232, 34.1 uF, 60 kV, 13×29×27″, the only capacitor qualified by LANL for the 23 Mega Joule Atlas application. Maxwell's past experience in this type of capacitor will be covered. The performance data will be reviewed and the life test data compared to the original calculated design life. Challenges included Maxwell's `keep it simple' design goal which was maintained to minimize the effort required to create and manufacture a nearly 600 pound capacitor.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Glass fibers; Service life; Fiberglass energy storage capacitor; Capacitors

Authors: Bramoulle M., Marret J.P., Michalczyk P., Rubin de Cervens D.
Title: Evolution of the D.C. capacitors
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: TPC, St. Apollinaire, France
Authors with affiliations: Bramoulle, M., TPC, St. Apollinaire, France; Marret, J.P., TPC, St. Apollinaire, France; Michalczyk, P., TPC, St. Apollinaire, France; Rubin de Cervens, D., TPC, St. Apollinaire, France
Abstract: This paper describes the evolution of the medium and high voltage d.c. capacitors, used for the filtering and energy storage applications. This evolution was accelerated in the 90s because of the new requirements for the d.c. capacitors for the rolling stock. The basic design was radically changed thanks to the combination of existing but seemingly incompatible raw materials. Over the last 10 years, all the improvements have been based on a better knowledge of the influence of the metallization, including the resistivities and the segmentation modes. The successfull experiences obtained on more than 50,000 large filter capacitors have led to transfer this technology to the energy storage field. For this application in which the voltages and the energy are often high, the self-healing process is secured by some other resistivity levels and some different modes of segmentation in order to reduce the inrush energy in the local breakdown and to meet the discharge current requirements.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Metallizing; Railroad rolling stock; Direct current capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Pierorazio A.J., Birk A.M.
Title: Effects of pressure relief valve behaviour on 2-phase energy storage in a pressure vessel exposed to fire
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Queen's University, Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont. K7L 3N6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Pierorazio, A.J., Queen's University, Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont. K7L 3N6, Canada; Birk, A.M., Queen's University, Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont. K7L 3N6, Canada
Abstract: Recent studies have shown that the hazards associated with loss of containment and BLEVEs (Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapour Explosions) are strongly tied to the energy stored in the liquid phase of a pressure vessel. This stored energy is affected by heat transfer with the surroundings (eg. fire exposure) and pressure relief valve (PRV) action. Since it would be desirable to minimize this stored energy to reduce hazards, a study was initiated by Transport Canada and Queen's University to quantify the effect of various PRV parameters on the thermal energy storage of a pressure vessel. A fully-automated state-of-the-art test facility has been constructed to perform 2-phase blowdown tests using steam and water. This paper describes the Queen's University/Transport Canada PRV Test Program and the test procedures and facilities used. It goes on to show some preliminary results from 2-phase testing currently underway to determine the optimal PRV operating characteristics from a hazard mitigation standpoint. The results of this study may be useful for standards-writing bodies to set experimentally determined optimal behaviour criteria for PRVs and acceptable tolerances for deviation from this.
Index Keywords: Explosions; Fires; Hazards; Heat transfer; Pressure vessels; Steam; Water; Boiling liquid expanding vapor explosions (BLEVE); Thermal energy storage; Pressure relief valves

Authors: Trifoglio Massimo, Gianotti Fulvio, Stephen John B., Ferro Gianclaudio, Visparelli Daniele
Title: Science test equipment for the INTEGRAL-PICsIT instrument
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Trifoglio, Massimo, Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy; Gianotti, Fulvio, Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy; Stephen, John B., Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy; Ferro, Gianclaudio, Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy; Visparelli, Daniele, Istituto TeSRE/CNR, Bologna, Italy
Abstract: The IBIS (Imager on Board INTEGRAL Satellite) instrument is a telescope designed to produce images of the high-energy sky with an angular resolution of several arcminutes over a wide field of view. This is obtained by use of a coded aperture in conjunction with two separate position sensitive detection planes. The upper layer, ISGRI (INTEGRAL Soft Gamma-Ray Imager) consists of 16384 CdTe elements and operates between 15 and 600 keV, while the underlying layer PICsIT (Pixellated Imaging CsI Telescope) comprises 8 identical modules housing altogether 4096 CsI(Tl) scintillating crystals coupled to PIN photodiodes and functions between 0.15 and 10 MeV. The PICsIT Science Test Equipment has been designed in order to support the functional, environmental and calibration tests of the PICsIT detector at all test levels (from 1 to 8 modules), including when the PICsIT module is integrated in the IBIS instrument and, afterwards, when IBIS itself is integrated in the spacecraft. To this end, the system has been distributed over two workstations: the On-line Science Console and the Off-line Science Console. The On-line Science Console manages the interfacing with the equipment which commands and acquires the data from the instrument, the near-real time acquisition unpacking and storage of the instrument data, and also allows the operator to continuously monitor the calibration procedure from a scientific point of view. The Off-line Science Console allows the operator to perform more detailed investigations of the instrument performances. The system as implemented for the Engineering Model tests and calibration and the current status of the project are described.
Index Keywords: Astronomy; Calibration; Gamma rays; Optical resolving power; Photodiodes; Offline science console; Online science console; Telescopes

Authors: Zhang Xiaoqing, Xia Zhongfu, Pan Yonggang, Zhang Yewen
Title: Influence of boron ion implantation on the mechanics and electret properties of Si3N4 single layer film
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Xiaoqing, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Xia, Zhongfu, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Pan, Yonggang, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Zhang, Yewen, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Amorphous silicon nitride (Si3N4) film has outstanding electret properties and it is compatible to the micromachining technology. Therefore, it is expected to use as electret vibrating membrane in miniature microphone. One of the most important parameters of characterizing electret-vibrating membrane is flexibility, so the reduction of internal stress due to boron ion implantation for the LPCVD Si3N4 film on silicon substrate is discussed first. The charge storage ability for the Si3N4 films B+ implanted by various doses and energies are investigated by means of negative corona charging, the isothermal surface potential decay measurements and open-circuit thermally stimulated discharge (TSD) current spectrum analysis.
Index Keywords: Amorphous films; Boron; Chemical vapor deposition; Electrets; Electric corona; Electric current measurement; Ion implantation; Micromachining; Positive ions; Pressure effects; Spectrum analysis; Thermal effects; Charge decay; Electret vibrating membrane; Isothermal surface potential decay measurements; Low pressure chemical vapor deposition; Mechanistic property; Negative corona charging; Thermally stimulated discharge current spectrum analysis; Silicon nitride

Authors: Bryant Ph., Griesmayer E., Jericha E., Rauch H., Regler M., Schonauer H.
Title: 0.5 MW/10 Hz option of the spallation source AUSTRON
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bryant, Ph., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Griesmayer, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Jericha, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Rauch, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Regler, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schonauer, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: In 1993-94 a feasibility study for AUSTRON, a neutron spallation source, was made on behalf of the Austrian Ministry of Science and Research. At that time, the machine was a synchrotron cycling at 25 Hz and delivering an average beam power of 205 kW at 1.6 GeV. An option to double the power by doubling the frequency was foreseen. Now a more ambitious development of the original concept is proposed that aims at 0.5 MW at 1.6 GeV, pulsed at either 50 Hz or 10 Hz. The slow repetition rate is achieved by the addition of a storage ring holding four consecutive (single bunch) pulses from the 50 Hz synchrotron until a fifth pulse is accelerated and transferred to the target with the four stored ones. In this way, an energy per pulse of 50 kJ (one half of the pulse energy of the 5 MW ESS) is obtained, yielding about 3.5×1016 thermal neutrons/(s cm2). This peak flux matches well a number of innovative instruments and allows unprecedented resolution for some more conventional ones. On August 20, 1998, the Austrian Government has unanimously decided to contribute one third of the total cost of the facility and invites international partners to participate.
Index Keywords: Storage rings; Synchrotrons; Targets; Neutron spallation source; Neutron sources

Authors: Bhat C., Spentzouris L.K., Colestock P.L.
Title: Measurements of intrabeam scattering rates below transition in the Fermilab antiproton accumulator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhat, C., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Spentzouris, L.K., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Colestock, P.L., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: An important factor in the successful operation of the Antiproton Recycler Project at Fermilab is the rate at which intrabeam scattering heats the stored beam in each plane. This machine will operate below transition energy. An application of classical intrabeam scattering theory for such a machine indicates that transverse or longitudinal cooling might occur, rather than heating, under certain conditions. However, this effect has not been studied experimentally. Hence, we have undertaken a study of the heating/cooling rates below transition in a coasting antiproton beam in the Fermilab Accumulator Ring, in an attempt to verify the theoretical models in this regime. This storage ring, employs a variety of stochastic cooling systems which can be used to alter the ratio of emittances in each plane as the initial conditions for our experiment. We have used both a conventional free-expansion technique as well as a longitudinal-echo-decay-rates technique to determine the scattering rates. In this paper, we present a preliminary analysis of our data and its comparison with various intra-beam scattering models below transition.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; Numerical analysis; Particle beam dynamics; Scattering; Accumulator rings; Intrabeam scattering; Transition energy; Storage rings

Authors: Irwin Mary Jane, Narayanan Vijaykrishnan
Title: Energy issues in multimedia systems
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Irwin, Mary Jane, Pennsylvania State Univ, United States; Narayanan, Vijaykrishnan, Pennsylvania State Univ, United States
Abstract: This paper presents possible optimizations to reduce the energy budget for SoC designs that will be used in next generation multimedia systems. Since future multimedia systems will include the processor core(s), the entire memory system, system buses, I/O controllers, system clocking and control and, in wireless applications, RF components, all on one chip, lowering power dissipation in next generation multimedia chips presents a number of design challenges. Possible strategies for managing the power budget in future multimedia SoCs are presented. Reducing the power consumption of the memory system, system control, and system buses are a particular focus.
Index Keywords: Computer architecture; Energy utilization; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Storage allocation (computer); Memory systems; System buses; Multimedia systems

Authors: Anferov V.A., Blinov B.B., Crandell D.A., Derbenev Ya.S., Kageya T., Koutin S.V., Krisch A.D., Phelps R.A., Lorenzon W., Ratner L.G., Sivers D.W., Sourkont K.V., Wong V.K., Youssof S.S., Chu C.M.
Title: Siberian snake experiments at the IUCF Cooler Ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anferov, V.A., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Blinov, B.B., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Crandell, D.A., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Derbenev, Ya.S., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Kageya, T., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Koutin, S.V., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Krisch, A.D., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Phelps, R.A., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Lorenzon, W., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Ratner, L.G., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Sivers, D.W., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Sourkont, K.V., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Wong, V.K., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Youssof, S.S., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Chu, C.M., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Recent polarized proton beam experiments in the IUCF Cooler Ring found an evidence for a second-order snake depolarizing resonance, when the vertical betatron tune was inadvertently set near a quarter-integer. We have also studied the possibility of spin-flipping the beam polarization in the presence of a full Siberian snake using an rf solenoid. By varying the rf solenoid's ramp time and frequency range, we reached a spin-flip efficiency of about 97%.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; High energy physics; Polarization; Protons; Solenoids; Tuning; Second-order snake depolarizing resonances; Spin-flip efficiency; Storage rings

Authors: Barry W., Byrd J., Corlett J.N., Li D., Fox J., Minty M., Prabhaker S., Teytelman D.
Title: Operational experience with the PEP-II transverse coupled-bunch feedback systems
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barry, W., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Byrd, J., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Corlett, J.N., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Li, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Fox, J., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Minty, M., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Prabhaker, S., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Teytelman, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Operational experience with the PEP-II high energy ring (HER) and low energy ring (LER) transverse coupled-bunch feedback systems is discussed. In particular, some key performance data including beam transfer function, mode spectrum, and some growth rate observations are presented. In general, growth rates much greater than expected have been observed in the HER. LER growth rates have not been measured but are thought to be lower than those of the HER based on lower feedback gains required for LER beam stabilization. Some results from experiments using the longitudinal feedback system electronics in conjunction with the transverse feedback system to study the HER instabilities are presented.
Index Keywords: Feedback; Positrons; Storage rings; High energy ring (HER); Low energy ring (LER); Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Ortega Romeo, van der Schaft Arjan, Maschke Bernhard, Escobar Gerardo
Title: Energy-shaping of port-controlled Hamiltonian systems by interconnection
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Decision and Control
Affiliations: Lab des Signaux et Systemes, Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Ortega, Romeo, Lab des Signaux et Systemes, Yvette, France; van der Schaft, Arjan, Lab des Signaux et Systemes, Yvette, France; Maschke, Bernhard, Lab des Signaux et Systemes, Yvette, France; Escobar, Gerardo, Lab des Signaux et Systemes, Yvette, France
Abstract: Passivity-based control (PBC) has shown to be very powerful to design robust controllers for physical systems described by Euler-Lagrange (EL) equations of motion. The application of PBC in regulation problems of mechanical systems yields controllers that have a clear physical interpretation in terms of interconnection of the system with its environment. In particular the total energy of the closed-loop is the difference between the energy of the system and the energy supplied by the controller. Furthermore, since the EL structure is preserved in closed-loop, PBC is robust vis a vis unmodeled dissipative effects. Unfortunately, these nice properties are sometimes lost when PBC is used in other applications, for instance, in electrical and electromechanical systems. In this paper we further contribute to develop a new PBC theory encompassing a broader class of systems, and preserving the aforementioned energy-balancing stabilization mechanism and the structure invariance, continuing upon our work in [14], [9] and [17]. Towards this end we consider port-controlled Hamiltonian systems with dissipation (PCHD), which result from the network modeling of energy-conserving lumped-parameter physical systems with independent storage elements, and strictly contain the class of EL models.
Index Keywords: Closed loop control systems; Energy dissipation; Equations of motion; Invariance; Large scale systems; Mathematical models; Robustness (control systems); Energy shaping; Euler Lagrange operation; Port controlled Hamiltonian systems; Possivity based control; Control system synthesis

Authors: Kanaya Noriichi, Asaoka Seiji, Maezawa Hideki
Title: Vacuum-pump control system using programmable logic controllers on the TCP/IP network for the 2.5-GeV storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanaya, Noriichi, High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Asaoka, Seiji, High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan; Maezawa, Hideki, High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: A vacuum-pump control system has been developed using programmable-logic controllers (PLC) for the 2.5-GeV storage ring at the Photon Factory, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK). There are sixty-six titanium-getter vacuum pumps at the storage ring. Evacuation of gases in the storage ring is done by controlling the current in the titanium filaments in the vacuum pump (max 50A). A PLC has a TCP/IP network port, 16-bit-digital output ports connected to sixteen solid-state relays (SSR) for current control. The PLC can simultaneously control up to sixteen pumps. These vacuum pumps are connected to SSRs which chop the AC current so as to control the current in the pumps. To operate the pumps, the pump current must have a trapezoidal-shaped current form. The PLC is configured so that the current in the pumps has a trapezoidal form associated with pre-heating, evacuation, and cooling-down phases of the pump. PLCs are connected to a personal computer (PC) through the network. The PC can automatically control the PLCs by sending a set of commands through the TCP/IP network. The commands specify the duration of the current form. Upon receiving a command from a PC running under WindowsNT through the network, the PLC generates pulse-trains through the digital output ports to trigger the SSRs in association with the operating phases. The design of the vacuum-pump control system is discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer control; Control system analysis; Control system synthesis; Electric current control; Internet; Network protocols; Programmable logic controllers; Vacuum pumps; Internet protocol (IP); Transmission control protocol (TCP); Storage rings

Authors: Ruggiero A.G.
Title: Circular RFQ storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ruggiero, A.G., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a novel idea of storage ring for the accumulation of intense beams of light and heavy ions at low energy. The new concept is a natural development of the combined features of conventional storage rings and ion traps, and is basically a linear RFQ bent on itself. The advantages are: smaller beam dimensions, higher beam intensity, and a more compact storage device.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Ion beams; Radio-frequency quadrupole (RFQ) storage rings; Storage rings

Authors: Alonso Jose R.
Title: Spallation neutron source project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alonso, Jose R., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: The SNS is a `joint-venture' project of five DOE National Laboratories, aimed at building the world's most powerful accelerator-based pulse spallation source. At its planned 2 MW operation, it will produce neutron fluxes at least a factor of ten greater than Rutherford Appleton Laboratory's ISIS, currently the world's leading spallation source. The current design of the SNS, shown in Figure 1, calls for 600 ns pulses of 1 GeV protons striking a liquid mercury target at a 60 Hz rate. Room-temperature and cryogenic moderators produce beams of slow neutrons suitable for materials research. Responsibility for system components is as follows: LBNL will provide the high-brightness H- ion source, transport structures and a 2.5-MeV RFQ accelerator; Los Alamos will build linacs to bring the beam to the full energy of 1 GeV; Brookhaven will build the accumulator ring to compress the 1 ms linac pulse into the sharp pulse delivered to the target; ≈1200 turns will be injected, storing 2×1014 protons in the ring, which are extracted in a single turn; Oak Ridge will provide the mercury target systems and all conventional facilities; and Argonne and Oak Ridge are coordinating the design of at least 10 neutron-scattering instruments to be provided as the initial suite of experiment stations. The project is formally underway, having been approved and funded by DOE and the US Congress for a construction start in FY99. Neutron beams will be available for users in FY06.
Index Keywords: Neutron scattering; Storage rings; Cryogenic moderators; Neutron sources

Authors: Andreev V., Gorchenko V., Govorov A., Kirichenko A., Kovalenko A., Kulikov I., Mikhailov V., Monchinsky V., Romanov S., Sveshnikov B., Tsarenkov A., Vasilishin B., Voevodin M., Volkov V.
Title: Nuclotron beam diagnostics
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Andreev, V., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Gorchenko, V., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Govorov, A., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Kirichenko, A., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Kovalenko, A., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Kulikov, I., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Mikhailov, V., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Monchinsky, V., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Romanov, S., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Sveshnikov, B., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Tsarenkov, A., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Vasilishin, B., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Voevodin, M., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Volkov, V., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation
Abstract: The superconducting synchrotron Nuclotron was put into operation in March 1993 at the Laboratory of High Energies, JINR in Dubna. The Nuclotron Control System (NCS) provided an efficient support for the machine operation during all runs. The dedicated NCS subsystem for beam diagnostics in the injection transfer line and the Nuclotron ring is described.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Particle beam injection; Superconducting magnets; Nuclotrons; Storage rings

Authors: Sun B.G., Chen L.K., Wang J.H., Jin Y.M., Wang G.C., Lu P.
Title: Bunch length measurement and its lengthening in HLS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, B.G., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China; Chen, L.K., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China; Wang, J.H., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China; Jin, Y.M., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China; Wang, G.C., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China; Lu, P., Univ of Science and Technology of, China, Anhui, China
Abstract: The paper discusses the method and principle of bunch length measured by HP54121T 20 GHz digital sampling oscilloscope in Hefei Light Source (HLS) ring. The measurement results of the bunch length and the energy spread are given. The rms. bunch length is about 3.8 to approximately 10.33 cm. A new theory on the bunch lengthening is used to explain the experimental results. It is proved that the beam-cavity interaction is the most important factor to the multi-bunch lengthening of HLS.
Index Keywords: Cathode ray oscilloscopes; Electron energy levels; Storage rings; Electron bunches; Electron beams

Authors: Gerber M.B., Hofsajer I.W.
Title: Evaluation of suitability of electromagnetic integration in single switch single stage unity power factor correction converters
Affiliations: Rand Afrikaans Univ, Auckland Park, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Gerber, M.B., Rand Afrikaans Univ, Auckland Park, South Africa; Hofsajer, I.W., Rand Afrikaans Univ, Auckland Park, South Africa
Abstract: With planar inductive components, it is possible to integrate electric energy storage functions into the conventional winding window, without a significant increase in the overall volume. This electromagnetic integration is well suited to high volume low cost manufacturing techniques. The limitations of the currently available planar electromagnetic integration technology limits the choice of topology that can be realistically integrated. In this paper several unity power factor correction converter topologies are analysed with regards to electromagnetic integration is analysed and predictions made as to what may be achieved as planar electromagnetic integration technology advances.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric network topology; Electric power factor correction; Electric windings; Network components; Power converters; Electromagnetic integration technology; Inductive components; Planar magnetic structures; Integrated circuit manufacture

Authors: Kolyada Yu.E., Fedun V.I., Onishchenko N.I.
Title: Commutation of high current pulse electric schemes using the inductance with a rectangular hysteresis loop
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Priazovsky Gos. Techn. Univ, Mariupol, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Kolyada, Yu.E., Priazovsky Gos. Techn. Univ, Mariupol, Ukraine; Fedun, V.I., Priazovsky Gos. Techn. Univ, Mariupol, Ukraine; Onishchenko, N.I., Priazovsky Gos. Techn. Univ, Mariupol, Ukraine
Abstract: Two-electrodes commutator for power electric scheme switching is proposed and investigated at the following operation mode. Closing of high current scheme is realized by applying of high voltage low current pulse to commuted gap. By means of nonlinear inductance that separated the commutator and the main power capacitor storage element, the conditions were fulfilled at which nonlinear inductance had the high inductive resistance for triggering signal because of operating at linear part of hysteresis loop, but low one for the main power electric scheme at the saturation region. The tests of such system has been carried out at the power plasma gun working. The stored energy 100 kJ of 50 capacitors 150 μF and 5 kV each was commuted by the triggering pulse of 10 sec triangular shape with voltage amplitude 30-100 kV and current up to 10 A.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric commutation; Electric commutators; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Magnetic hysteresis; Plasma guns; Hysteresis loops; Pulse power electric schemes switching; Electric switches

Authors: Polulyakh E.P., Plotnikova L.A., Afanas'ev V.A., Kharinov M.I., Kondratenco A.K., Klimenco E.Yu., Novicov V.I.
Title: Development of toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storages (SMES) for high-current pulsed power supplies
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Polulyakh, E.P., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Plotnikova, L.A., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Afanas'ev, V.A., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Kharinov, M.I., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Kondratenco, A.K., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Klimenco, E.Yu., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation; Novicov, V.I., Troitsk Inst for Innovation and, Fusion Research, Troitsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: A brief description of the superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) constructions, their performances and experimental results are presented. Possibilities of their weight-dimension characteristic optimization have been shown. Opportunities for `Dual Use' of such superconducting magnetic systems are considered.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Superconducting magnets

Authors: Bardi A., Belferte S., Dell'Orso M., Galeotti S., Giannetti P., Leger A., Meschi E., Speer T., Spinella F., Wu X.
Title: A Prototype of Programmable Associative Memory for Track Finding
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Piazza Torricelli 2, 56100 Pisa, Italy; INFN Pisa, Via Livornese 1291, 56010 S. Piero A Grado (PI), Italy; Département de Physique Nucléaire et Corpusculaire, Université de Genève, 24 Quai Ernest-Ansermet, CH-1211 Genève, Switzerland; CERN/Div. PPE, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bardi, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Piazza Torricelli 2, 56100 Pisa, Italy; Belferte, S., INFN Pisa, Via Livornese 1291, 56010 S. Piero A Grado (PI), Italy; Dell'Orso, M., Département de Physique Nucléaire et Corpusculaire, Université de Genève, 24 Quai Ernest-Ansermet, CH-1211 Genève, Switzerland; Galeotti, S., CERN/Div. PPE, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland; Giannetti, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Piazza Torricelli 2, 56100 Pisa, Italy; Leger, A., INFN Pisa, Via Livornese 1291, 56010 S. Piero A Grado (PI), Italy; Meschi, E., Département de Physique Nucléaire et Corpusculaire, Université de Genève, 24 Quai Ernest-Ansermet, CH-1211 Genève, Switzerland; Speer, T., CERN/Div. PPE, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland; Spinella, F., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Piazza Torricelli 2, 56100 Pisa, Italy; Wu, X., INFN Pisa, Via Livornese 1291, 56010 S. Piero A Grado (PI), Italy
Abstract: We present a device, based on the concept of associative memory for pattern recognition, dedicated to on-line track finding in high-energy physics experiments. A large pattern bank, describing all possible tracks, can be organized into Field Programmable Gate Arrays where all patterns are compared in parallel to data coming from the detector during readout. Patterns, recognized among 266 possible combinations, are output in a few 30 MHz clock cycles. Prograrnmability results in a flexible, simple architecture and it allows to keep up smoothly with technology improvements. A 64 PAM array has been assembled on a prototype VME board and fully tested up to 30 MHz. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Field programmable gate arrays; Particle beam tracking; Programmable associative memories; Particle detectors

Authors: Yan Xinxiang, Patterson Dean
Title: Improvement of drive range, acceleration and deceleration performance in an electric vehicle propulsion system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Northern Territory Univ, Darwin, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Xinxiang, Northern Territory Univ, Darwin, Australia; Patterson, Dean, Northern Territory Univ, Darwin, Australia
Abstract: This paper presents technologies that will be employed in a battery electric vehicle, aiming at improving the vehicle drive range, acceleration and deceleration performance and reducing the cost. Firstly it discusses a short-term power management scheme employing a high-power-density ultracapacitor bank to load level a high-energy-density, cost-effective but low-power-density Zinc Bromine battery for satisfactory overall performance of the vehicle power source. Then it looks at the issue of constant power operation of a BDCM propulsion system. A novel multifunctional dc-dc converter topology has been proposed for both short-term power management and the constant power operation of the BDCM propulsion system. It features simple circuitry, high efficiency, and low cost. Analysis of the operation principles of the multifunctional dc-dc converter is given. Control methods of regenerative braking of a BDCM at different operation modes are especially addressed.
Index Keywords: Battery electric vehicle; Electric vehicle propulsion system; Power management; Zinc bromine battery; Acceleration; Capacitors; Cost effectiveness; Deceleration; Electric network topology; Land vehicle propulsion; Power control; Power converters; Storage battery vehicles

Authors: King Bruce J.
Title: Studies for muon collider parameters at center-of-mass energies of 10 TeV and 100 TeV
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: King, Bruce J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: Parameter lists are presented for speculative muon colliders at center-of-mass energies of 10 TeV and 100 TeV. The technological advances required to achieve the given parameters are itemized and discussed, and a discussion is given of the design goals and constraints. An important constraint for multi-TeV muon colliders is the need to minimize neutrino radiation from the collider ring.
Index Keywords: Elementary particle sources; Storage rings; Muon colliders; Neutrinos; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Gao J.
Title: Intrinsic upper limit to the beam energy of an electron-positron circular collider
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: LAL, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Gao, J., LAL, Orsay, France
Abstract: In this paper we predict that there exists an intrinsic upper limit to the beam energy of an e+e- circular collider due to the beam-beam effects. The maximum beam energy is given by E0,max = 85.17√NIP(GeV), where NIP is the number of the interaction points in the ring. It is concluded that LEP is the only machine on this planet which has the potential to test the validity of this theoretical prediction by reducing its interaction points to one.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Storage rings; Electron-positron circular colliders; Particle beam energy; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: von Holtey G., Lamont M.
Title: Protection of LEP experiments against particle background at highest beam energies
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: von Holtey, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lamont, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The main particle backgrounds at LEP are off-energy electrons and positrons and synchrotron radiation photons. While the former are normally acceptable and are not expected to increase with energy, the latter is many orders of magnitude larger than can be tolerated and increases rapidly with beam energy. The LEP collimator protection system, designed for 45 GeV, therefore had to be extended to cope with much increased photon rates to be expected at twice the beam energy. General experience with background rates in the LEP experiments at highest beam energies are reported.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Particle detectors; Photons; Positrons; Radiation shielding; Synchrotron radiation; Electron-positron storage rings; Storage rings

Authors: Sullivan M., Cai Y., Donald M., Ecklund S., Fieguth T., Field C., Fisher A.S., Henderson L., Himel T., Krejcik P., Mazaheri G., Minty M., Reichel I., Seeman J., Wienands U.
Title: Beam-beam collisions at the PEP-II B Factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sullivan, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Cai, Y., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Donald, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Ecklund, S., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Fieguth, T., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Field, C., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Fisher, A.S., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Henderson, L., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Himel, T., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Krejcik, P., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Mazaheri, G., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Minty, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Reichel, I., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Seeman, J., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Wienands, U., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: We describe first beam collisions at the PEP-II B Factory, a collaboration of SLAC, LBNL, and LLNL. The beams are brought close to each other in the transverse (x,y) and longitudinal (timing) directions through the use of two shared beam position monitors located 0.72 m from either side of the interaction point (IP). Transverse beam-beam deflection scans and the use of a zero-angle luminosity detector allow us to center the collisions. Beam collisions were also seen by exciting one beam at its tune frequency and observing a response in the other beam at the same frequency. Shifts in betatron tunes have also been measured. To date, the peak measured luminosity attained is 5.2±1×1032 cm-2 s-1 with 786 bunches in each beam and with beam currents of 354 mA for the high-energy beam (HEB) and 680 mA for the low-energy beam (LEB).
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Colliding beam accelerators; Particle beam dynamics; Tuning; Beam-beam collisions; Zero-angle luminosity detectors; Storage rings

Authors: Carlson R.W., Thomas G.R., Hovingh J.
Title: Radiant heat transfer from storage casks to the environment
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
