Authors with affiliations: Carlson, R.W., Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Thomas, G.R., Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Hovingh, J., Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: A spent fuel storage cask must efficiently transfer the heat released by the fuel assemblies through the cask walls to the environment. This heat must be transferred through passive means, limiting the energy transfer mechanisms from the cask to natural convection and radiation heat transfer. Natural convection is essentially independent of the characteristics of the array of casks, provided there is space between casks to permit a convection loop. Radiation heat transfer, however, depends on the geometric arrangement of the array of casks because the peripheral casks will shadow the interior casks and restrict radiant heat transfer from all casks to the environment. The shadowing of one cask by its neighbors is determined by a view factor that represents the fraction of radiant energy that leaves the surface of a cask and reaches the environment. This paper addresses the evaluation of the view factor between a centrally located spent fuel storage cask and the environment. By combining analytic expressions for the view factor of (1) infinitely long cylinders and (2) finite cylinders with a length-to-diameter ratio of 2 to represent spent fuel storage casks, the view factor can be evaluated for any practical array of spent fuel storage casks.
Index Keywords: Containers; Energy transfer; Heat radiation; Natural convection; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Spent nuclear fuel storage casks; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Miller J.M., Gale A.R., Sankaran V.A.
Title: Electric drive subsystem for a low-storage requirement hybrid electric vehicle
Affiliations: Ford Research Laboratory, Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, MI 48121, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, J.M., Ford Research Laboratory, Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, MI 48121, United States; Gale, A.R., Ford Research Laboratory, Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, MI 48121, United States; Sankaran, V.A., Ford Research Laboratory, Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, MI 48121, United States
Abstract: Integrating an electric machine drive system into the powertrain of a hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) represents a challenging exercise in packaging complex electromechanical and power electronic subsystems. The Ford combined alternator starter (FCAS) and its attendant power and control electronics are physically partitioned because power electronics has not yet evolved to the stage in which fully packaged drives can be realized. A similar situation exists for the control and sensor subsystems necessary for a fully functional high-performance drive. Hardware partitioning requires that more attention be given to installation issues and to mitigating system interactions. The FCAS system consists of an integrated starter/alternator (S/A), an S/A module (SAM), and a vehicle electrical infrastructure that can support the power and energy levels demanded. Our field experience with the FCAS system will be presented along with test results obtained from vehicle operation.
Index Keywords: Power electronics; Starters; Synchronous generators; Hybrid electric vehicles (HEV); Integrated power electronic module; Electric vehicles

Authors: Bulyak E., Dovbnya A., Gladkikh P., Grigor'ev Yu., Karnaukhov I., Khodyachikh A., Kononenko S., Lapshin V., Molodkin V., Mytsykov A., Nemoshkalenko V., Shcherbakov A., Shpak A., Telegin Yu., Zelinsky A.
Title: Compact X-ray source based on Compton scattering
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Bulyak, E., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Dovbnya, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Gladkikh, P., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Grigor'ev, Yu., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Karnaukhov, I., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Khodyachikh, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Kononenko, S., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Lapshin, V., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Molodkin, V., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Mytsykov, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Nemoshkalenko, V., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shcherbakov, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shpak, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Telegin, Yu., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine; Zelinsky, A., NSC KIPT, Kharkov, Ukraine
Abstract: The paper discusses the use of Compton backscattering of an intense laser light on a relativistic electron beam to produce high-intensity γ beams, and also the practicability of the concept. Requirements on the parameters of electron and photon beams are described, and the lattice of the electron storage ring with a beam energy up to 150 MeV is proposed, wherein experiments on intense photon beam generation and laser cooling of the electron beam can be conducted. Electron beam parameters in the storage ring are calculated with due regard for the intrabeam scattering, photon beam parameters are also estimated. The scheme of experiment that enables the production of a photon beam with an intensity of approximately 1013s-1 is proposed.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic wave backscattering; Electron beams; Laser beams; Light scattering; Photons; Compton scattering; Photon beam generation; Storage rings

Authors: Chen S.Y., Xu H.J., Zhao Z.T.
Title: Shanghai synchrotron radiation facility
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Chinese Acad of Sciences, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, S.Y., Chinese Acad of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Xu, H.J., Chinese Acad of Sciences, Shanghai, China; Zhao, Z.T., Chinese Acad of Sciences, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) was proposed by the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Shanghai Municipal Government in 1995. The estimated total budget is around 120 M USD, and the operation is scheduled to begin by the end of 2004. Although the whole SSRF project is still awaiting final approval, its R&D has been approved already. The SSRF is a third generation light source designed to produce high brightness and flux soft X-ray and hard X-ray in the energy region of 0.1 to approximately 40 keV. It consists of a 300 MeV linac, a 3.5 GeV booster, a 3.5 GeV storage ring and dozens of beam lines and experimental stations. In this paper, the main parameters and features of the SSRF are presented.
Index Keywords: Light sources; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; X rays; Hard X rays; Soft X rays; Synchrotrons

Authors: Isbi Y., Sternklar S., Granot E., Lyubin V., Klebanov M., Lewis A.
Title: Sub-wavelength optical recording on chalcogenide glassy film
Affiliations: Non Linear Optics Group, Electrooptics Div., Soreq NRC, 81800, Yavne, Israel; Division of Applied Physics, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel; Department of Physics, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Isbi, Y., Non Linear Optics Group, Electrooptics Div., Soreq NRC, 81800, Yavne, Israel, Division of Applied Physics, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel; Sternklar, S., Non Linear Optics Group, Electrooptics Div., Soreq NRC, 81800, Yavne, Israel; Granot, E., Non Linear Optics Group, Electrooptics Div., Soreq NRC, 81800, Yavne, Israel; Lyubin, V., Department of Physics, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Klebanov, M., Department of Physics, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Lewis, A., Division of Applied Physics, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Chalcogenide glassy films are suggested as a candidate for near-field nano-writing. Photo-induced changes in the transmission (photo-darkening) of AsSe chalcogenide glassy films, using cw as well as pulsed green light, was investigated. The sensitivity of this effect is up to 500 times greater using single pulse (7 ns) illumination as compared to low power cw exposures. A 25% reduction of transmission using one pulse, at an energy flux achievable in the near field, makes this medium a good candidate for nano-writing. Recording of 125 nm-width lines is shown using cw illumination.
Index Keywords: Amorphous films; Continuous wave lasers; Laser beam effects; Laser pulses; Laser recording; Nanotechnology; Optical data storage; Optical glass; Optical microscopy; Photolithography; Pulsed laser applications; Selenium compounds; Chalcogenide glassy films; Subwavelength optical recording; Optical films

Authors: Hafner Brian J., Sanders Joan E.
Title: Theoretical effectiveness of energy storage and return prosthetic devices in trans-tibial amputees
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hafner, Brian J., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States; Sanders, Joan E., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the theoretical effectiveness of energy storage and return (ESR) devices in trans-tibial prosthetic devices. A mathematical model of an ESR prosthesis is used to evaluate the effect of ESR components on force transmission through the prosthesis. Results suggest that force transmission is more sensitive to stiffness than to the prosthesis damping components.
Index Keywords: Biomechanics; Joints (anatomy); Mathematical models; Stiffness; Trans-tibial amputees; Artificial limbs

Authors: Panickar P.S., Islam S.M., Bleijs J.A.M.
Title: Potential of load management to improve the economics of wind-diesel hybrid systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Murdoch Univ, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Panickar, P.S., Murdoch Univ, Australia; Islam, S.M., Murdoch Univ, Australia; Bleijs, J.A.M., Murdoch Univ, Australia
Abstract: This paper investigates the possibility of fuel savings obtainable from a wind-diesel hybrid system through load management strategies. Scope for improvement in system economics by selecting the optimum wind turbine capacity for the hybrid system is also explored. Comparison of performances was carried out using the 'Hybrid2' simulation program. The study was based on a single diesel and single wind generator without any storage. The diesel was allowed to operate continuously, with a minimum loading of 40% of its rated power maintained where necessary by a dump load. The first part of the study involved selection of appropriate diesel-wind combinations for achieving highest fuel savings and/or the lowest generation costs. An economic evaluation to calculate the cost/kWh of generated energy for the different hybrid combinations resulted in determining an optimum size of wind turbine for the system. The second part of the study investigated the effect of load management strategies. The results indicate a decrease in generation cost and fuel consumption and a considerable yearly saving on the diesel costs.
Index Keywords: Fuel savings; Wind diesel hybrid systems; Wind generator; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Electric load management; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Fuel consumption; Wind turbines; Wind power

Authors: Wu G., Bhat C.M., Brown B.C., Johnson D.E.
Title: Chromaticity control in the Fermilab Main Injector
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, G., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Bhat, C.M., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Brown, B.C., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Johnson, D.E., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: Chromaticity control in the Fermilab Main Injector will be important both in accelerating protons and antiprotons from 8 GeV to 150 GeV (or 120 GeV) and in decelerating recycled 150 GeV antiprotons to 8 GeV for storage in the Recycler Ring. The Main Injector has two families of sextupoles to control the chromaticity. In addition to the natural chromaticity, they must correct for sextupole fields from ramp-rate-dependent eddy currents in the dipole beam pipes and current-dependent sextupole fields in the dipole magnets. The horizontal sextupole family is required to operate in a bipolar mode below the transition energy of 20 GeV. We describe methods used to control chromaticities in the Fermilab Main Injector. Emphasis is given to the software implementation of the operator interface to the front-end ramp controllers. Results of chromaticity measurements and their comparison with the design model will be presented.
Index Keywords: Eddy currents; Particle beam injection; Protons; Antiprotons; Chromaticity; Particle injectors; Particle accelerator accessories

Authors: Galstjan E., Kazanskiy L.
Title: Project of semiconductor high-power high-repetition rate compact accelerator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: MRTI, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Galstjan, E., MRTI, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kazanskiy, L., MRTI, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: A compact accelerator capable of 120 kV, 2 kA, 15-25 ns pulse duration at 1 kHz repetition rate is described. These capabilities are made possible by employing inductive energy storage and modern high-power superfast semiconductor switches. These switches can reconnect at 0.1-1 ns at 1-10 kA and 10-100 kV. Switching is controlled with high accuracy, as the jitter in operation of keys does not exceed 20 ps. Thus, the repetition rates of switching is limited only by heat rejection from the device.
Index Keywords: Pulse generators; Semiconductor switches; Ultrafast phenomena; Semiconductor accelerators; Linear accelerators

Authors: Ryzhikov V.D., Starzhinskiy N.G., Kostyukevych S.O., Gal'chinetskii L.P., Danshin E.A., Kvitnitskaya V.Z., Chernikov V.V.
Title: Effect of surface of single crystals ZnSe(Te) and CsI(Tl) on dynamic characteristics of spectrometric parameters of detection blocks
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Ryzhikov, V.D., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Starzhinskiy, N.G., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Kostyukevych, S.O., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Gal'chinetskii, L.P., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Danshin, E.A., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Kvitnitskaya, V.Z., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Chernikov, V.V., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine
Abstract: Evaluation was made of changes in scintillation and dynamic characteristics of detection blocks of `scintillator-photodiode' type based on crystals ZnSe(Te) and CsI(Tl) after long-term storage of unprotected crystals under normal climatic conditions, as well as after action of water vapor. It is shown that changes of energy resolution (137Cs γ-quanta) of large CsI(Tl) crystals are not significant; only the radiation noise threshold is changed due to the phosphorescence of the disturbed surface layer of the crystal. For single crystals ZnSe(Te), which are used for spectrometry of charged particles and short-range gamma-radiation as thin plates, both dynamic noise threshold and spectrometric characteristics are changed. Possibilities to restore the initial crystal properties are discussed, and ways to protect the crystal surface from environmental effects are considered.
Index Keywords: Cesium compounds; Gamma ray spectrometers; Phosphorescence; Phosphors; Photodetectors; Photodiodes; Semiconducting zinc compounds; Semiconductor counters; Single crystals; Cesium iodide; Zinc selenide; Scintillation counters

Authors: King B.J., Moser S.S., Weggel R.J., Mokhov N.V.
Title: Cupronickel rotating band pion production target for muon colliders
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: King, B.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Moser, S.S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Weggel, R.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Mokhov, N.V., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: A conceptual design is presented for a high power cupronickel pion production target. It forms a circular band in a horizontal plane with approximate dimensions of: 2.5 meters radius, 6 cm high and 0.6 cm thick. The target is continuously rotated at 3 m/s to carry heat away from the production region to a water cooling channel. Bunches of 16 GeV protons with total energies of 270 kJ and repetition rates of 15 Hz are incident tangentially to arc of the target along the symmetry axis of a 20 Tesla solenoidal magnetic capture channel. The mechanical layout and cooling setup are described. Results are presented from realistic MARS Monte Carlo computer simulations of the pion yield and energy deposition in the target. ANSYS finite element calculations are beginning to give predictions for the resultant shock heating stresses.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Computer simulation; Cooling; Copper alloys; Electric arcs; Elementary particle sources; Finite element method; Monte Carlo methods; Proton irradiation; Solenoids; Storage rings; Targets; Muon colliders; Pion production targets; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Huang Zhirong, Ruth Ronald D.
Title: Radiative cooling of relativistic electron beams
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: APS/ANL, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Zhirong, APS/ANL, Argonne, United States; Ruth, Ronald D., APS/ANL, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Radiative cooling is a natural and effective method of phase-space cooling for stored electron beams. In electron storage rings the average effects of synchrotron radiation from the bending magnets cause the beam emittances in all three degrees of freedom to damp towards equilibria, determined by the fluctuating nature of quantum emissions. In this paper, we show that the radiation damping in a focusing system is fundamentally different from that in a bending system. Quantum excitation to the transverse dimensions is absent in a straight, continuous focusing channel, and is exponentially suppressed in a focusing-dominated ring. Thus, the transverse normalized emittances in such systems can in principle be damped to the Compton wavelength of the electron, limited only by the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. In addition, we investigate methods of rapid damping such as radiative laser cooling. We propose a laser-electron storage ring (LESR) where the electron beam in a compact storage ring repetitively interacts with an intense laser pulse stored in an optical resonator. The laser-electron interaction gives rise to fast cooling of electron beams and can be used to overcome the space-charge effects encountered in a medium-energy circular machine. Applications to the designs of ultra-low-emittance damping rings and compact x-ray sources are also explored.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Electric space charge; Electron beams; Laser pulses; Laser-electron storage ring (LESR); Radiative cooling; Storage rings

Authors: Manohara H.M., Morikawa E., Choi J., Sprunger P.T.
Title: Pattern transfer by direct photo etching of poly(vinylidene fluoride) using X rays
Affiliations: J. Bennet Johnston, Sr. Ctr. for A., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70806, United States
Authors with affiliations: Manohara, H.M., J. Bennet Johnston, Sr. Ctr. for A., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70806, United States; Morikawa, E., J. Bennet Johnston, Sr. Ctr. for A., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70806, United States; Choi, J., J. Bennet Johnston, Sr. Ctr. for A., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70806, United States; Sprunger, P.T., J. Bennet Johnston, Sr. Ctr. for A., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70806, United States
Abstract: A direct pattern transfer method has been developed by photo etching poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) using X rays (1-16 keV) from a synchrotron storage ring. The ability to pattern thin film of PVDF, a piezoelectric, pyroelectric and ferroelectric polymer, has potential applications in the areas of MEMS, nonlinear optics, and nonvolatile ferroelectric random access memory technology. Without the use of any reactive chemical gas, a maximum etched depth in excess of 9 μm is achieved. The etched depth for a given photon energy approaches saturation with respect to exposure time. An in situ mass spectrometry revealed the evolution of hydrogen, fluorine, and hydrogen fluoride species. The etched regions turned dark in color indicating a possible increase in the fraction of carbon atoms. The X-ray transmittance of photo etched PVDF approached that of a pure carbon as the exposure time is increased. Upon etching the root mean-square surface roughness of the etched portion increased by more than a factor of two. The rate of etching increased at elevated sample temperatures.
Index Keywords: Etching; Fluorine containing polymers; Microelectromechanical devices; Surface roughness; Vinyl resins; X rays; Photo etching; Polyvinylidene fluoride; Photolithography

Authors: Paciura K., Hancke G.P., Grzesiak L., Koczara W., da Ponte Manuel
Title: Battery energy storage system for the Hygen electricity generator and power supply system
Affiliations: Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Paciura, K., Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Hancke, G.P., Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Grzesiak, L., Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Koczara, W., Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; da Ponte, Manuel, Univ of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: Batteries are the Achilles' heel in power supply systems which include energy storage through series connected battery strings. Even though the duty cycles of batteries in UPS applications are the least troublesome, in mission critical UPS applications batteries are replaced prematurely to guarantee reliability. In Hybrid Electric Vehicles and the Hygen application, batteries are subjected to abusive operating conditions and severe duty cycles. Popular batteries and established Battery Management Systems have proved to be unreliable. An energy storage system, utilizing Advanced Lead-Acid batteries and a special battery monitoring and control system, was developed for the Hygen application.
Index Keywords: Acids; Control systems; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Lead; Storage battery vehicles; Uninterruptible power systems; Battery energy storage systems; Hybrid electric vehicles; Hybrid electricity generators; Lead acid battery; Electric batteries

Authors: Amjadi H.
Title: Charge storage in double layers of thermally grown silicon dioxide and APCVD silicon nitride
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
Affiliations: Institute for Telecommunications and Electroacoustics, Darmstadt University of Technology, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Amjadi, H., Institute for Telecommunications and Electroacoustics, Darmstadt University of Technology, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Experimental results on charge storage and discharge in double layers of silicon dioxide and silicon nitride will be reported and discussed. SiO2 with a thickness of 300 nm was thermally grown on silicon wafers, while cover layers of Si3N4 with thicknesses of 50, 100, and 150 nm were deposited chemically at atmospheric pressure. The samples were charged by the point-to-grid corona method. At room temperature, the measured surface potential V was stable during a period of almost three years. Isothermal measurements under different environmental conditions showed an improved charge retention compared to a single layer of thermally grown silicon dioxide. After approximately 3 h at 300 °C, the observed voltage drop was <10% for the double layers and approximately 60% for bare SiO2. Similar results were obtained under a humid condition of 95%RH and 60 °C. Besides, thermally stimulated current (TSC) was measured in an open-circuit setup with a temperature ramp of 200 °C/h. For the double layers, a current peak with a maximum temperature at approximately 500 °C was observed. The measured current in the range of 300 to 400 °C, the location of current maxima observed in thermally grown silicon dioxide or APCVD silicon nitride, was negligible. In addition to improved electret properties the internal stress in the investigated double layers can be adjusted by a proper thickness ratio of oxide layer to nitride layer. Therefore double layers of silicon dioxide and nitride seem to be promising materials for integrated sensors and actuators based on the electret effect.
Index Keywords: Chemical vapor deposition; Electrets; Electric corona; Electric energy storage; Residual stresses; Semiconducting silicon compounds; Semiconductor growth; Silicon wafers; Thermally stimulated currents (TSC); Electric insulating coatings

Authors: Menzl Frank, Lehmann Jochen
Title: Application of automatic control systems and the utilisation of renewable energy sources in the complex laboratory of alternative energy
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Fachhochschule Stralsund, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Menzl, Frank, Fachhochschule Stralsund, Germany; Lehmann, Jochen, Fachhochschule Stralsund, Germany
Abstract: The utilisation of renewable energy sources for the supply of energy has been increased rapidly in Europe and Germany over the past 10 years. Wind power plants and photovoltaic installations are grid connected, which is the best operating regime. But for island solutions with a weak main supply or sites were excess energy cannot be consumed, a storage of energy is necessary or useful. Hydrogen can be used as an energy carrier for such solutions. Both variants can be investigated in the Complex Laboratory of Alternative Energy at the Stralsund University of Applied Sciences. One main installation is a wind electrolyser system. The system comprises a 100 kW windmill, a 20 kW electrolyser and a 200 Nm3 pressure tank. Furthermore, the application of programmable logic devices and process visualisation programs as well as automatic control systems is necessary. The whole system has been described in the article. Furthermore, operating experiences will be reported. After than an outlook for further projects will be given.
Index Keywords: Computer software; Control systems; Laboratories; Logic devices; Photovoltaic cells; Remote control; Sensors; Solar energy; Wind power; Alternative energy; Automatic control systems; Photovoltaic installation; Process visualization system; Wind electrolyser system; Wind power plants; Windmills; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Kollé J.J.
Title: Compressed-water pulse generators for sheet metal joining
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Tempress Technologies Inc., Kent, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kollé, J.J., Tempress Technologies Inc., Kent, WA, United States
Abstract: A compressed-water pulse generator consists of a heavy-walled pressure vessel equipped with a fast-opening discharge valve. At ultra-high-pressure - UHP>100 MPa - water has significant compressibility, allowing storage and discharge of energetic pulses from a compact tool. Pulse generators with discharge energies of up to 250 kJ and a nozzle diameter of 25-mm have been built and tested. The UHP pulses may be further accelerated through a tapered nozzle to generate hyper-pressure pulses with stagnation pressures of over 1 GPa. Heavy pulse generators have applications in civil engineering including rock blasting, concrete demolition and soil foundation improvement. Smaller systems can be used for manufacturing applications including hydro-forming, metal punching, joining and surface treatment.
Index Keywords: Compressibility of liquids; Jets; Joining; Nozzles; Sheet metal; Surface treatment; Compressed-water pulse generator; Sheet metal joining; Pressure vessels

Authors: Rodgers M.Steven, Allen Jim J., Meeks Kent D., Jensen Brian D., Miller Sam L.
Title: Microelectromechanical high-density energy storage/rapid release system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodgers, M.Steven, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Allen, Jim J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Meeks, Kent D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Jensen, Brian D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Miller, Sam L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: One highly desirable characteristic of electrostatically driven microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) is that they consume very little power. The corresponding drawback is that the force they produce may be inadequate for many applications. It has previously been demonstrated that gear reduction units or microtransmissions can substantially increase the torque generated by microengines. Operating speed, however, is also reduced by the transmission gear ratio. Some applications require both high speed and high force. If this output is only required for a limited period of time, then energy could be stored in a mechanical system and rapidly released upon demand. We have designed, fabricated, and demonstrated a high-density energy storage/rapid release system that accomplishes this task. Built using a 5-level surface micromachining technology, the assembly closely resembles a medieval crossbow. Energy releases on the order of tens of nanojoules have already been demonstrated, and significantly higher energy systems are under development.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Electrostatic devices; Mathematical models; Microactuators; Scanning electron microscopy; Silicon; Surface tension; Microelectromechanical high density energy storage; Microengine; Microtransmission; Rapid release system; Microelectromechanical devices

Authors: Stewart L., Koelsch D.C., McKinnon M.A., Machiels A.J.

Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP

Northwest National Laboratory, Battelle Boulevard, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Machiels, A.J., Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, CA 94303-0813, United States
Abstract: Research studies by the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) established the technical and operational requirements necessary to enable the on-site cask-to-cask dry transfer of spent nuclear fuel. Following further evaluations by the Department of Energy (DOE) and National Academy of Sciences, the United States Congress appropriated funds in fiscal years 1992 and 1993 to develop the spent nuclear fuel dry transfer system (DTS) and a transportable storage system. The DOE issued a $1.5 million Cooperative Agreement to EPRI in September 1993 for the cost-shared design of the DTS. The transportable storage system is being developed under a separate Cooperative Agreement with the Sacramento Municipal Utility District.
Index Keywords: Containers; Radioactive waste storage; Spent fuels; Dry transfer systems (DTS); Radioactive waste transportation

Authors: Henze Gregor P., Krarti Moncef
Title: Impact of forecasting uncertainty on the performance of a predictive optimal controller for thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Univ of Nebraska at Omaha, Omaha, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henze, Gregor P., Univ of Nebraska at Omaha, Omaha, United States; Krarti, Moncef, Univ of Nebraska at Omaha, Omaha, United States
Abstract: In this paper an investigation is presented to determine the effect of forecasting uncertainty on the cost savings performance of a predictive optimal controller for thermal energy storage (TES) systems. Specifically, this investigation analyzed four uncertainty models to predict future values for cooling loads, weather variables, and electrical rates. The uncertainty models considered are unbiased Gaussian noise, correlated Gaussian noise, unbiased uniform noise, and biased uniform noise. The results of the analysis summarized in this paper show that the predictive optimal controller is robust and does not require high levels of accuracy in predicting the cooling loads and the real-time pricing (RTP) rates.
Index Keywords: Computer aided analysis; Computer simulation; Control system analysis; Cooling; Optimal control systems; Predictive control systems; Spurious signal noise; Thermal load; Forecasting uncertainty models; Real-time pricing (RTP) rates; Thermal energy storage (TES) systems; Heat storage

Authors: Bochkov V.D., Dyagilev V.M., Nicolin S.V., Ushich V.G., Seeteekh D.S., Vlasov P.N.
Title: Pseudospark switch crowbar unit - high reliability, low cost system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Bochkov, V.D., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Dyagilev, V.M., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Nicolin, S.V., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Ushich, V.G., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Seeteekh, D.S., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Vlasov, P.N., Research Inst of Gas-Discharge, Devices, Ryazan, Russian Federation
Abstract: TD-50 k/45, two-gap sealed-off ceramic pseudospark switch operating with pulsed current up to 50 kA and with operating voltage up to 50 kV was used as crowbar switch for high power TV Inductive Output Tube - IOT 7340R produced by EEV (U.K.). The basic parameters of crowbar system: peak voltage 26÷32 kV, storage capacitance 12 μF, series resistor - 15 Ω, peak discharge current - 2 kA, follow-on current - 80-90 A, total charge - 6-7 Coulomb, reservoir heater range 6.0 V±1.0 V (1÷1.5 A), trigger energy 0.3 J, delay time of TD-50 k/45-110 ns, delay time of crowbar unit - less 2.5-3 μs. Pseudospark crowbar system passed type tests accepted in EEV. This system has been working satisfactorily since August 1998 24 hours a day in the 25 kW television transmitter `Onega-25' (St.-Petersburg). Cold cathode thyratrons or pseudospark switches combining the advantages of spark gaps and thyratrons are devoid of their basic imperfections. It allows to expect expansion of spheres of their application.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Ceramic products; Cold cathode tubes; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric potential; Resistors; Thyratrons; Cold cathode thyratrons; Pseudospark switches; Electric switches

Authors: Rouillard Jean, St-Pierre Christian, Geoffroy Denis, Carignan Claude, Choquette Yves
Title: Testing and lithium polymer batteries in outside power cabinet for telecommunication system
Affiliations: ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rouillard, Jean, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; St-Pierre, Christian, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Geoffroy, Denis, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Carignan, Claude, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Choquette, Yves, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada
Abstract: This paper is the third of a series describing the development of the Lithium Polymer Battery/(LPB), a new battery technology for use as an energy storage system in telecommunication applications. The first two papers [3,4] gave a description of this technology, its scientific background and its development toward a fully operational battery system. Laboratory testing, showing the very promising results at the cell and module levels, were also reported. The first field tests of LPB systems are underway. This paper briefly reviews the LPB technology focusing on its control, monitoring and communication systems that are very important for the execution of the tests. Test sites are briefly described and the preliminary results are presented and analyzed. An Alpha LPB battery module was used in these tests. It is a development module used to validate the LPB technology and the module design. An engineering (Beta) module will be developed based on the experience gained during the field tests.
Index Keywords: Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy storage; Equipment testing; Monitoring; Telecommunication systems; Digital loop carrier; Fiber in the loop; Hybrid fiber coax; Lithium polymer batteries; Lithium batteries

Authors: Albonesi David H.
Title: Selective cache ways: On-demand cache resource allocation
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual International Symposium on Microarchitecture
Affiliations: Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Albonesi, David H., Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Abstract: Increasing levels of microprocessor power dissipation call for new approaches at the architectural level that save energy by better matching of on-chip resources to application requirements. Selective cache ways provides the ability to disable a subset of the ways in a set associative cache during periods of modest cache activity, while the full cache may remain operational for more cache-intensive periods. Because this approach leverages the subarray partitioning that is already present for performance reasons, only minor changes to a conventional cache are required, and therefore, full-speed cache operation can be maintained. Furthermore, the tradeoff between performance and energy is flexible, and can be dynamically tailored to meet changing application and machine environmental conditions. We show that trading off a small performance degradation for energy savings can produce a significant reduction in cache energy dissipation using this approach.
Index Keywords: Microprocessor chips; Storage allocation (computer); On-demand cache resource allocation; Buffer storage

Authors: Andersson Ake, Johnson Matthew S., Nelander Bengt
Title: Observation of coherent synchrotron radiation from a 1 mm electron bunch at the MAX-I storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Lund, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Ake, Univ of Lund, Lund, Sweden; Johnson, Matthew S., Univ of Lund, Lund, Sweden; Nelander, Bengt, Univ of Lund, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The coherent generation of synchrotron radiation by an electron storage ring is predicted for wavelengths equal to or longer than the electron bunch length. With typical bunch lengths of approximately 1 cm, diffraction and chamber-screening effects have so-far blocked observation of coherent radiation from a conventional radiation beam line. In the low-energy, second-generation light source MAX-I, the magnet lattice has been tuned to a small momentum compaction factor, allowing rms bunch lengths as short as 1 mm. Here we report the coherent emission phenomena observed from such a bunch at the infrared beam line attached to the MAX-I ring.
Index Keywords: Coherent light; Diffraction; Infrared radiation; Light emission; Light sources; Magnets; Storage rings; Chamber screening effects; Coherent radiation; Electron bunch; Infrared beam line; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Kim J., Zhang J., Giesselmann M., Dickens J., Mankowski J., Kristiansen M.
Title: Energy efficiency analysis of an inductive storage system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Zhang, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Giesselmann, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Dickens, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Mankowski, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Kristiansen, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Abstract: The energy efficiency and voltage amplification in an inductive energy storage system was evaluated by numerical simulation with Mathcad. The voltage amplification and energy efficiency of the inductive storage system increased with the reduction in fuse-interruption time. When the storage energy inductance was reduced, voltage amplification underwent small changes but the changes in energy efficiency was greater. In diode and resistive load cases, energy efficiency increased due to the current increases relative to the decrease in inductance. In the capacitive load case, the load charging voltage and the energy efficiency decreased due to the smaller fuse resistance relative to the smaller storage energy inductance.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Energy efficiency; Mathematical models; Inductive energy storage systems; Electric energy storage

Authors: Pokryvailo A.
Title: To the theory of parallel railgun driven by an inductive storage power supply
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pokryvailo, A., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: Albeit far from maturity, inductive storage is a promising technology for electromagnetic launchers. A system comprising a railgun coupled to an inductive storage power supply is analyzed again. An analytical nondimensional treatment of the lossless case is given, readily allowing the assessment of the performance limits of such a system. A lossy system has been analyzed numerically. A conclusion is drawn that, at the discharge process, the coil losses are of minor importance compared to the rail losses.
Index Keywords: Electric coils; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric losses; Electric power systems; Inductive storage power supply; Parallel railguns; Power inductors

Authors: Mahapatra K.K., Ghosh Arindam, Doradla S.R.
Title: Simplified model for control design of STATCOM using three-level inverter
Source title: IEEE Region 10 Annual International Conference, Proceedings/TENCON
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Mahapatra, K.K., Indian Inst of Technology, Kanpur, India; Ghosh, Arindam, Indian Inst of Technology, Kanpur, India; Doradla, S.R., Indian Inst of Technology, Kanpur, India
Abstract: A simplified closed-loop model is proposed for a static compensator (STATCOM). Although PI and PD controllers for the proposed model have been investigated, the later controller is found to offer better performance. This model makes it possible to extract instantaneous active fundamental component of the load current. The STATCOM is configured using a three-level voltage source inverter. For high power applications the multilevel inverter is preferred over the commonly used two level voltage source inverter from the standpoint of harmonic components, dc link voltage and inverter switching frequency. The STATCOM is capable of providing reactive power compensation for fundamental and harmonics; power factor correction under balanced and unbalanced loading conditions. The performance of the STATCOM together with the proposed model is validated by extensive simulation results.
Index Keywords: Closed loop control systems; Computer simulation; Control system synthesis; Electric control equipment; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric load management; Electric power factor correction; Mathematical models; Reactive power; Three term control systems; Two term control systems; Closed loop model; Control design; Load current; Static compensator; Three level inverter; Static converters

Authors: Wong A.Y.K., Cheng D.K.W., Lee Y.S.
Title: Harmonic compensation for nonlinear loads by active power filter
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Wong, A.Y.K., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Cheng, D.K.W., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Lee, Y.S., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper is to study a single phase shunt active power filter (APF) using a bi-directional full-bridge converter with capacitive energy storage to compensate for the harmonics generated by nonlinear loads. The usage of a capacitor as a reactive power source for the APF simplifies the circuitry. The harmonic current reference is obtained by feeding the load current signal into a 50Hz notch filter. The simple and fast hysteresis control strategy involving only a few number of analog and logic components makes it attractive for the low power domestic application. The usefulness of the proposed control algorithm is confirmed by simulation as well as by experimental results.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Capacitors; Circuit theory; Digital control systems; Electric converters; Electric loads; Harmonic generation; Hysteresis; Notch filters; Reactive power; Active power filter; Full bridge converter; Nonlinear loads; Active filters

Authors: Shimomura Naoyuki, Nagata Masayoshi, Akiyama Hidenori
Title: Compact pulsed power generator using a Marx circuit and a exploding wire
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Univ of Tokushima, Tokushima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimomura, Naoyuki, Univ of Tokushima, Tokushima, Japan; Nagata, Masayoshi, Univ of Tokushima, Tokushima, Japan; Akiyama, Hidenori, Univ of Tokushima, Tokushima, Japan
Abstract: A compact pulsed power generator with an inductive energy storage system is investigated. The energy transfer ratio into the load is considered by generic calculations, which confirmed the need of a high fuse opening resistance. Long and thin wires are suitable to generate the high voltage as a fuse opening switch. The generator circuit parameters are optimized by numerical analysis, taking into account the stored energy in the inductor at the beginning of wire vaporization and energy consumed during wire vaporization. The generator is designed for high voltage applications. Although the output current is low because of the low initial charging energy, the voltage multiplication factor is, accordingly, high. The inductive pulsed power generator consists of a Marx circuit, an inductor, and a thin and long exploding copper wire. An output voltage up to 800 kV and voltage risetimes of 15 to 40 ns are experimentally obtained.
Index Keywords: Electric switches; Equivalent circuits; Numerical analysis; Plasma sources; Abstract only; Exploding wires; Marx circuits; Pulsed power generators; Plasma devices

Authors: Loree Diana L., O'Loughlin James P.
Title: Regulated capacitor charging circuit using a high reactance transformer
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Air Force Research Lab, Kirtland Air Force Base, United States
Authors with affiliations: Loree, Diana L., Air Force Research Lab, Kirtland Air Force Base, United States; O'Loughlin, James P., Air Force Research Lab, Kirtland Air Force Base, United States
Abstract: A high reactance transformer circuit is used to provide for the compact, simple, economic and reliable charging of a capacitor energy store to a predetermined and regulated voltage. The circuit can be operated from a single phase, three phase, or poly phase prime power source or service. The circuit employs a high-reactance transformer in combination with a phase-programmed switch. The transformer impedance limits the surge current loading on the prime power source. The phase-programmed switch is used to achieve the voltage regulation. The transformer secondary is rectified and is wound to provide the desired charge voltage on the capacitor store. The controller commands the primary switch that begins the charging cycle by closing at a predetermined phase relation to the prime power a.c. (alternating current) source. The predetermined phase is necessary to control the in-rush current to the primary of the transformer. The primary switch may be a fast solid state type such as an SCR (Silicon Controlled Rectifier). The same primary switch opens, or recovers in the open state at a current zero crossing, to remove the primary voltage when the capacitor store reaches full charge, and thus provides regulation of the charging voltage. The repetition rate of the charging circuit is limited to approximately 25% of the prime power a.c. source frequency for three phase applications and approximately 8% of the a.c. source frequency for single phase applications. The accuracy of the regulation also depends on the maximum repetition rate in relation to the source frequency.
Index Keywords: Electric network synthesis; Electric transformers; Switching circuits; Voltage control; Silicon controlled rectifier (SCR); Capacitor storage

Authors: Ennis J.B., MacDougall F.W., Cooper R.A., Bates J.
Title: Self-healing pulse capacitors for the National Ignition Facility (NIF)
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Maxwell Energy Products, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ennis, J.B., Maxwell Energy Products, Inc, San Diego, United States; MacDougall, F.W., Maxwell Energy Products, Inc, San Diego, United States; Cooper, R.A., Maxwell Energy Products, Inc, San Diego, United States; Bates, J., Maxwell Energy Products, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Approximately 4,000 capacitors, each storing 83.5 kJ of energy, will be required for the United States Department of Energy National Ignition Facility (NIF), being built at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL). To achieve the required system reliability, lifetime, and cost goals, the capacitors were specified to be of the self-healing, metallized electrode type of construction. Maxwell Energy Products has previously delivered a number of banks of self-healing capacitors, including the 52 MJ bank at the U.S. Army ARDEC facility at Picatinny Arsenal, NJ. Development of capacitors specifically for NIF began several years ago and continues today at Maxwell, with the primary goal of reducing the manufacturing cost. In support of this effort, LLNL has procured prototypes and life tested a number of our designs over the past three years. This paper will review the development of NIF capacitors at Maxwell, focussing on the lifetime performance of different designs during the development. This work has resulted in Maxwell Type CM capacitor designs whose demonstrated lifetime capability has far exceeded the 20,000 shot NIF requirement, having energy densities as high as 0.84 J/cc.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electrodes; Metallizing; Self-healing pulse capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Bertazzoni S., Cardarilli G.C., Piergentili D., Salmeri M., Salsano A., Giovenale D.Di, Grande G.C., Marinucci P., Sperandei S., Bartalucci S., Mazzenga G., Ricci M., Bidoli V., De Francesco D., Picozza P.G.
Title: Failure tests on 64 Mb SDRAM in radiation environment
Source title: IEEE International Workshop on Defect and Fault Tolerance in VLSI Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bertazzoni, S., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Cardarilli, G.C., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Piergentili, D., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Salmeri, M., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Salsano, A., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Giovenale, D.Di, Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Grande, G.C., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Marinucci, P., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Sperandei, S., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Bartalucci, S., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Mazzenga, G., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Ricci, M., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Bidoli, V., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; De Francesco, D., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy; Picozza, P.G., Univ of Rome `Tor Vergata', Rome, Italy
Abstract: In this paper we analyze the failures of Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) 64 Mb Synchronous DRAM in radiation environment. The experimental setup, the test procedure, and the results of three different test runs at the Catania LNS-INFN cyclotron are described in some details. Three kinds of heavy ions were used to test devices under different conditions of energy release that generates different amount of charge inside the chip. In particular, 30 MeV/AMU 93Nb (LETSi to approximately 21 MeV/(mg/cm2), RSi to approximately 397 μm), 30 MeV/AMU 120Sn (LETSi to approximately 30 MeV/(mg/cm2), RSi to approximately 370 μm) and 15 MeV/AMU 197Au (LETSi to approximately 90 MeV/(mg/cm2), RSi to approximately 95 μm) were used. In all cases, the bare dies were directly bonded on an AF4 carrier to avoid plastic and lead-frame shielding. Different failure types that could affect the operations of a system based on this device were registered. To verify that the characteristics of the events depend on the zone striken by the particle a specific test was performed.
Index Keywords: Cyclotron radiation; Electric shielding; Failure analysis; Integrated circuit testing; Microprocessor chips; Synchronous dynamic random access memory (SDRAM); Dynamic random access storage

Authors: van der Merwe J.B., Mouton H.du T.
Title: Solid state opening switch requirements for standard inductive storage pulse forming networks
Affiliations: Univ of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: van der Merwe, J.B., Univ of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa; Mouton, H.du T., Univ of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, South Africa
Abstract: The commutation of energy from an inductive energy storage Pulse Forming Network (PFN) to a load requires high power opening switches. The problems associated with this are numerous as requirements reach far into the tens of kA and kV. This paper examines relationship between standard storage topologies and their opening switches, and draws attention to the possible problems one could encounter.

Authors: Zimin Sergey P.
Title: Properties and stability of parameters of highly compensated PbS-CdS, PbS-SnS, PbS-PbO and PbTe-CdTe films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Yaroslavl State Univ, Yaroslavl, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zimin, Sergey P., Yaroslavl State Univ, Yaroslavl, Russian Federation
Abstract: The properties of highly compensated quasiuniform films of Pb1-xSnxS (x=0.05), Pb1-xCdxS (x=0.05-0.30), (PbS)1-x-(PbO)x (x=0.005, x=0.02), Pb1-xCdxTe (x=0.05, x=0.20) solid solutions with a sodium acceptor impurity are described in this work. The films were grown by the method of molecular beam epitaxy on BaF2 (111) substrates. It was shown that the films with different composition have the identical electric and photoelectric properties. Temperature dependences of Hall coefficient, dark resistivity and photoconductivity relaxation time have activation character. A high stability of electric and photoelectric parameters (carrier density, carrier mobility, photoconductivity relaxation time) after thermal impact and after prolonged storage in the air was obtained.

Title: Lessons learned from drop testing
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rahl, T.E., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Morton, D.K., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Ware, A.G., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Snow, S.D., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) has developed a set of standard canisters for the handling, interim storage, transportation, and disposal in the national repository of DOE spent nuclear fuel (SNF). The canister was developed to withstand a drop from 30 feet onto a rigid (flat) surface, sustaining only minor damage - but no rapture - to the pressure (containment) boundary. The design concept was validated through a drop testing program and finite element analyses. The drop-testing program consisted of seven drop tests of smaller test specimens and five drop tests of full-scale representative canisters. This paper addresses fabrication of the test specimens, instrumentation, data acquisition, data processing, and details of the actual drops. The author discusses the problems encountered during the test program, the solutions applied, and some lessons learned. For seasoned drop test engineers, many of the things presented in this paper may seem trivial or obvious. This paper is mainly for those embarking on their first drop test program. It is hoped the information presented herein will make their first drop test go smoother. It is the simple overlooked things that tend to cause problems on test day, rather than the obvious complicated problems that have been well thought out prior to test day.
Index Keywords: Computer aided analysis; Finite element method; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Structural analysis; Drop testing; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Horry M.L., Donovan G.L., Potter J.E., Bloomquist D.D., Harris M.L., Grelle N.L., Lockas M., Steedly J., Alessandri D.
Title: `Z' facility dielectric oil clean-up
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Horry, M.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Donovan, G.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Potter, J.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Bloomquist, D.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Harris, M.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Grelle, N.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Lockas, M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Steedly, J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Alessandri, D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: In August of 1998 the Z facility leaked approximately 150 gallons of deionized water into the dielectric oil of the Energy Storage Section (ESS). After processing the oil to remove existing particulate and free water the dielectric breakdown strength increased from the mid 20 kV range to values in excess of 40 kV. 40 kV is above historical operating levels of about 35 kV. This, however, was not enough to allow 90 kV charging of the Marx Generators in the ESS. Further analysis of the oil showed dissolved water at a saturated level (70 - 80 ppm) and some residual particulate contamination smaller than 3 microns. The dissolved water and particulate combination was preventing the 90 kV charging of the Marx Generators in the ESS. After consulting with the oil industry, it was determined that nitrogen sparging could be used to remove the dissolved water. Further particulate filtering was also conducted. After approximately 20 hours of sparging the water content in the ESS was reduced to 42 ppm which enabled Marx charging to 90 kV.
Index Keywords: Crude petroleum; Dielectric materials; Electric breakdown of liquids; Leakage (fluid); Particles (particulate matter); Water filtration; Energy storage section (ESS); Marx generators; Electric energy storage

Authors: Teramoto Yusuke, Kohno Susumu, Lisitsyn Igor V., Katsuki Sunao, Akiyama Hidenori
Title: Characterization of cable plasma guns for microsecond plasma opening switch
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Teramoto, Yusuke, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Kohno, Susumu, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Lisitsyn, Igor V., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katsuki, Sunao, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Akiyama, Hidenori, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: Cable plasma guns are frequently used as a plasma source in plasma opening switches. Our plasma guns are designed for use in a 400 kA inductive voltage adder with an inductive energy storage system. The plasma source consists of eight cable guns mounted on an outer coaxial electrode. The characteristics of the plasma generated by the cable plasma guns have been investigated using a laser interferometer. The contour maps of the plasma density of the whole area between the electrodes are plotted as a function of time.
Index Keywords: Adders; Electrodes; Interferometers; Laser applications; Plasma density; Plasma guns; Plasma sources; Cable plasma guns; Inductive voltage adders (IVA); Laser interferometers; Plasma opening switches (POS); Electric switches

Title: Beam instrumentation for the Spallation Neutron Source ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Witkover, R.L., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Cameron, P.R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Shea, T.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Connolly, R.C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Kesselman, M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) will be constructed by a multi-laboratory collaboration with BNL responsible for the transfer lines and ring. The 1 MW beam power necessitates careful monitoring to minimize un-controlled loss. This high beam power will influence the design of the monitors in the high energy beam transport line (HEBT) from linac to ring, in the ring, and in the ring-to-target transfer line (RTBT). The ring instrumentation must cover a 3-decade range of beam intensity during accumulation. Beam loss monitoring will be especially critical since un-controlled beam loss must be kept below 10-4. A Beam-In-Gap (BIG) monitor is being designed to assure out-of-bucket beam will not be lost in the ring.
Index Keywords: Linear accelerators; Particle beam dynamics; Storage rings; Beam-in-gap (BIG) monitors; High energy beam transport (HEBT); Ring-to-target transfer lines; Spallation neutron sources (SNS); Neutron sources

Authors: Hu K.H., Chen Jenny, Hsu K.T., Ueng T.S., Hsu S.Y.
Title: Closed orbit measurement system for the booster synchrotron in SRRC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hu, K.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chen, Jenny, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Ueng, T.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, S.Y., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: The booster of SRRC is a 1.3 GeV synchrotron with 10 Hz repetition rate. Electron beam from 50 MeV accelerates to 1.3 GeV within 50 msec. It serves as the injector for 1.3 to approximately 1.5 GeV storage ring of Taiwan Light Source (TLS). To reduce heat related problem in the machine and beamline optics, 1.5 GeV full energy injection is scheduled in near future. The closed orbit measurement system of booster synchrotron consists of 23 set of BPMs, multiplexes, 500 MHz receivers, timing control electronic and VME bus transient digitizer. The closed orbit is sampled every 150 μsec, 600 orbits acquired while the energy ramping. The closed-orbit is observed as function of energy. The orbit change due to imperfection of lattice and slow pulse magnet is easily observed. This system is expected to provide us abundant information to improve the operation efficiency, trouble shoot of booster.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Light sources; Particle beam injection; Particle beam tracking; Particle optics; Storage rings; Beam position monitors (BPM); Booster synchrotrons; Synchrotrons

Authors: Harkay K.C., Borland M., Chae Y.-C., Emery L., Huang Z., Lessner E.S., Lumpkin A.H., Milton S.V., Sereno N.S., Yang B.X.
Title: Impedance and the single bunch limit in the APS storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harkay, K.C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Borland, M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Chae, Y.-C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Emery, L., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Huang, Z., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Lessner, E.S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Lumpkin, A.H., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Milton, S.V., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Sereno, N.S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Yang, B.X., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The single-bunch current limit and tune shift with current have been documented over time in the 7-GeV Advanced Photon Source (APS) storage ring as a function of lattice, chromaticity, and number of small-gap insertion device (ID) chambers. The contribution to the machine coupling impedance of the 8-mm-gap ID chambers was reported earlier. One 5-mm-gap ID chamber was installed in December 1997. This required changing the lattice to preserve the vertical acceptance. The new lattice reduced the average vertical beta function at the 5-mm chamber as well as at all the other ID chambers and so has also lowered the effect of the vertical coupling impedance. As additional 8-mm and 5-mm chambers are planned, a more detailed characterization of the impedance is essential. This includes separating the effects of the transitions between the small-gap chambers and the standard chambers from the resistive wall impedance of the small-gap chambers themselves. In this paper, we report on the transverse instabilities and thresholds observed in the vertical and horizontal planes. From these observations, various contributions to the coupling impedance are derived.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric impedance; Elementary particle sources; Energy gap; Photons; Advanced photon sources (APS); Chromaticity; Storage rings

Authors: Harkay K.C., Rosenberg R.A.
Title: Measurements of the electron cloud in the APS storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harkay, K.C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Rosenberg, R.A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation interacting with the vacuum chamber walls in a storage ring produce photoelectrons that can be accelerated by the beam, acquiring sufficient energy to produce secondary electrons in collisions with the walls. If the secondary-electron yield (SEY) coefficient of the wall material is greater than one, as is the case with the aluminum chambers in the 7-GeV Advanced Photon Source (APS) storage ring, a runaway condition can develop. As the electron cloud builds up along a train of stored positron or electron bunches, the possibility exists that a transverse perturbation of the head bunch will be communicated to trailing bunches due to interaction with the cloud. In order to characterize the electron cloud, a special vacuum chamber was built and inserted into the ring. The chamber contains 10 rudimentary electron-energy analyzers, as well as three targets coated with different materials. Measurements show that the intensity and electron energy distribution are highly dependent on the temporal spacing between adjacent bunches and the amount of current contained in each bunch. Furthermore, measurements using the different targets are consistent with what would be expected based on the SEY of the coatings. Data for both positron and electron beams are presented.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Electron energy analyzers; Elementary particle sources; Particle beam dynamics; Perturbation techniques; Photons; Positrons; Targets; Advanced photon sources (APS); Electron cloud instability (ECI); Photoelectrons; Secondary electron yield (SEY); Storage rings

Authors: Boenig H.J., Mielke C.H., Robinson R.A., Schillig J.B., Painter T., Eyssa Y.M.
Title: Design of a 16 kV, 100 kA, 2 Hz power supply for high-field, repetitively pulsed, split-pair magnets
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boenig, H.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Mielke, C.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Robinson, R.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Schillig, J.B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Painter, T., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Eyssa, Y.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Los Alamos National Laboratory is installing in its Neutron Scattering Center a high-field, split-pair, pulsed magnet system as a user facility for neutron scattering experiments. The first magnet, to be designed and built by the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, will be repetitively pulsed at a frequency of 2 Hz and is designed for a field strength of 23 T for 10e7 cycles and up to 30 T for 10e4 cycles. The 1.6 GVA pulsed power supply, which energizes the magnet, consists of a double ringing circuit with a capacitive energy storage unit. The parameters and the unique features of the major components of the supply, such as the capacitor bank including the charging unit, the solid-state closing switch, the free-wheeling diode, the auxiliary inductor and the cabling arrangement will be explained. In particular the design of the 16 kV, 100 kA, 2 Hz, solid-state closing switch, which is based on thyristor technology, will be presented. The overall electrical system is designed for 5×10e8 pulses. The fatigue life of each component must be evaluated. Fatigue life data for the major components, as presented in the literature and obtained from the component manufacturers, will be summarized and the fatigue life effect on the component design will be shown.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric switches; Magnets; Neutron scattering; Pulsed power supply; Split-pair magnets; Electric power systems

Abstract: By analyzing the anomalous junction leakage of a single tail bit and introducing the trap level fluctuation model, we have successfully established a methodology for predicting the refresh time (Tref) of the current and next generations for the Tref-oriented DRAM design optimization.

Title: Critical systems for high peak power storage ring FEL
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Abstract: The Duke storage ring is a facility dedicated for the deep UV free electron laser (FEL) development. It is especially designed for the high peak power applications, having a long optical cavity and large energy acceptance. In this paper we describe FEL gain modulator and optical cavity control system, which are essential for obtaining maximal peak power.

Authors: Mokhov N.V., Van Ginneken A.
Title: Neutrino induced radiation at muon colliders
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mokhov, N.V., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Van Ginneken, A., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: Intense highly collimated neutrino beams are created from muon decays at high-energy muon colliders causing significant radiation problems even at very large distances from the collider ring. A newly developed weighted neutrino interaction generator permits detailed Monte Carlo simulations of the interactions of neutrinos (and of their progeny) to be performed using the MARS code. Dose distributions in a human tissue-equivalent phantom (TEP) are calculated when irradiated with neutrino beams (100 MeV-10 TeV). Results are obtained for a bare TEP, one embedded in several shielding materials and for a TEP located at various distances behind a shield. The distance from the collider ring (up to 60 km) at which recommended annual dose limits can be met is calculated for 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 4 TeV muon colliders. The possibility to mitigate the problem via beam wobbling is investigated.
Index Keywords: Charged particles; Computer simulation; Monte Carlo methods; Storage rings; Muon colliders; Neutrino beams; Software package MARS; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Assmann R.W.
Title: Regimes of polarization in a high energy e+e- storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Assmann, R.W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Several regimes of polarization must be considered for high-energy e+e- storage rings. Based on a theoretical paper by Derbenev, Kontratenko and Skrinsky from 1979 we describe the different cases. Particularly, it is shown that from a certain high energy onwards the polarization degree is expected to increase with energy. This is in sharp contrast to the usually considered regime where the expected polarization level decreases for higher beam energies. The theory of Derbenev, Kontratenko and Skrinsky is applied to the LEP storage ring with its energy range from the Z at 91 GeV to the W at 200 GeV. Though the theoretical expectations for beam polarization at the highest beam energy remain low, it is shown that the depolarization can move into a new regime for LEP above 60 GeV. The high energy LEP is the first storage ring that operates in this new and experimentally unknown regime of beam spin dynamics.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Polarization; Positrons; Electron-positron storage rings; Radiative spin polarization; Storage rings

Title: Muon colliders: Status of R&D and future plans
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Abstract: The case for a future high-energy collider based on muon beams is presented. Issues to be considered for further research and development of muon colliders are discussed.
