Authors: Haddad Wassim M., Chellaboina VijaySekhar, Kablar Natasa A.
Title: Nonlinear impulsive dynamical systems. Part I: stability and dissipativity
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Decision and Control
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haddad, Wassim M., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States; Chellaboina, VijaySekhar, Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States; Kablar, Natasa A., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, United States
Abstract: In this paper we develop Lyapunov and invariant set stability theorems for nonlinear impulsive dynamical systems. Furthermore, we generalize dissipativity theory to nonlinear dynamical systems with impulsive effects. Specifically, the classical concepts of system storage functions and supply rates are extended to impulsive dynamical systems providing a generalized hybrid system energy interpretation in terms of stored energy, dissipated energy over the continuous-time system dynamics, and dissipated energy over the resetting instances. Furthermore, extended Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov conditions in terms of the impulsive system dynamics characterizing dissipativeness in terms of system storage functions are derived. Finally, the framework is specialized to passive and nonexpansive impulsive systems to provide a generalization of the classical notions of passivity and nonexpansivity.
Index Keywords: Control nonlinearities; Control system analysis; Control system synthesis; Feedback control; Invariance; Lyapunov methods; Set theory; System stability; Dissipativity theory; Impulsive dynamical systems; System storage functions; Nonlinear control systems

Authors: Reuter Hartmut
Title: Hiding HSM systems from the user
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reuter, Hartmut, Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Germany
Abstract: File life-times longer than the life-time of HSM-systems make it necessary to move files from one HSM-system to another. Such a migration takes a long time and cannot be hidden from the user unless an additional layer of software is put in between. RZG is using MR-AFS as such a layer. The features of MR-AFS are presented once again. RZG's experiences with HSM-migrations and the usage patterns of MR-AFS are discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer software; High energy physics; Hierarchical storage management (HSM) system; Data storage equipment

Authors: Jones J., Sharma S., Bromberek D., Howell J.
Title: APS SR flexible bellows shield performance
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Sharma, S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Bromberek, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Howell, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) storage ring (SR) consists of long rigid vacuum chambers connected by flexible formed bellows components. These SR bellows and additional diagnostic chambers are designed with leaf spring beryllium-copper (Be-Cu) alloy contact fingers that insert into mating rigid sleeves to function as electromagnetic shields. The shields protect the bellows convolutions from particle beam image currents and rf energy and reduce beam-induced rf resonances in the diagnostics chambers. The beam aperture of the shields is approximately the same as that of the beam chambers so that the beam impedance of the SR is minimized. The bellows shields systems' thermal performance has been tested and is monitored during APS SR beam operations. Testing included infrared radiometer camera imaging and thermocouple instrumentation of the rigid sleeve. Direct results indicate that the liners perform well under all stored beam fill loadings through and including 100-mA, 8-bunch operations. Maximum temperatures of the bellows liner systems are typically 35-50° Celsius during standard 100 mAmp stored beam fills and 50-70° Celsius during fills, producing both maximum peak and total current simultaneously. The indirect observations of ring vacuum levels support the temperature data.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic shielding; Light sources; Photons; Resonance; Flexible bellows shield; Vacuum chambers; Storage rings

Authors: Belomestnykh S.
Title: High luminosity performance of CESR with the new generation superconducting cavity
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Belomestnykh, S., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: With the installation of the first superconducting RF (SRF) cavity in 1997, the upgrade of the CESR RF system has begun. This cavity belongs to the new generation of so-called HOM damped cavities designed for high current storage rings. The upgrade is proceeding by replacing one by one old copper cavities with superconducting ones during short machine shutdowns. The superconducting cavity operates at accelerating gradients up to 7 MV/m and delivers to the beam maximum RF power of 220 kW through the ceramic window, the record value for superconducting cavities.
Index Keywords: High energy physics; Superconducting devices; Superconducting cavity; Storage rings

Authors: Wrulich Albin F.
Title: Future directions in the storage ring development for light sources
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: PSI, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wrulich, Albin F., PSI, Switzerland
Abstract: Major performance objectives for storage-ring based light sources are small emittance and energy spread, high beam stability, and full exploitation of the photon energy from a few eV up to hard X-rays. Most of the recent- generation light sources are built up by highly optimized lattices of the Double Bend- or Triple Bend Achromat type. There is little room left to further optimize these lattices to even smaller emittances. Only a local adjustment of the optics at the source points might still bring some benefit. With decreasing emittance orbit stability is becoming more and more important. Cures for vibrations, thermal effects and ground motion have to start at the basic design of the building, the storage ring infrastructure and the magnet support system. Beam instabilities are especially harmful as they increase the energy spread and as a consequence deteriorate the higher harmonics of the undulator radiation. Well optimized beams suffer from lifetime problems due to Touschek scattering. Particular problems arise when short bunches are requested, for instance for storage ring based lasers. Medium-energy machines are able to produce high brilliance in the hard X-ray range by means of mini-undulators with small gaps. This, again, has an adverse effect on the beam lifetime due to beam gas scattering. The current trend in storage ring development for future Light Sources is discussed. What are the crucial issues and where is improvement desirable and possible? Is there still room for improving the basic design of a light source? Are there alternatives to the `classical' lattices which could be used for the next generation? Or is improvement possible only on the operational field?
Index Keywords: Light scattering; Light sources; X rays; Mini-undulators; Touschek scattering; Storage rings

Authors: Darrelmann Hilmar
Title: Comparison of high power short time flywheel storage systems
Affiliations: Piller GmbH, Osterode, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Darrelmann, Hilmar, Piller GmbH, Osterode, Germany
Abstract: Current Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) systems are supported mainly by batteries to cover short network breakdowns. The advantages of batteries in this application are their high degree of modularisation, low charging regime losses and not least their wide spread availability. Disadvantages are their weight, high maintenance costs and their high price if storage times of less than one minute are desired and are sufficient like in the area of power quality improvement. As an alternative to lead acid batteries different storage methods have been investigated recently. Storage systems like new type batteries, superconductive coils (SMES), pressure reservoir storage and supercapacitors have been taken into consideration. But most of these new techniques are still in the early test phase, run with high losses, require high investment costs or space or are not proven enough. The flywheel technology is the most suitable solution for a high reliable storage in the Megawatt/Second range. The paper describes the current state of the art technology, explains the action principles and compares in particular the two different systems 'High speed flywheel' and 'Low speed flywheel'.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric breakdown; Electric switchgear; Electric utilities; Flywheels; Outages; Uninterruptible power systems; Flywheel storage systems; High speed flywheel; Low speed flywheel; Power failure; Power quality systems; Electric energy storage

Authors: Mi J., Lee Y.Y., Morse W.M., Pai C.I., Pappas G.C., Sanders R., Semertzidis Y.K., Warburton D., Zapasek R., Jungmann K., Roberts L.
Title: Pulsed modulator power supply for the g-2 muon storage ring injection kicker
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mi, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Lee, Y.Y., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Morse, W.M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Pai, C.I., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Pappas, G.C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Sanders, R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Semertzidis, Y.K., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Warburton, D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Zapasek, R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Jungmann, K., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Roberts, L., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the pulse modulator power supplies used to drive the kicker magnets that inject the muon beam into the g-2 storage ring that has been built at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Three modulators built into coaxial structures consisting of a series circuit of an energy storage capacitor, a damping resistor and a fast thyratron switch are used to energize three magnets that kick the beam into the proper orbit. A 100 kV charging power supply is used to charge the capacitor to 95 kV. The damping resistor shapes the magnet current waveform to a 450 nanosecond half-sine to match the injection requirements. This paper discusses the modulator design, construction and operation.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Electric waveforms; Modulators; Particle beam injection; Pulse generators; Pulse modulation; Resistors; Thyratrons; Ultrafast phenomena; Injection kickers; Muon storage rings; Pulsed modulator power supplies; Storage rings

Authors: Choi J., Huang J.Y., Kim M.G., Lee T.-Y., Park E.S., Chang S.S.
Title: Operational status of PLS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, J., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Huang, J.Y., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Kim, M.G., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Lee, T.-Y., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Park, E.S., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea; Chang, S.S., Pohang Accelerator Lab, Kyungbuk, South Korea
Abstract: The Pohang Light Source (PLS) has been operating successfully at 2.0 GeV. But now the energy can be raised up to 2.5 GeV by energy ramping in the storage ring. The operational status of PLS is presented including 2.5 GeV operation. Beam parameters such as emittance, lifetime etc. have been measured at a few energy levels. The measured results are presented and discussed with emphasis on their energy dependence.
Index Keywords: Electron energy levels; Light sources; Energy ramping; Storage rings

Authors: Zubieta L., Bonert R.
Title: Experimental 400 kWsec double-layer capacitor energy storage system
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zubieta, L., Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Canada; Bonert, R., Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: Double-Layer Power Capacitors (DLCs) are very attractive in several applications and specially in high power load shaving. However, the electrical behaviour of these devices is considerably different from the traditional capacitors. Due to the low voltage of the single cell DLC, many devices have to be connected in series to reach the technically required voltages. This paper presents the aspects to be considered in building an energy storage system based on double-layer capacitors, especially those factors that may affect the voltage sharing among capacitors. Furthermore, the paper presents the experimental results from a 400 kWsec energy storage system built with 100 double-layer capacitors connected in series.
Index Keywords: Double layer power capacitor; Voltage sharing; Capacitance; Electric potential; Equivalent circuits; Mathematical models; Resistors; Capacitors

Authors: Dahono Pekik A., Riyadi Slamet, Mudawari Ahmad, Haroen Yanuarsyah
Title: Output ripple analysis of multiphase dc-dc converters
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Bandung Inst of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Dahono, Pekik A., Bandung Inst of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia; Riyadi, Slamet, Bandung Inst of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia; Mudawari, Ahmad, Bandung Inst of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia; Haroen, Yanuarsyah, Bandung Inst of Technology, Bandung, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper presents an output ripple analysis of multiphase dc-dc converters that having an output LC filter. Analytical expressions for the output voltage ripple of two- and three-phase dc-dc converters are derived. Influence of the coupling coefficient of the output filter inductor on the output ripple is investigated. Because the unique parameters of the LC filter cannot be determined solely based on the specified maximum output ripple, an additional criterion based on minimum energy storage is introduced. A comparative evaluation of single-phase, two-phase, and three-phase dc-dc converters is presented. Validity of the proposed analysis method is verified by experimental results.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitors; Electric filters; Electric inductors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric resistance; Electric switches; Power electronics; Coupling coefficient; Filter inductor; Multiphase DC-DC converters; Output ripple analysis; Power density; Switching frequency; Power converters

Authors: Rim Geun-Hie, Cho Chu-Hyun, Pavlov E.P.
Title: Design and testing of a rotary arc gap switch for pulsed power
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, Changwon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Rim, Geun-Hie, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, Changwon, South Korea; Cho, Chu-Hyun, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, Changwon, South Korea; Pavlov, E.P., Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, Changwon, South Korea
Abstract: One of the key issues in the pulsed power generation and application is the switch technology. The switches are divided into two categories of the opening and the closing switch. The lack of good repetitive opening switches has inhibited the use of inductive energy storage system despite its high energy density. Being contrasted with the opening switches, the closing switches are relatively simple and can be readily available with capacitive energy storage system. The most popular closing-switches up-to date are spark-gap switches. Theses switches have very limited lifetime due to arc-corrosion resulting from pinch effect and localized arc-heating. To extend the switch lifetime by minimizing electrode-vaporization, rotary arc gap-switches are proposed in the literatures. The rotation of the arc can be achieved by providing rotating magnetic field from outside or by self-induced magnetic field. This study investigates a rotating arc gap (RAG) switch driven by the self-induced magnetic field. The physical dimensions, rotating arc-speed, arc voltage-drop, and its experimental set-up are described in detail.
Index Keywords: Electric arcs; Electric energy storage; Electric network synthesis; Electric potential; Electric power generation; Magnetic fields; Pulsed power generation; Rotating arc gap (RAG) switches; Voltage drop; Electric switches

Authors: Wenninger J.
Title: Observation of radial ring deformations using closed orbits at LEP
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wenninger, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: With a circumference of 26.7 km the LEP ring is subject to long range geological deformations which must be monitored accurately to guarantee a sufficient precision on the beam energy for the LEP experiments. Changes of the LEP circumference can be extracted from the radial position of the closed orbits with an accuracy better than 0.1 mm. The observed tidal deformations with amplitudes of up to 1 mm were found to be in good agreement with geological models. Besides such periodic effects seasonal circumference variations of 2 mm are also observed. A summary of measurements collected between 1993 and 1998 is presented.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Geologic models; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Particle beam energy; Storage rings

Authors: Zisman M.S., Himel T.M.
Title: Commissioning of the PEP-II Low-Energy Ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zisman, M.S., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Himel, T.M., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The newly constructed PEP-II Low-Energy Ring (LER) is designed to store up to 3 A of 3.1 GeV positrons. It was built as a collaboration between SLAC, LBNL, and LLNL. The ring was completely installed and under vacuum on July 107 1998. First stored beam was obtained on July 16, and first evidence for electron-positron collisions between LER and HER (High-Energy Ring) beams was observed on July 23, marking the formal completion of the PEP-II project. To date, three commissioning runs have occurred, the first in July 1998 (3 weeks), the second during October-December 1998 (7 weeks), and the most recent during January-February 1999 (5 weeks). During these runs various problems were uncovered and corrected, and the stored beam current has increased from 1 mA to 1160 mA. In this paper, the final LER configuration is described and results of the commissioning runs are presented. The LER is making steady progress toward its operating current of 2.16 A.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Positrons; Low-energy ring (LER); Storage rings

Authors: Jalil M.B.A., Wagner M.
Title: Effect of stray capacitances in a multiple-tunnel junction memory device
Affiliations: Microelectronics Research Centre, Cavendish Laboratory, CB3 0HE, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Hitachi Cambridge Laboratory, Cavendish Lab., Madingley Rd., C., Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jalil, M.B.A., Microelectronics Research Centre, Cavendish Laboratory, CB3 0HE, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Wagner, M., Hitachi Cambridge Laboratory, Cavendish Lab., Madingley Rd., C., Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: The retention time of a multiple-tunnel junction (MTJ) trap device is investigated, taking into account the effects of stray capacitances, which have been neglected so far. Using the image-soliton method, the exact solution to Gibb's energy change of tunnelling across the MTJ is obtained. The I-V characteristics and the retention time are then approximated via a much-reduced Master Equation. It is found that the stability of the trap is not adversely affected by stray capacitances provided that temperature is kept low.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Current voltage characteristics; Electron tunneling; Gibbs free energy; Semiconductor junctions; Tunnel junctions; Multiple tunnel junctions (MTJ) trap memory devices; Stray capacitance; Semiconductor storage

Authors: Heil C., Eckardt B., Betz R.
Title: Development and implementation of an in-situ post-accident sampling system (In-situ PASS)

Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Electric energy storage; Hazards; Thermodynamics; Accident sampling systems; Electric power plants

Authors: Biryukov V.M.
Title: On possibility of crystal extraction and collimation at 0.1-1 GeV
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Inst for High Energy Physics, Protvino, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Biryukov, V.M., Inst for High Energy Physics, Protvino, Russian Federation
Abstract: Bent crystal situated in a circulating beam can serve for efficient slow extraction or active collimation of the beams. This technique, well established at 10-1000 GeV, could be efficient also at the energies as low as 0.1-10 GeV according to the computer simulations presented in this paper. Applications might include halo scraping in the Spallation Neutron Source or slow extraction from synchrotrons.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Crystals; Storage rings; Bent crystals; Particle beam collimation; Particle beam extraction

Authors: Hua C.H., Clinthorne N.H., Wilderman S.J., Leblanc J.W., Rogers W.L.
Title: Quantitative evaluation of information loss for cornpton cameras
Affiliations: Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hua, C.H., Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Clinthorne, N.H., Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Wilderman, S.J., Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Leblanc, J.W., Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Rogers, W.L., Department of Biomédical Engineering, Division of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: Compton cameras decouple the inverse relationship between spatial resolution and detection sensitivity which compromises the performance of conventional collimated cameras. However, this improvement is usually achieved at the expense of the amount of information conveyed by each detected photon, In this paper, we propose a simple approach to calculate the information loss for a ring Compton camera. We describe this information loss as "decoding penalty", defined as the ratio of variance of reconstructed intensity for a pixel of interest for a ring Compton camera to a mechanically collimated camera normalized to a per-detected-photon basis. The uniform Cramér-Rao bound, our mathematical tool, provides a lower bound on the variance that is dependent on the system and data statistics alone rather than the estimator. Results suggest that ring Compton cameras perform comparably to conventional collimated cameras at incident photon energy of 140 keV and substantially outperform their counterparts at 364 keV. ©1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Compton cameras; Cramer-Rao bound; Information loss; Gamma rays; Image reconstruction; Information use; Mathematical models; Optimization; Photons; Storage rings; X ray cameras

Authors: Assmann R., Dehning B., Hildreth M., Matheson J., Mugnai G., Placidi M., Roncarolo F., Torrence E., Sonnemann F., Uythoven J., Wenninger J., Blondel A.
Title: Observation of radiative spin-polarization at 60.6 GeV
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Assmann, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Dehning, B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hildreth, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Matheson, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mugnai, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Placidi, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Roncarolo, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Torrence, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Sonnemann, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Uythoven, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wenninger, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Blondel, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Radiative spin-polarization has been used extensively at LEP to accurately measure the beam energy around the Z resonance. As the LEP physics has moved on to the W boson the calibration based on polarization must be extended towards higher beam energies. This is difficult as the depolarizing effects of spin resonances grow rapidly with beam energy. At LEP it has been possible for the first time to measure transverse beam polarization at 60.6 GeV. To allow a build-up of polarization the tunes and the energy were chosen accurately. A low phase advance optics was used and careful orbit correction was carried out using dynamic beam based alignment data. Harmonic spin matching was applied both in a deterministic and a novel semi-empirical way.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Polarization; Positrons; Radiative spin polarization; Storage rings

Authors: Harkay K.C.
Title: Theory and measurement of the electron cloud effect
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harkay, K.C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Photoelectrons produced through the interaction of synchrotron radiation and the vacuum chamber walls can be accelerated by a charged particle beam, acquiring sufficient energy to produce secondary electrons (SEs) in collisions with the walls. If the secondary-electron yield (SEY) coefficient of the wall material is greater than one, a runaway condition can develop. In addition to the SEY, the degree of amplification depends on the beam intensity and temporal distribution. As the electron cloud builds up along a train of stored bunches, a transverse perturbation of the head bunch can be communicated to trailing bunches in a wakefield-like interaction with the cloud. The electron cloud effect is especially of concern for the high-intensity PEP-II (SLAC) and KEK B-factories and at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. An initiative was undertaken at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) storage ring to characterize the electron cloud in order to provide realistic limits on critical input parameters in the models and improve their predictive capabilities. An intensive research program was undertaken at CERN to address key issues relating to the LHC. After giving an overview, the recent theoretical and experimental results from the APS and the other laboratories will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; Photons; Electron clouds; Photoelectrons; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Dénès G., Milova G., Antonov B.D.
Title: Phase transformations of superionic PbSnF4 above ambient temperature: X-ray diffraction versus temperature
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Laboratory of Solid State Chemistry and Mössbauer Spectroscopy, Concordia University, Montréal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada; Institute of High Temperature Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Ural Division, Ekaterinburg, 620145, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dénès, G., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Laboratory of Solid State Chemistry and Mössbauer Spectroscopy, Concordia University, Montréal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada; Milova, G., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Laboratory of Solid State Chemistry and Mössbauer Spectroscopy, Concordia University, Montréal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada; Antonov, B.D., Institute of High Temperature Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Ural Division, Ekaterinburg, 620145, Russian Federation
Abstract: PbSnF4 is the highest performance fluoride ion conductor. A fast amperometric response oxygen sensor based on PbSnF4 has been constructed and tested. A long life device with time independent response and reliable performance requires the materials used for its construction be stable over the life time of the device in the operating conditions. Since ionic conductivity is thermally activated, possible use at high temperature can be envisaged. Therefore, it is of prime importance to know in details the behavior of the material versus time in the expected temperature range of use and of storage. PbSnF4 can be prepared by many methods that we have investigated, and each method gives a material that is different from the others in one way or another (symmetry, strain, particle randomization, particle dimensions, temperature range of stability). In addition, we have shown that several phase transitions take place versus temperature or when some other treatments are applied. Many of these transitions are very sluggish, and therefore give a false impression of stability, when the phases are actually metastable, and thus changes take place slowly over time. We have studied the stability of tetragonal α-PbSnF4 and o-PbSnF4 by use of X-ray diffraction, in the most probable conditions of use (ambient temperature to 200°C in air). Changes were found to take place, which should be taken into account in the design of devices and when establishing their optimum temperature of use and storage.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Amperometric sensors; Ionic conduction in solids; Phase transitions; Temperature; Thermodynamic stability; X ray diffraction analysis; Fluoride ion conductor; Time independent response; Lead compounds

Authors: Liu Mingsheng, Veteto Bryan, Claridge David E.
Title: Rehabilitating a thermal energy storage system through commissioning
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Mingsheng, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States; Veteto, Bryan, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States; Claridge, David E., Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Abstract: A thermal energy storage system was installed in a 37,000 ft2 hospital in April 1992. The chiller had to be operated every summer during peak demand periods until the authors rehabilitated system through building commissioning in late 1995. This paper presents information about the building systems, commissioning activities, and the measured energy savings.
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Refrigerating machinery; Building commissioning; Thermal energy storage systems; Heat storage

Authors: Hartmann R., Hartner G., Briel U.G., Dennerl K., Haberl F., Strueder L., Truemper J., Bihler E., Kendziorra E., Hochedez J.-F., Jourdain E., Dhez P., Salvetat Ph., Auerhammer J., Schmitz D., et. al.
Title: Quantum efficiency of the XMM pn-CCD camera
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hartmann, R., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Hartner, G., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Briel, U.G., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Dennerl, K., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Haberl, F., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Strueder, L., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Truemper, J., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Bihler, E., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Kendziorra, E., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Hochedez, J.-F., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Jourdain, E., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Dhez, P., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Salvetat, Ph., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Auerhammer, J., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; Schmitz, D., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany; et. al., Max-Planck-Inst fuer, Extraterrestrische Physik, Garching, Germany
Abstract: A review is given on the calibration techniques applied for quantum efficiency measurements at the Synchrotron Radiation Facility at the Institut d'Astrophysique Spatial (IAS) in Orsay and the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt at the electron storage ring BESSY in Berlin. Applied data correction is summarized such as charge transfer loss and split event recognition.

Authors: Ahrens Daniel W., Hanauer Brad T., Waters John E.
Title: Plastic Lithium Ion energy/power systems are key to integrated and affordable hybrid automotive solutions
Source title: AIAA/IEEE Digital Avionics Systems Conference - Proceedings
Affiliations: Delphi Automotive Systems, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ahrens, Daniel W., Delphi Automotive Systems, United States; Hanauer, Brad T., Delphi Automotive Systems, United States; Waters, John E., Delphi Automotive Systems, United States
Abstract: If Hybrid Electric Vehicles are going to be successful, practical energy/power solutions must be implemented. One major cost driver on any hybrid application is the energy storage system, and the greater the power or energy storage requirements, the greater the cost. In addition, the energy storage system can be a major integration challenge as it often consumes highly valued vehicle space. The packaging, maintenance, safety and mass issues of the energy storage system must also be considered, as they all impact vehicle integration requirements. With the advent of Plastic Lithium Ion (PLI) technology, energy storage systems can be minimized, thus reducing the impact of cost, mass and volume to the hybrid vehicle platform. In addition, PLI technology provides packaging flexibility for optimum vehicle integration. By leveraging creativity, plastics engineering, and systems integration, PLI technology holds the key to practical and affordable Hybrid Electric Vehicles.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Automotive engineering; Cost effectiveness; Electric vehicles; Energy storage; Ions; Lithium; Maintenance; Hybrid electric vehicles; Plastic lithium ion; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Vilkov Yu.V., Kravchenko A.S., Selemir V.D.
Title: Magnetocumulative source of high-power pulses with double inductive energy storage
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: VNIIEF, Sarov, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vilkov, Yu.V., VNIIEF, Sarov, Russian Federation; Kravchenko, A.S., VNIIEF, Sarov, Russian Federation; Selemir, V.D., VNIIEF, Sarov, Russian Federation
Abstract: Magneto-cumulative generators are high-power sources of magnetic energy pulses. Duration and shape of the pulses, created by these generators lies in a rather narrow range, which is determined by detonation velocity of the most power HE-substances, used in these generators. Different schemes and device for generator parameters agreement with load parameters are used for formation of current pulses of different shape and duration on a wide load values range. These schemes and devices include inductive coupling of generator contour with load contour, accumulation of magnetic energy, created by MCG and its commutation to the load using breaking units, which use phase transition metal-insulator at conductor temperature increase, current open switches and different types of plasma-erosion open switches. The main purpose of these schemes and devices is to create current pulse of required shape with comparable or higher power value, than developed by MCG, on the load. Below we will describe the source of high-power energy pulses, based on MCG. Transformer energy bending from MCG, breaking units, made of electrically exploding wires, and non-controllable sharpening discharger are used in this source.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric switches; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Magnetic energy pulses; Magnetocumulative generators; Pulse generators

Authors: Serej S., Kellogg E., Edgar R., Scholze F., Ulm G.
Title: Absolute calibration of the Chandra X-ray observatory: transfer standard solid state detectors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Serej, S., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States; Kellogg, E., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States; Edgar, R., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States; Scholze, F., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States; Ulm, G., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: In order to achieve as close as possible to the ground calibration goal of ≈ 1-2% for the Chandra X-ray Observatory (formerly AXAF), two high purity solid state detectors (SSD's) were used as transfer standards for measuring absolute x-ray flux. The calibration of these SSD's are based on the analysis of data obtained on various monochromatic and undispersed synchrotron beamlines at the BESSY electron storage ring in Berlin, Germany. Here we report on our updated analysis for determining the detector response function in the energy range 2.1-5.9 keV and on our recently completed analysis of the response function and detection efficiency measurements in the energy range 0.4-1.7 keV. The response function model used for spectral analysis of the data is based on the HYPERMET function, which is included in JMKmod within the XSPEC package.
Index Keywords: Calibration; Computer simulation; Electron ring accelerators; Light transmission; Photodiodes; Radiometers; Solid state devices; Spectrum analysis; Synchrotrons; X rays; Cyrogenic electrical substitution radiometer; Detector response function; Electron storage ring; Solid state detectors; Particle detectors

Authors: Giesselmann M., Zhang J., Heeren T., Kristiansen E., Dickens J., Castro D., Garcia D., Kristiansen M.
Title: Pulse power conditioning with a transformer for an inductive energy storage system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giesselmann, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Zhang, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Heeren, T., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Kristiansen, E., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Dickens, J., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Castro, D., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Garcia, D., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States; Kristiansen, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, United States
Abstract: One of the key technologies in a high power microwave system is the Pulsed Power Conditioning System (PPCS). For a system driven by an explosive flux compression generator, the PPCS may consist of an energy storage inductor, a fuse type opening switch and a sharpening spark gap. This paper presents the investigation of a PPCS with a pulse transformer. Before the construction of a prototype, the behavior of the PPCS has been simulated using the PSpice circuit simulation code. A transformer with a primary inductance Lp = 3.5 μH, secondary inductance Ls = 85 μH, and a coupling coefficient K = 0.75, was designed and used in our experiments. The transformer was designed with two coaxial windings. Simulation results as well as experimental waveforms are shown.
Index Keywords: Computer aided analysis; Computer simulation; Computer software; Electric energy storage; Electric network analysis; Electric spark gaps; Electric windings; Power inductors; Pulse generators; Waveform analysis; Coaxial windings; Inductive energy storage systems; Pulsed power conditioning systems (PPCS); Software package PSPICE; Pulse transformers

Authors: Leung K.K., Sutanto D.
Title: Storage power flow controller (SPFC) using battery storage
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Leung, K.K., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hong Kong; Sutanto, D., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper describes several new topologies of Energy Storage systems connected to the grid which can provide concomitant benefits associated with a Unified Power Flow Controller - a single device that provide fast control of real and reactive power along a transmission corridor by continuously providing phase angle control, series compensation and shunt reactive power compensation-while at the same time providing several other very important benefits to power system operation such as, harmonic compensation, load leveling, voltage stability improvement and back-up supply. These Storage Power Flow Controllers (SPFC) can provide improved power system operation and control, added system security and reduced power system losses.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric lines; Electric load flow; Electric network topology; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Electric power transmission; Energy storage; Power control; Power electronics; Reactive power; Battery energy storage systems; Energy Storage Systems; Flexible AC transmission systems; Phase angle control; Power quality; Storage Power Flow Controller; Transmission corridor; Unifield Power Flow Controller; Voltage drop compensation; Electric control equipment

Authors: Savage M.E.
Title: Final results from the high-current, high-action closing switch test program at Sandia National Laboratories
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Savage, M.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: We tested a variety of high-current closing switches for lifetime and reliability on a dedicated 2 MJ, 500 kA capacitor bank facility at Sandia National Laboratories. Our interest was a switch capable of one shot every few minutes, switching a critically damped, DC-charged 6.2 mF bank at 24 kV, with a peak current of 500 kA. The desired lifetime is 24 thousand shots. Typical of high-energy systems, particularly multi-module systems, the primary parameters of interest related to the switch are: 1) reliability, meaning absence of both pre-fires and no-fires, 2) total switch lifetime or number of shots between maintenance, and 3) cost. Cost was given lower priority at this evaluation stage because there are great uncertainties in estimating higher-quantity prices of these devices, most of which have been supplied before in only small quantities. The categories of switches tested are vacuum discharge, high-pressure discharge, and solid-state. Each group varies in terms of triggering ease, ease of maintenance, and tolerance to faults such as excess current and current reversal. We tested at least two variations of each technology group. The total number of shots on the switch test facility is about 50 thousand. We will present the results from the switch testing. The observed lifetime of different switches varied greatly: the shortest life was one shot; one device was still operating after six thousand shots. On several switches we measured the voltage drop during conduction and calculated energy dissipated in the switch; we will show these data also.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electric potential; Energy dissipation; Closing switches; High pressure discharge switches; Vacuum discharge switches; Electric switches

Authors: Lyubutin S.K., Rukin S.N., Slovikovsky B.G., Tsiranov S.N.
Title: Experimental study of SOS-based generator for low impedance load
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Lyubutin, S.K., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Rukin, S.N., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Slovikovsky, B.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Tsiranov, S.N., Russian Acad of Sciences, Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: This paper presents results of the experimental examination of a generator outfitted with a semiconductor opening switch operating with a low impedance (4-5 Ohm) load. The pulse amplitude reaches 50 kV at the half-height length of the semisquare pulse equal to 100 ns. The generator was examined at the pulse repetition rate of 5 Hz. The average output power at the load is up to 250 W. The output assembly of the generator comprises a pumping capacitor, a magnetic switch, a semiconductor opening switch, and a semisquare pulse generation circuit. The output assembly receives energy via a spark gap from an intermediate storage. The intermediate storage is charged by a pulsed thyristor charging unit having a step-up pulse transformer. The paper describes the test installation including the circuitry, the operating principle and characteristics of the constituent elements. It also furnishes results of the experiments on the transfer of energy in the generator elements, operation of the spark gap and the semiconductor opening switch, generation of the output pulse, and the energy loss.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric spark gaps; Magnetic devices; Pulse transformers; Semiconductor switches; Thyristors; Semiconductor opening switches (SOS); Pulse generators

Authors: Malek Chantal Khan, Saile Volker
Title: Application domains for synchrotron radiation sources of various energies
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malek, Chantal Khan, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States; Saile, Volker, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation, its production and some applications are presented with special regards to the main characteristics needed by most users and the various options for generating synchrotron light from bending magnets, undulators, and wigglers. In parallel to the development of various generations of increasingly powerful synchrotron light sources, compact and simply designed synchrotrons have been built for maximum x-ray output and uptime for industrial use or as smaller regional facilities. The use of synchrotron radiation for industry-related applications has increased continuously during the past 10 years and the demands in some fields like x-ray protein crystallography are expected to grow dramatically.
Index Keywords: Storage rings; X rays; X ray crystallography; Wigglers; Synchrotron light; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Waltman R.J., Zhang H., Khurshudov A., Pocker D., Karplus M., York B., Xiao Q.-F., Zadoori H., Thiele J.-U., Tyndall G.W.
Title: Effect of carbon overcoat thickness on the Zdol boundary lubricant film
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Tribology Division, TRIB
Affiliations: IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; IBM Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waltman, R.J., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Zhang, H., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Khurshudov, A., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Pocker, D., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Karplus, M., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; York, B., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Xiao, Q.-F., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Zadoori, H., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Thiele, J.-U., IBM Systems Storage Division, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States; Tyndall, G.W., IBM Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, United States
Abstract: Formation of a tribologically reliable interface between the read-write head and the computer disk in hard-disk drives is accomplished by the use of a thin, wear-resistant carbon overcoat in conjunction with a molecularly-thin perfluoropolyether (PFPE) lubricant film. The intermolecular interactions that develop between the PFPE lubricant and the carbon overcoat govern the adhesion, coverage, and physical properties of the lubricant, e.g. the lubricant structure and mobility. Consequently, the molecular interactions at the lubricant-carbon interface will contribute to the overall tribological performance of the disk-drive. Due to the ever-increasing demands for storage capacity, pressure exists to reduce the separation distance between the read/write head and disk surface. One means of reducing this separation distance is to use thinner protective overcoats on both the head and disk surfaces. In this study the interactions between Fomblin Zdol and both amorphous hydrogenated (CHx) and nitrogenated (CNx) carbon overcoats were investigated as a function of overcoat thickness from 0-100 angstroms. The Zdol film structure was probed by titrating the magnetic alloy, the CHx and CNx surfaces with Zdol. The molecular weight dependence of the maximum bonded Zdol thickness on these surfaces is used to deduce structural information on the adsorbed Zdol film. In progressing from CHx to CNx to the magnetic alloy, we find the Zdol boundary layer film to be characterized by an increase in average distance between the PFPE backbone and the surface, or equivalently an increase in the average Zdol monolayer thickness. On the CHx overcoat, Zdol preferentially lies more parallel to the surface, whereas on the magnetic layer, Zdol is oriented more perpendicular to the surface. When these experiments were conducted as a function of carbon overcoat thickness, we find that interaction of Zdol with the field of the underlying magnetic film becomes important at carbon film thicknesses <30 angstroms. The dependence of the Zdol adhesion on carbon overcoat thickness was quantified by determining the Zdol film thickness dependence of both the dispersive and polar components of the Helmholtz free energy. The Zdol bonding kinetics were also studied as a function of carbon thickness.
Index Keywords: Boundary layers; Carbon; Free energy; Interfaces (materials); Lubricants; Magnetic disk storage; Magnetic films; Magnetic heads; Molasses; Monolayers; Protective coatings; Wear resistance; Boundary lubricant films; Carbon overcoats; Tribology

Authors: Scofield M., Dunnavant K.
Title: Evaporative cooling and TES after deregulation
Affiliations: Conservation Mechanical Systems, Sebastopol, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scofield, M., Conservation Mechanical Systems, Sebastopol, CA, United States; Dunnavant, K.
Abstract: The integration of evaporative cooling and thermal energy storage (TES) systems in dry western climates has many benefits beyond installation and operating cost savings. High occupancy applications such as schools, prisons, nursing homes, and hospitals benefit from the introduction of all outdoor air. Improved air quality with winter humidification and reduced risk of airborne infection promise to increase productivity and reduce absenteeism for crowded indoor environments.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Cost effectiveness; Deregulation; Evaporative cooling systems; Heat storage; Crowded indoor environment; Air conditioning

Authors: Horn Paul M.
Title: Information technology will change everything
Authors with affiliations: Horn, Paul M.
Abstract: There will be no institution, no person, and no government that will be unaffected when information technology changes everything. The extrapolation is information storage. Before the magnetic disk-drive, it took a hunk of material to store a single bit of information. While the energy to do one piece of computing dropped by 12 orders from 1948 to 1990. So, the information technology industry continues to speed up exponentially. Knowledge becomes the currency, as digital data storage is becoming so inexpensive. Information, not data, will become the currency of the next century. Augmented-reality means that technology will let one interact with your environment in fundamentally new ways.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Economic and social effects; Magnetic recording; Technological forecasting; Moore's law; Information technology

Authors: Picci G., Rabuffi M.
Title: Pulse handling capability of energy storage metallized film capacitors
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: ICAR, Monza, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Picci, G., ICAR, Monza, Italy; Rabuffi, M., ICAR, Monza, Italy
Abstract: The aim of this work was to point out the current performance of metallized polypropylene film capacitors. Many tests have demonstrated that the contact between the sprayed terminations and the metallized electrodes is one of the most critical points for capacitors manufactured with this technology, generally when the capacitors are used in impulsive conditions. This is the case of energy storage application. The effects of pulses having high peak current, but short duration (20-40 μs), are compared to the effects of pulses having lower peak current, but higher duration (200-300 μs). The comparison is made between pulses having the same I2t. The modalities of manufacture and the conditions during metallization, winding and spraying processes are examined in the context of certain mechanical problems during the pulse transient, with particular attention to the connections on the sprayed terminations. The possibility to detect the beginning of detachment of sprayed ends by the use of photodiodes has been taken into consideration. The result of these studies has been an improvement in the performance of energy storage capacitors meeting the discharge and life requirements of the NIF capacitors.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Photodiodes; Plastic films; Polypropylenes; Metallized polypropylene self-healing capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Arsoy A.B., Wang Z., Liu Y., Ribeiro P.F.
Title: Transient modeling and simulation of a SMES coil and the power electronics interface
Affiliations: IEEE; Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24060-0111, United States; BWX Technologies, Inc., Lynchburg, VA 24505-0785, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arsoy, A.B., IEEE, Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24060-0111, United States; Wang, Z., IEEE, Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24060-0111, United States; Liu, Y., IEEE, Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA 24060-0111, United States; Ribeiro, P.F., IEEE, BWX Technologies, Inc., Lynchburg, VA 24505-0785, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the modeling and simulation results of a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system for power transmission applications. This is the largest SMES coil ever built for power utility applications and has the following unique design characteristics: 50 MW (96 MW peak), 100 MJ, 24 kV dc interface. As a consequence of the high-power and high-voltage interface, special care needs to be taken with overvoltages that can stress the insulation of the SMES coil, especially in its cryogenic operating environment. The transient overvoltages impressed on the SMES coil are the focus of this investigation. Suppression methods were also studied to minimize transients. The simulation is based on detailed coil and multiphase gate turn-off (GTO)-based chopper models. The study was performed to assist in the design of the SMES coil insulation, transient protection, and the power electronics specification and interface requirements.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Computer simulation; Power electronics; Superconducting magnets; Thyristors; Transients; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric energy storage

Authors: Henderson S., Boisvert V., Finkelstein K., Rice D., White J.
Title: Technique for measuring the relative CESR beam energy
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henderson, S., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Boisvert, V., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Finkelstein, K., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Rice, D., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; White, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: The beam energy at the Cornell Electron Storage Ring must be maintained within 1 MeV of the Υ(4S) resonance peak. The beam energy is determined on a run-by-run basis by calculation based upon machine parameters. As a test of the energy calculation we have explored a technique for determining the relative CESR beam energy using synchrotron radiation. We describe the technique and present a status report on our experimental investigations.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Electron energy levels; Electron resonance; Mathematical models; Synchrotron radiation; Cornell electron storage ring (CESR); Storage rings

Authors: Krasnopolsky V., Krylov S., Mamaev G., Mamaev S., Poutchkov S., Tenyakov I., Fedorov V., Sidorov A., Alekseev N.
Title: ITEP-TWAC injection and extraction kicker
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Krasnopolsky, V., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Krylov, S., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Mamaev, G., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Mamaev, S., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Poutchkov, S., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Tenyakov, I., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Fedorov, V., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Sidorov, A., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Alekseev, N., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The system multi-turn injection and fast extraction for installation ITEP-TWAC is developing in MRTI RAS. In this paper one kicker in injection ring and one extraction kicker in storage ring are described. In both kickers rise time of magnetic field is not more 300 ns, and platen duration 300-500 ns. The total length of the injection kicker is 1.8 m, aperture is 0.1×0.1 m and kicker strength is 0.16 T·m. The total length of the extraction kicker is 1.5 m, aperture is 0.09×0.09 m and kicker strength is 0.14 T·m. Both kickers are situated outside vacuum chamber and consisted of number uniform sections 0.3 m length. In each section ferrite magnet, pulse former line, matched resistor 2.5 Ohm and 50 kV ceramic metal thyratron with grounded grid are used. Pulse current in each magnet achieves 7-8 kA in order to magnetic field not more 0.1 T. In each former line concentration capacitors and inductance in order to storage energy and pulse correction are used. The compact pulse power supply system in each section gives the possibility connection with magnet short feed buses without low-impedance 2.5 Ohm cable.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Capacitors; Electric inductors; Ferrites; Magnetic fields; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Pulse generators; Resistors; Thyratrons; Ultrafast phenomena; Extraction kickers; Injection kickers; Storage rings

Authors: Shiue Wen-Tsong, Chakrabarti Chaitali
Title: Memory design and exploration for low power, embedded systems
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shiue, Wen-Tsong, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States; Chakrabarti, Chaitali, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we describe a procedure for memory design and exploration for low power embedded systems. Our procedure tries to reduce the power consumption due to memory traffic by (i) applying memory optimizing transformations such as loop transformations, (ii) storing frequently accessed variables in a register file and an on-chip cache, and (iii) reducing the conflict misses by appropriate choice of cache size and data placement in off chip memory. We then choose a cache configuration (cache size, line size) that satisfies the system requirements of area, number of cycles and energy. We include energy in the performance metrics, since for different cache configurations, the variation in energy is quite different from the variation in the number of cycles. Our memory exploration procedure considers only a selected set of candidate points, thereby reducing the search time significantly.
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Buffer storage; Computer architecture; Embedded systems; Energy utilization; Mathematical transformations; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Storage allocation (computer); Off chip memories; On-chip caches; Digital signal processing

Authors: Sikora J., Billing M., Codner G., Meller R., Strohman C., Pelaia T.
Title: Longitudinal feedback at CESR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sikora, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Billing, M., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Codner, G., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Meller, R., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Strohman, C., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Pelaia, T., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: Total stored electron and positron beam currents at the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) have been limited by the presence of a dipole multibunch longitudinal instability having a threshold at approximately 250 mA of total current. A longitudinal feedback system has been under constant development, test, operation and upgrade over the past several years. The result has been an increase in the High Energy Physics (HEP) operating current to over 500 mA total. This paper describes the overall design of the present system, using a horizontal stripline kicker to produce combined horizontal and longitudinal bunch by bunch beam stabilization. Some details on specific subsystems, including: receiver design, individual bunch phase DC offset correction, digital signal filtering, and the RF modulator will be given, as well as an outline of plans for further development.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Longitudinal feedback system; Storage rings

Authors: Logatchov P.V., Bak P.A., Starostenko A.A., Dikansky N.S., Tupikov V.S., Gubin K.V., Mishnev V.M., Korabelnikov M.B., Fedotov M.G.
Title: Non-destructive singlepass monitor of longitudinal charge distribution in an ultrarelativistic electron bunch
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Logatchov, P.V., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Bak, P.A., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Starostenko, A.A., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Dikansky, N.S., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tupikov, V.S., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gubin, K.V., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mishnev, V.M., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Korabelnikov, M.B., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Fedotov, M.G., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: We present here the first experimental test of a singlepass non-destructive method of monitoring of longitudinal charge distribution in an intensive relativistic electron bunch. This method is based on the scanning of a thin electron beam within the energy range 20-100 kV in the electromagnetic field of an intensive relativistic bunch. The probe beam was injected across the path of primary relativistic bunch. This type of an electron beam probe is suitable for both circular or linear accelerators. The prototype results obtained at VEPP-3 storage ring are in good agreement with the calculations and give us a very high degree of confidence that this single bunch diagnostic tool can be very useful not only for accelerator tuning, but also for precise measurements.
Index Keywords: Electric charge; Electromagnetic field effects; Nondestructive examination; Storage rings; Electron bunches; Electron beams

Authors: Abo-Bakr M., Anders W., Buerkmann K., Duerr V., Kuske P., Mueller R., Ott K., Scheer M., Weihreter E., Wuestefeld G., Winick H., Kaiser H., Koupsidis J., Marx M., Voss G.-A.
Title: Extending the range of a low energy SR-source to hard X-rays
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BESSY, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Abo-Bakr, M., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Anders, W., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Buerkmann, K., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Duerr, V., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Kuske, P., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Mueller, R., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Ott, K., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Scheer, M., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Weihreter, E., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Wuestefeld, G., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Winick, H., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Kaiser, H., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Koupsidis, J., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Marx, M., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Voss, G.-A., BESSY, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: An outline design is presented for a SR-source providing high brilliance VUV/soft X-Rays and high flux hard X-rays based on existing hardware of the BESSY I storage ring, which will be shut down by the end of 1999. Essential features are a 6-cell double bend achromat lattice, with low beta in three of the 6 long straight sections to facilitate the use of superconducting multipole wigglers. Beam optical implications are discussed together with technical modifications of existing hardware and possible operation at 1.0 GeV. A design of a 7.5 T multipole wiggler is given.
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Superconducting devices; X rays; Double bend achromat lattice; Multipole wigglers; Storage rings

Authors: Tanabe Takaya, Takayanagi Makoto, Tatemiti Hidetoshi, Ura Tetsuya, Yamamoto Manabu
Title: Redundant optical storage system using DVD-RAM library
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems
Affiliations: NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanabe, Takaya, NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan; Takayanagi, Makoto, NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan; Tatemiti, Hidetoshi, NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan; Ura, Tetsuya, NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan; Yamamoto, Manabu, NTT Integrated Information &, Energy Systems Lab, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: A Digital virtual Disk (DVD) random access memory (RAM) Redundant Array of Inexpensive Libraries (RAIL) optical storage system has been developed and tested at NTT Integrated Information & Energy Systems Laboratories. The RAIL storage system incorporates multiple DVD libraries that consist of dual DVD-RAM drives. Each DVD library utilizes a single mechanical robot picker for media loading and unloading. The current capacity of the single sided and single layered DVD optical media used in that system is 2.6 gigabytes. To increase the reliability of stored data and at the same time to eliminate the need for read after write verification, a process that can double the recording time, a RAID 4 algorithm has been implemented in the control unit of the RAIL storage system. Data sent by the host are transferred to a control unit, that stripes data over five data groups plus one parity unit. The striped and parity data are sent to individual libraries and written to DVD media. This system writes and retrieves storage data with a transfer rate of approximate 6 MB/sec, using write and read control methods that minimize data striping overhead. Other performance factors that affect the transfer rates are the striping size and the number of drives used in the RAIL system. Experimental results indicate that stripe sizes of 32 to 64 KB are sufficient to achieve high throughput. In addition, the transfer rates showed no further increase when the number of 1 drives exceeded eight. This RAIL optical storage system which offers data redundancy can be used for networked multimedia applications.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Database systems; Optical disk storage; Videodisks; Digital virtual disk (DVD); Random access storage

Authors: Roser T.
Title: Acceleration of polarized protons to high energy
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roser, T., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: High energy polarized beam collisions will open up the unique physics opportunities of studying spin effects in hard processes. However, the acceleration of polarized beams in circular accelerators is complicated by the numerous depolarizing spin resonances. Using a partial Siberian Snake and a rf dipole that ensure stable adiabatic spin motion during acceleration has made it possible to accelerate polarized protons to 25 GeV at the Brookhaven AGS. Full Siberian Snakes and polarimeters are being developed for RHIC to make the acceleration of polarized protons to 250 GeV possible. A similar scheme is being studied for the 800 GeV HERA proton accelerator.
Index Keywords: Particle beam dynamics; Polarimeters; Polarization; Protons; Storage rings; High energy polarized beam collisions; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Reeves S.R., Pekot L.J., Koperna G.J., Ammer James R.
Title: Deliverability enhancement via advanced fracturing technology in gas storage wells
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Advanced Resources Int, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reeves, S.R., Advanced Resources Int, Inc, United States; Pekot, L.J., Advanced Resources Int, Inc, United States; Koperna, G.J., Advanced Resources Int, Inc, United States; Ammer, James R., Advanced Resources Int, Inc, United States
Abstract: To bypass formation damage and sustain/enhance well deliverability, several new and novel fracture-stimulation technologies have been tested in gas storage fields across the U.S. as part of a joint U.S. Department of Energy and Gas Research Institute R&D program that started in 1994. These new technologies include tip-screenout fracturing, hydraulic fracturing with liquid CO 2 and proppant, extreme overbalance fracturing, and high-energy gas fracturing. Based on the results derived from the project, conclusions have been drawn concerning the applicability and utility of these technologies, storage well damage conditions and remediation candidate selection, and future technology needs.
Index Keywords: Formation damage; Gas storage wells; High energy gas fracturing; Pre and post fracture diagnostic test; Pressure transient tests; Carbon dioxide; Enhanced recovery; Flow of fluids; Natural gas fields; Natural gas wells; Societies and institutions; Well pressure; Well stimulation; Well testing; Hydraulic fracturing

Authors: Guertin S.M., Swift G.M., Nguyen D.
Title: Single-event upset test results for the Xilinx XQ1701L PROM
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guertin, S.M., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Swift, G.M., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Nguyen, D., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: A 3.3 V serial PROM, used to configure advanced Xilinx field programmable gate arrays (FPGA), was tested for single event effects with heavy ions. Device latchup was observed with an linear energy transfer threshold of 55 MeV per mg/cm2 and a saturated cross-section of 10-5 cm2. Three types of upsets were measured: address errors; premature end-of-program signals; and functional interrupt. One way to mitigate single event upset (SEU) effects in these devices is to control the time period during which they operate. An alternative approach is to cycle the power in the PROM just before configuring or reconfiguring the FPGA devices that are driven by the PROM to avoid the functionality errors that can be induced by SEU effects.
Index Keywords: Field programmable gate arrays; Random access storage; Single event effect; Single event latchup; Radiation effects

Authors: Portnov George G.
Title: Russian experience in composite flywheels spin-tests
Affiliations: Inst of Polymer Mechanics of Latvian, Univ, Riga, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Portnov, George G., Inst of Polymer Mechanics of Latvian, Univ, Riga, Latvia
Abstract: Spin-test results are given for two types of composite flywheels, namely, molded disks and rim-type flywheels with chord-wise wrapping. The models differed in form, size, and materials. Dynamic problems associated with flywheel speed-up, ultimate peripheral speeds, and the limiting energy storage capacities are described. Results are also given for full-scale flywheel tests. Dynamic problems were shown to be the governing factors for rim-type flywheels.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Delamination; Elasticity; Energy storage; Friction; Resins; Resonance; Rotation; Stresses; Testing; Chord wise wrapping; Composite flywheels; Molded disks flywheels; Rim type flywheels; Spin tests; Flywheels

Authors: Shirey Cynthia L., Bakis Charles E., Weaver Eric J.
Title: Tensile behavior of filament wound composites in vacuum
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shirey, Cynthia L., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Bakis, Charles E., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Weaver, Eric J., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Abstract: The tensile behavior of candidate filament wound composite materials for flywheel energy storage applications was evaluated. The materials were conditioned in a vacuum of 10-30 mtorr for at least 85 days prior to testing, and no appreciable weight losses were recorded during that period. Glass and carbon composites conditioned and fatigue tested in vacuum lost 10% to 12% of remaining strength per decade of logarithmic lifetime over the 102 to 105 range of cyclic lifetime. The ZenTrom glass/epoxy and the S2-glass/epoxy composites were noted to have more overall fatigue sensitivity than either E-glass/epoxy or T700S carbon/epoxy due to a steeper slope of the S-N curve at very low cyclic lifetimes. Typical fatigue failures were characterized as a longitudinal splintering mode growing inward from the lateral edges of the specimen. No significant differences in the ultimate tensile strength, Young's modulus, and ultimate strain were noted when vacuum-conditioned specimen were compared to as-received specimens.
Index Keywords: Carbon fibers; Elastic moduli; Energy storage; Epoxy resins; Fatigue of materials; Fatigue testing; Flywheels; Glass fibers; Strain; Tensile strength; Vacuum applications; Fatigue sensitivity; Filament wound composite materials; Glass and carbon composites; Tensile behavior; Ultimate tensile strength; Composite materials

Abstract: Nearfield recording and readout are investigated using reflection mode near-field scanning optical microscope (NSOM). About 150 nm sized-marks were recorded and readout in the three-layered phase-change optical disk using Ge2Sb2Te5 active medium. Full width at half maximum (FWHM) value of linewidth decreased with increasing writing speed. The minimum mark size of amorphous phase was much smaller than mark size from conventional far-field optics.

Authors: Huang Brad C.
Title: Polar woven flywheel rim design
Affiliations: Applied Material Technologies, Inc, Santa Ana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Brad C., Applied Material Technologies, Inc, Santa Ana, United States
Abstract: Although chemical batteries have been used extensively in spacecraft design, mechanical batteries such as flywheels offer significant weight and life benefits. Flywheel battery systems have the potential to store large amounts of energy for very little weight compared to chemical batteries and they can also be used as attitude control actuators to replace reaction wheel assemblies and control moment gyros. This dual function capability provides weight savings and an improvement in life and reliability of the total spacecraft system. Life expectancy of a flywheel is at least 10 years, during which it is expected to undergo 50,000 cycles (charge/discharge) while supplying 3 to 5 kW-h of usable energy. Two types of composite rotor construction include filament wound and polar woven architecture. Filament wound rotors are the most efficient, however, if rotor size is limited, a thin-walled filament wound rotor might not provide the required energy and therefore a shorter, thick-walled rotor is needed. Polar woven architecture offers superior radial stiffness and strength for a rotor design, which is required for the high radial stresses generated in a thick-wall rim section.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Energy storage; Fabrics; Reliability; Rotors; Spacecraft; Stiffness; Strength of materials; Stresses; Filament wound architecture; Flywheel battery systems; Polar woven architecture; Polar woven flywheel rim design; Total spacecraft system; Flywheels

Abstract: In 1998, a major upgrade to the South Pole facilities was started. The upgrade was constructed in increments.
