The review covers several considerations, such as tank configuration, leak containment, leak detection, piping, tank material selection criteria, the modular pumping building, alarm systems, and tank fill systems.

Authors: Leblanc J.W., Clinthorne N.H., Hua C.-H., Nygard E., Rogers W.L., Wehe D.K., Weilhammer P., Wilderman S.J.
Title: Experimental results from the C-SPRINT prototype compton camera
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Divison of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; IDE AS, Oslo, Norway; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Leblanc, J.W., Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Clinthorne, N.H., Divison of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Hua, C.-H., Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Nygard, E., IDE AS, Oslo, Norway; Rogers, W.L., Divison of Nuclear Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Wehe, D.K., Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Weilhammer, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wilderman, S.J., Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: A Compton camera is being tested for nuclear medicine applications. Our design uses a single 3 cm by 3 cm silicon pad detector as the first detector system, and SPRINT, an array of position-sensitive sodium iodide modules, as the second detector. Experimental results with a 99mTc point source show coincidence energy spectra agreeing with theoretical predictions. The coincidence energy spectra for both silicon and SPRINT detectors correspond to the geometry-determined scattering angle range. Recorded energy falls outside of strict geometric limits because of Doppler broadening and detector energy resolution effects. The summed energy peak in the initial data run for a 99mTc source has a FWHM energy resolution of 33 keV, primarily due to energy uncertainty in the SPRINT modules. A second data run showed an improvement to 25 keV in summed energy resolution due to careful calibration of, and correction for, significant first and second detector gain non-uniformities. Images generated from the second acquired data set result in a backprojection image resolution of 1.5 cm at a source distance of 10 cm. Analytical and Monte Carlo calculations show a very close agreement of 1.6 cm. Using a list-mode maximum likelihood EM reconstruction algorithm, the image resolution is improved to 7 mm, although the resolution recovery is at the expense of increased noise in the image. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computerized tomography; Doppler effect; Image reconstruction; Maximum likelihood estimation; Monte Carlo methods; Phosphors; Photomultipliers; Silicon sensors; Sodium compounds; Storage rings; Compton camera; Single photon ring tomograph; X ray cameras

Abstract: This paper presents feasible performance of digitally-controlled three-level three-phase voltage source soft switching inverter with two Auxiliary Resonant DC link snubbers which can operate under a condition of Zero Voltage Switching (ZVS). The operating principle of this inverter topology is suitable for high power energy storage utilization system is discussed as compared with two-level soft switching inverter. Abstract: Atlas is a pulsed-power facility under development at Los Alamos National Laboratory to drive high-energy density experiments. Design has been completed for this new generation pulsed-power machine consisting of an azimuthal array of 24, 240-kV Marx modules and transmission lines supplying current to the load region at the machine center. Testing is in progress on some prototype and first article components to verify performance before production begins on critical system components. Production will soon begin for much of the overall system, including the Marx tanks, tri-plate tanks, support structure, some transition components, and the personnel platform.
Index Keywords: Electric cables; Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Electric power system protection; Marx modules; Electric power systems

Authors: Sohn Chang W., Fuchs Jerry, Gruber Michael
Title: Chilled water storage cooling system for an army installation
Affiliations: U.S. Army CERL, Champaign, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sohn, Chang W., U.S. Army CERL, Champaign, United States; Fuchs, Jerry, U.S. Army CERL, Champaign, United States; Gruber, Michael, U.S. Army CERL, Champaign, United States
Abstract: A 2.25 million gal (8,517 m3) chilled water storage cooling system for the Central Energy Plant (CEP) #2 at an Army installation has been in operation since May 1996. The installation has 10.4 million sq ft (0.97 million m2) of building space and services housing and offices for 28,000 population. A district cooling system with the CEP #2 covers more than half of the installation. During the first year of operation in 1996, the system shifted more than 3 MW of electrical demand from the on-peak to off-peak period. Electrical cost savings for the installation is calculated to be about $430,000 during the first year of operation. The system will pay back in less than 3 years for the net construction cost of $1,200,000. A second system is currently under design for another central energy plant (CEP #1)at the installation.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Energy efficiency; District cooling systems; Water cooling systems

Abstract: The Department of Energy's (DOE) National Spent Nuclear Fuel Program (NSNFP) is chartered with the responsibility for developing a transportation system for the various spent nuclear fuels owned by the Department. The proposed transportation system concept was designed to accommodate the standard canister developed by the NSNFP as well as spent fuels for commercial origin. DOE believes that the dimensions and specifications of the proposed system are within fractional percentages of the ultimate final design of the system.

Abstract: The paper presents an electricity generating system for remote, stand alone applications, which utilizes a draught animal as the primary energy source. The features of a prototype generating system, comprising of a mechanical speed multiplier and a permanent magnet generator, are described. Preliminary results indicate that a minimum continuous power output of 200 W can be obtained.

Abstract: In this paper finite element steady state thermal analysis of the axially laminated synchronous reluctance motor was described in detail. Abstract: This paper covers experimental methods required to determine low power losses in the presence of large reactive powers as encountered in reactive energy storage components. Thermally controlled in-situ experiments are performed at different frequencies to determine the frequency dependent losses in the inductor.

Abstract: A large family of pulsed rotating generators combine very efficient kinetic energy storage with fast discharge capabilities and provide power for robotic actuators, undersea robotic operations and other applications. The electromagnetic and the electrodynamics of such power supplies are outlined, along with the expedient and efficient methods of modeling, analysis and design in fast discharging electromechanical systems.

Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xing, Kun, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Guo, Jinghong, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Huang, Wenkang, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Peng, Dengming, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Lee, Fred C., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Borojevic, Dusan, Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: In a distributed power system with many power converters on the dc bus, there is always a concern of the possible interactions between the system building blocks, which are designed at the individual box level. This paper presents a novel concept, the dc bus conditioner, which compensates the harmonic and reactive current on the dc bus and actively damps the oscillations in dc power system. With a certain amount of extra energy storage, the bus conditioner can provide the large signal variable frequency ripple current as required by the load and actively shape the small signal impedance characteristics of the dc bus interface at the mid-frequency range to increase the system stability margin. The breadboard experimental results are presented.
Index Keywords: Busbars; Circuit oscillations; Electric currents; Electric impedance; Electric loads; Power converters; Bus conditioner; Distributed power system; Electric power systems

Title: Method to charge and discharge high current energy storage coils

Abstract: When inductive energy storage devices are used in high current applications, low ohmic switches are needed. These switches are often mechanical and even superconducting switches may be used in future. These switches are usually slow and sensitive for over voltage and therefore they need a commutation circuit to connect and disconnect the source and load from the inductive energy storage device. A generic commutation circuit is proposed and implemented on a 50 kA discharge module. Experimental results are presented of a system which uses eight of these modules in parallel in a 300 kA pulsed magnetic field application.

Abstract: Many industrial plants rely on Adjustable Speed Drives (ASD) for critical applications. However, most are susceptible to power disturbances, especially voltage sags and momentary interruptions. ASD tripping in process industries can be very costly due to loss of product as well as production down time. This paper presents a 100 kW, 5-second ride-through system (RTS) for ASDs using Ultracapacitors for energy storage.

Authors: Akagi Hirofumi, Ogasawara Satoshi, Kim Hyosung
Title: Theory of instantaneous power in the three-phase four-wire systems: a comprehensive approach
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Okayama Univ, Okayama City, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akagi, Hirofumi, Okayama Univ, Okayama City, Japan; Ogasawara, Satoshi, Okayama Univ, Okayama City, Japan; Kim, Hyosung, Okayama Univ, Okayama City, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a holistic approach to the theory of instantaneous power in three-phase four-wire systems, focusing on the original theory created in 1983 and a modified theory presented in 1994. The two theories are perfectly identical if no zero-sequence voltage is included in a three-phase three-wire system. However, they are different in the instantaneous active and reactive power in each phase if a zero-sequence voltage and current are included in a three-phase four-wire system. Theory and computer simulations in this paper lead to the following conclusions: An active filter without energy storage components can fully compensate for the neutral current even in a three-phase four-wire system including a zero-sequence voltage and current, when a proposed control strategy based on the original theory is applied. However, the active filter cannot compensate for the neutral current fully, when an already-proposed control strategy based on the modified theory is applied.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric filters; Electric potential; Electric wire; Electric wiring; Power supply circuits; Three phase four wire systems; Zero sequence voltage; Electric power systems

Authors: Ovshinsky S.R.
Title: Amorphous and disordered materials - the basis of new industries
Affiliations: Energy Conversion Devices, Inc., Troy, MI 48084, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ovshinsky, S.R., Energy Conversion Devices, Inc., Troy, MI 48084, United States
Abstract: As in the past, materials will shape the new century. Dramatic changes are taking place in the fields of energy and information based on new synthetic materials. In energy, the generation of electricity by amorphous silicon alloy thin film photovoltaics; the storage of electricity in nickel metal hydride batteries which are the batteries of choice for electric and hybrid vehicles. In the information field, phase change memories based on a reversible amorphous to crystalline transformation are widely used as optical memories and are the choice for the new rewritable CDs and DVDs. The scientific and technological bases for these three fields that have become the enabling technologies are amorphous and disordered materials. We will discuss how disordered, multielemental, multiphase materials can throw new light upon metallic conductivity in both bulk and thin film materials. We will demonstrate new types of amorphous devices that have the ability to learn and adapt, making possible new concepts for computers.
Index Keywords: Electric conductivity of solids; Industrial engineering; Synthesis (chemical); Thin films; Disordered materials; Nickel metal hydride batteries; Metallic glass

Authors: van Dijk E., Ferreira J.A., van Gelder P.
Title: Current sharing between diode clamps of polar capacitor bank
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Directorate Material Royal, Netherlands Navy, Hague, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van Dijk, E., Directorate Material Royal, Netherlands Navy, Hague, Netherlands; Ferreira, J.A., Directorate Material Royal, Netherlands Navy, Hague, Netherlands; van Gelder, P., Directorate Material Royal, Netherlands Navy, Hague, Netherlands
Abstract: The layout of a capacitor bank with clamping diodes is investigated based on an experimental 5.5 kJ energy storage unit for pulse power applications. While the current sharing between parallel connected capacitors is good, it is not the case with parallel connected clamping diodes. Despite a very low inductance busbar and attention to symmetrical layout, unequal current sharing results. Good agreement was obtained between measured waveforms and a detailed simulation model. The simulation model indicated that the unequal current sharing is due to small differences between the coupling factors of capacitors batteries at the ends and the middle of the bank. It is concluded that the best solution is to place the parallel diodes as close as possible to each other at a position where best averaged coupling is achieved with the individual capacitors of the bank.
Index Keywords: Current sharing; Diode clamps; Polar capacitor bank; Pulse converter; Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Diodes; Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electrolytic capacitors; Thyristors; Integrated circuit layout

Abstract: In this paper, a general powerful circuit of a universal custom power conditioner (UCPC), which is used to improve power reliability and quality applied to distribution networks, is presented in detail. UCPC is based on series and shunt tri-level PWM converters with a battery energy storage system (BESS) for multi-function operations such as harmonic elimination, reactive power control, voltage sags compensation and uninterruptible power supply (UPS). The basic algorithm of system is deadbeat control with repetitive compensation strategy based on voltage space vector PWM method. Some simulation results are use to verify that UCPC can synthetically fulfill different compensation functions.

Authors: Irrera F., Russo F.
Title: Enhanced injection in n -poly/SiO/SiC/p-Sub MOS capacitors for low-voltage nonvolatile memory applications: experiment

Authors with affiliations: Irrera, F., Dipartimento di Ingegneria Elettronica, Università La Sapienza, di Roma, Italy, Texas Instruments, Avezzano (AQ), Italy; Russo, F., Dipartimento di Ingegneria Elettronica, Università La Sapienza, di Roma, Italy, Micron Technology, Avezzano (AQ), Italy
Abstract: In this paper, n-4-poly/SiOz/SiCh/p-sub capacitors with enhanced electron injection under substrate accumulation are extensively studied. First, systematic investigation of the role of technology parameters in the PECVD deposition of the SiOj; films is presented. In particular, the effect of the silane dilution parameter on the device performance is investigated and the SiOz film optimized in terms of reliability and electron injection enhancement. Then, investigation of the electrical behavior of n++-poly/SiOi;/SiO2/p-sub MOS capacitors is presented. As a result, a picture of the space defect distribution in the SiO-4 films is proposed. In SiO-4 films, a relevant density of trapped charge adds to ionized impurities. In particular, the net charge is negative in the bulk of the dielectric, indicating that trapped electrons exceed all the other charge contributions. The space distribution of defects is strongly nonuniform and has the maximum in the vicinity of the SiO-4/SiCh interface. After dc current stress, the devices undergo electrical degradation, the dominant mechanism of degradation being the creation of interface hole traps. The trap generation model is based on the release of hydrogen and pairs generation in the SiO-4 films. The time-scale of trap filling during the stress is tens of seconds, which suggests that the stress-induced traps are deep in the energy gap. © 1999 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Charge injection; Mos devices; Nonvolatile memory; Semiconductor device reliability; Stress measurements; Tunneling
Index Keywords: Electron tunneling; Nonvolatile storage; Plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition; Silica; Stress analysis; Semiconductor device reliability; MOS capacitors

Authors: Choi P., Lunney J.G., Engel A., Dumitrescu C., Hansen T.N., Krisch I., Larour J., Rous J.
Title: 1013 A/s high energy density micro discharge radiation source
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Choi, P., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Lunney, J.G., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Engel, A., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Dumitrescu, C., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Hansen, T.N., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Krisch, I., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Larour, J., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Rous, J., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: The creation of a high brightness high energy density discharge based radiation source relies on a rapid delivery of electrical energy to a self contained plasma. Different types of pinch discharges have been studied in the past which produce localized regions of ultra-high energy density plasmas in the form of hot spots and micro pinches. These plasma features are not routinely reproducible in space and time. In this paper, we present a novel scheme for the production of a high energy density plasma based on a high current microcapillary discharge with effective source dimension of below 100 μm in diameter and in length. The discharge is created directly in a structure in the energy storage dielectric, resulting in a discharge inductance of less than 1 nH. In this way, a peak current of 10 kA with a rise time of 1013 A-s-1 at the micro capillary discharge is achieved with an energy storage of 0.2 J on the capacitor. Experimental investigation on the plasma parameters and the influence of different capillary materials are presented. Results show that a kT = 100 eV and ne = 1019 cm-3 plasma is formed emitting a 5 ns radiation pulse down to the soft X-ray region and fast ions of 8-10 keV due to free expansion.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electromagnetic wave emission; Ions; Pinch effect; Plasma density; X rays; Microcapillary discharges; Pinch discharges; Plasma sources

Authors: Weck W., Biebach J., Ehrhart P., Mueller A., Reiner G.
Title: Power supply system for ETC type launchers - demonstration of laboratory set-up
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weck, W., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany; Biebach, J., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany; Ehrhart, P., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany; Mueller, A., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany; Reiner, G., Magnet-Motor GmbH, Starnberg, Germany
Abstract: Future electric weapons in mobile applications will require pulsed power supplies with very high values of energy as well as power at the lowest possible volume and mass. As there are hardly any energy storage elements that can meet both requirements, high energy density and power density at the same time, a power supply system is presented that consists of two subsystems: - The Magnetodynamic Storage (MDS), a flywheel type storage unit, as an intermediate storage buffer - and a superconducting inductive energy storage system with superconducting opening switches as the pulsed power unit. The components of a current experimental set-up consisting of a 21 MJ/0.5 MW MDS unit and a 0.5 MJ/100 MW superconducting storage system are presented and the function principle is described. The system performance is demonstrated by results of laboratory experiments. Especially interesting is the fact that sequential discharge of the superconducting coil modules can be used for optimized pulse shaping according to the respective application.
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; Magnetohydrodynamic converters; Ordnance; Pulse shaping circuits; Superconducting devices; Electric weapons; Electro-thermal-chemical launchers; Magnetohydrodynamic storage (MDS); Pulse generators

Authors: Morton D.K., Ware A.G., Rahl T.E., Snow S.D., Smith N.L.
Title: Development of the standardized DOE spent nuclear fuel canister design and preliminary design specification
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States

Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Ware, A.G., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Rahl, T.E., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Snow, S.D., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States; Smith, N.L., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technol. Co., Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., P.O. Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-3760, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) has developed a set of standard canisters for the handling, interim storage, transportation, and disposal in the national repository of DOE spent nuclear fuel (SNF). The Department's National Spent Nuclear Fuel Program (NSNFP) and Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) worked together along with DOE sites to develop the canister design. The standardized DOE SNF canister had to be capable of handling virtually all of the DOE SNF in a variety of potential storage and transportation systems and also be acceptable to the repository, based on current and anticipated future requirements. Since specific design details regarding storage, transportation, and repository disposal of DOE SNF are not yet finalized, the NSNFP recognized that it was necessary to specify a complete DOE SNF canister design. This design had to be flexible enough to be incorporated into various storage and transportation systems and yet standardized so that the canister would be acceptable to the repository for disposal. This paper discusses the efforts taken to gain DOE complex consensus, the reasons for various design decisions, the steps taken to demonstrate the robustness of the proposed canister design, and other insights associated with the development of the standardized DOE SNF canister design and the preliminary design specification.
Index Keywords: Materials handling; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Specifications; Spent fuels; Standards; Structural design; Spent fuel canisters; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Hawkins John M., Robbins Tim
Title: Vanadium energy storage system concepts for telecommunications applications
Affiliations: Telepower Australia Pty Ltd, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Hawkins, John M., Telepower Australia Pty Ltd, Australia; Robbins, Tim, Telepower Australia Pty Ltd, Australia
Abstract: The Vanadium Redox Battery (VRB) is a flow battery technology that has technical performance characteristics which are attractive for a number of industrial energy storage applications, including diesel-abatement concepts in Remote Area Power Supply (RAPS) applications, standby power plant, medium and large-scale grid-connected load-leveling, and distributed power conditioning. VRB technology is currently undergoing commercialization. The VRB exhibits considerable cost competitiveness against many conventional energy storage technologies, and has a number of unique design attributes well suited for applications within telecommunications powering infrastructure. This paper describes concepts to integrate the basic VRB into a new and unique energy storage technology - the Vanadium Energy Storage System (VESS) - for use in telecommunications powering applications.
Index Keywords: Distributed power conditioning; Remote area power supply; Vanadium energy storage system; Vanadium redox battery; Electric batteries; Electrolytes; Power plants; Standby power systems; Telecommunication systems; Vanadium; Energy storage

Authors: Baker Keith, Gronthoud Guido, Lousberg Maurice, Schanstra Ivo, Hawkins Charles
