Abstract: This defect-based study analyzes statistical signal delay properties and delay fault test pattern constraints in the CMOS deep submicron environment. Delay fault testing has uncertainty, or noise, in its attempt to detect defects that slow a signal. CMOS resistive vias and contacts were used as a delay defect target. Data were taken from a scan-based test chip (Veqtor) on the Philips 0.25 μm technology. Methods to improve delay fault defect detection are given.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Data storage equipment; Energy gap; Failure analysis; Linear integrated circuits; Logic gates; Microprocessor chips; Oscillators (electronic); Quality assurance; Defect based delay testing; Resistive vias contacts; Scan based test chip; Integrated circuit testing

Authors: Malek Chantal Khan, Saile Volker
Title: Application domains for synchrotron radiation sources of various energies
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malek, Chantal Khan, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States; Saile, Volker, Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation, its production and some applications are presented with special regards to the main characteristics needed by most users and the various options for generating synchrotron light from bending magnets, undulators, and wigglers. In parallel to the development of various generations of increasingly powerful synchrotron light sources, compact and simply designed synchrotrons have been built for maximum x-ray output and uptime for industrial use or as smaller regional facilities. The use of synchrotron radiation for industry-related applications has increased continuously during the past 10 years and the demands in some fields like x-ray protein crystallography are expected to grow dramatically.
Index Keywords: Crystallography; Storage rings; X rays; X ray protein crystallography; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: de Cervens D.Rubin, Marret J.P.
Title: Energy bank of `LASER MEGAJOULE' CEA project
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Commissariat a l`Energie Atomique, Bruyeres le Chatel, France
Authors with affiliations: de Cervens, D.Rubin, Commissariat a l`Energie Atomique, Bruyeres le Chatel, France; Marret, J.P., Commissariat a l`Energie Atomique, Bruyeres le Chatel, France
Abstract: CEA decided to realize the MEGAJOULE LASER (LMJ) in two steps. In a first time, one laser chain will be built in the `Ligne d'Integration Laser' (LIL) at CEA-CESTA. The LIL will allow components qualification before the realization of the thirty laser chains for the MEGAJOULE LASER. CEA has consulted four companies to carry out the LMJ Energy Bank. THOMSON-CSF DETEXIS has been chosen by CEA to realize a 450 MJ energy bank. The contract of LMJ Energy Bank realization gives the complete result responsibility to THOMSON-CSF, according to CEA specifications. CEA gave THOMSON-CSF the results of a three years LIMEIL Laboratory experimentation on several components, like power supply, capacitors, resistors, high energy switches and cabling system studies.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric cables; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; High energy lasers; Resistors; Specifications; Megajoule laser; Electric energy storage

Authors: Hovingh J., Keeton S.C.
Title: Treatment of content heat generation in radioactive material (RAM) transportation packages
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hovingh, J., Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Keeton, S.C., Fission Ener. and Syst. Safety Prog., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: The content radionuclide decay heat loads of most radioactive material (RAM) transportation packages are assumed to be deposited in the contents. However, some of the long-range decay product energy from spent fuel is deposited external to the spent fuel. The energy that escapes the contents is usually deposited in the shield material surrounding the content containment vessel of the transportation packages. The maximum temperatures occur in the package when all the decay heat is deposited within the contents. This paper examines the effects of the deposition of a portion of the decay heat external to the contents on the peak temperatures in the package. For realistic decay heat fractions that escape the contents, and realistically large energy attenuation coefficients of the shield material, the peak temperatures are only slightly smaller than those computed based on the assumption that all the decay heat is deposited in the contents.
Index Keywords: Containers; Radioactive waste transportation; Radioisotopes; Spent fuels; Thermal stress; Spent nuclear fuel storage casks; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Sterzelmeier K., Buderer G., Gauthier-Blum C., Wenning W.
Title: Electromagnetic armor test facility with modular pulsed power conceptual design
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: French-German Research Inst of, Saint-Louis, Saint Louis, France
Authors with affiliations: Sterzelmeier, K., French-German Research Inst of, Saint-Louis, Saint Louis, France; Buderer, G., French-German Research Inst of, Saint-Louis, Saint Louis, France; Gauthier-Blum, C., French-German Research Inst of, Saint-Louis, Saint Louis, France; Wenning, W., French-German Research Inst of, Saint-Louis, Saint Louis, France
Abstract: The impulsive acceleration of protective devices or terminal ballistics interception elements like massive armor plates can only be realized by two means of propulsion: chemical stored energy such as high explosives or other propellants and electric power which is converted preferably into kinetic energy by single-stage launcher assemblies like pancake coil systems. This kind of propulsion has been used for more than 12 years at ISL in the field of active armor. Furthermore, the electric launcher technology with controlled multipartite single-stage coil assemblies represents a new supplementary topic with a high growth potential which is not yet exhausted. A separate test facility with modular structured energy packs (3×50 kJ) has been assembled as a basic installation for testing reinforced or armoured coils and multiple-coil systems. The presented paper describes the typical ratings of the energy packs and the modular conceptual design for a steerable two-dimensional launcher system.
Index Keywords: Ballistics; Electric coils; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Electromagnetic armor tests; Electric equipment protection

Authors: Fridman B.E., Kustov N.N., Lex A.G., Makarevich I.P., Rutberg Ph.G.
Title: Electrodynamic installation for compression of solid substances
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fridman, B.E., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kustov, N.N., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Lex, A.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Makarevich, I.P., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, Ph.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The installation for the z-pinch compression of solid substances up to 10 GPa pressure of 40-100 microseconds time duration is described in a paper. The installation is connected to the terminal of the E7-25 type Capacitive Energy Store and it is designed for 10 MA current pulse with 20 kV voltage. The features and structure of experimental installation are described. It is shown that the large axial forces act on the discharge chamber, when the heavy pulse current passes through the chamber's elements. The design of the installation provides the creation of initial squeezing forces in the contact connections of the discharge chamber and the absorption of kinetic energy of the chamber moving after the pulse current passing. With the purpose of restriction of overheating and electrical explosion of researching samples the device for the switching of discharge current from the sample to the low-inductance shunting circuit is included in the structure of the installation. The result of tests with currents up to 6 MA is submitted, as well as experimental data about the allowable current density in contact connections between electrodes and researching sample are given. The result of the first experimental researches is described also.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Current density; Electric discharges; Electric network synthesis; Electrodes; Pinch effect; Discharge chambers; Shunting circuits; Electrodynamics

Authors: Ingalls W., Prichard Jr. B., Sander O., Stelzer J., Stevens Jr. R., Wieting J., Zaugg T., Keller R., Leung K., Williams M.
Title: Status of the H- injector development program at LANSCE
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: LANL, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ingalls, W., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Prichard Jr., B., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Sander, O., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Stelzer, J., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Stevens Jr., R., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Wieting, J., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Zaugg, T., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Keller, R., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Leung, K., LANL, Los Alamos, United States; Williams, M., LANL, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The H- injector at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) is being upgraded to provide a 12% duty-factor, 40-mA, 80-key H- beams, which will enable 200-μA operation of the Los Alamos Neutron Scattering Center (LANSCE) proton storage ring (PSR). An improved version of the LANSCE operational surface-conversion ion source and a new accelerating column have been developed in collaboration with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL) for this application. We report here the results of the initial tests at LANL on a proof-of-principle (POP) ion source built at LBNL and on modeling studies. The POP ion source has been operated at the 40-mA design beam current, and the beam emittance of the 80-keV extracted beam has been measured both at the exit of the accelerating column and in the 80-keV low-energy beam transport (LEBT) line. Significant, current-dependent, emittance growth was observed in the LEBT. Experimental investigations of this growth are described.
Index Keywords: Ion sources; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Low energy beam transport (LEBT) line; Proof-of-principle (POP) ion sources; Storage rings

Authors: Biagini M.E., Biscari C., Ghigo A., Guiducci S., Mazzitelli G., Milardi C., Preger M.A., Sannibale F., Serio M., Vignola G., Zobov M., Boscolo M., Shatilov D.
Title: Optimization of DAΦNE beam-beam performance
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Biagini, M.E., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Biscari, C., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Ghigo, A., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Guiducci, S., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Mazzitelli, G., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Milardi, C., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Preger, M.A., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Sannibale, F., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Serio, M., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Vignola, G., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Zobov, M., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Boscolo, M., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Shatilov, D., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy
Abstract: The Φ-factory DAΦNE is an electron-positron collider with a design luminosity of 5.2*1032 cm-2 s-1 at the energy of the Φ-resonance (1020 MeV c.m.). In order to achieve the design luminosity high current multibunch electron and positron beams are stored in two separate rings and collide in two common interaction regions. Since the beams arrive at the interaction points from the different rings, a careful longitudinal timing and precise transverse scan of the colliding bunches are necessary to optimize the collider luminosity. In this paper we describe luminosity measurement techniques adopted in DAΦNE, discuss measures aimed at maximizing the luminosity in the beam-beam collisions and report the achieved results. The experimental data are compared with the results of numerical simulations.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electron beams; Optimization; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Storage rings; Beam-beam collisions; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Nadji A., Laclare J.-L., Level M.-P., Mosnier A., Nghiem P., Flynn G.
Title: Effect of nonlinear synchrotron motion on the SOLEIL energy acceptance
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Nadji, A., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Laclare, J.-L., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Level, M.-P., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Mosnier, A., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Nghiem, P., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Flynn, G., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France
Abstract: The lengthening of the trajectory is determined by the momentum compaction factor α and the betatron oscillation contribution term ΔC/C0. When the first order term of the momentum compaction factor α1 is small, the second order term α2 and ΔC/C0 have to be included in the longitudinal equations of motion. In this case, the RF bucket form changes and the energy acceptance can be significantly reduced. This leads to a decrease in Touschek beam lifetime. In this paper we show that the value of α2 in the standard low emittance lattice of SOLEIL is large and can reduce the energy acceptance of the machine. We discuss the magnitude of this reduction and the difficulties encountered in minimizing the value of α2 in the case of a low emittance lattice. We also show that the lengthening of the trajectory induced by horizontal and vertical betatron oscillations vanishes when the chromaticities are corrected to zero.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Equations of motion; Oscillations; Particle beam dynamics; Synchrotrons; Betatron oscillations; Storage rings

Authors: Pan Yonggang, Xia Zhongfu, Zhang Xiaoqin, Zhang Yewen
Title: Charge storage characteristic for double layer of Si3N4/SiO2 and single layer of Si3N4
Affiliations: Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Pan, Yonggang, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Xia, Zhongfu, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Zhang, Xiaoqin, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China; Zhang, Yewen, Tongji Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: The charge storage properties of amorphous silicon nitride (Si3N4) film deposited by LPCVD on silicon substrate and double layer of Si3N4/SiO2 on silicon substrate have been investigated. Because the double layer of Si3N4/SiO2 has more outstanding charge storage stability than single layer silicon dioxide, so people are very interested in the charge storage mechanism of Si3N4/SiO2. In this paper, a revised formula for calculating the mean charge depth of the double layer system for inorganic dielectric films was introduced based on Guenther and Sessler's method [1]. Space charge storage characteristic, the shift of the mean charge depth under the different conditions were investigated by means of corona charging, TSD (Thermal Stimulated Discharge), Capacitance-Voltage (C-V) analysis method and chemical surface modification, etc.
Index Keywords: Chemical vapor deposition; Dielectric films; Dielectric properties; Electric corona; Electric energy storage; Electric variables measurement; Oxidation; Silica; Silicon nitride; Silicon wafers; Surface treatment; Temperature; Amorphous silicon nitride film; Capacitance voltage analysis method; Corona charging; Double layer system; Inorganic dielectric films; Mean charge depth; Space charge storage characteristic; Surface potential decay measurement; Thermal stimulated discharge; Electric space charge

Authors: Hardekopf R.A., Stout D.S., Sutton T.D.
Title: Project status of the 1-GeV SNS linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hardekopf, R.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Stout, D.S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Sutton, T.D., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy has initiated construction of a $1.3 B Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) to be located at Oak Ridge, Tennessee. Five national laboratories, ANL, BNL, LANL, LBNL, and ORNL are collaborating in the design and construction of this major new U.S. neutron science facility. The present design is a 60-Hz, 1-GeV H- linac injecting into an accumulator ring to produce pulses of <1-μs on the neutron-producing target. The accelerator design has been refined from the CDR concept to provide improvements in assembly and maintainability. A converter-modulator design using IGBT technology replaces the conventional RF system to power the accelerating cavities. Cost estimates for the linac have utilized both accelerator modeling codes and more conventional cost-estimating approaches. Comparison of these two methods has led to increased confidence in the linac cost estimate of about $300 M (including R&D and controls but without contingency). A Monte-Carlo simulation of the project cost using risk-based analysis has further contributed to the estimate and identified critical areas. The project uses Primavera Project Planner as the scheduling software. A linac R&D program to develop key technologies is underway at Los Alamos.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Computer simulation; Cost benefit analysis; Gates (transistor); Monte Carlo methods; Neutron sources; Particle beam injection; Risk assessment; Storage rings; Targets; Accumulator rings; Insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT); Particle injectors; Spallation neutron sources (SNS); Linear accelerators

Authors: Mosnier A.
Title: Cures of coupled bunch instabilities
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SOLEIL, Gif/Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Mosnier, A., SOLEIL, Gif/Yvette, France
Abstract: To achieve the desired luminosities and brilliances in future storage rings for colliders and synchrotron light sources, very large beam currents need to be stored in many tightly spaced bunches. A serious limitation of the performances comes then from the conventional coupled bunch instabilities (CBI). Energy oscillations and transverse oscillations are mainly driven by high-Q structures and the resistivity of the vacuum chamber. Control of these multibunch instabilities has become a critical issue and various strategies are considered to push up the instability thresholds: HOM frequency control to avoid the overlap of dangerous modes with beam spectrum, heavy mode damping to reduce the resonant buildup of the fields, Landau damping to destroy the coherence of the beam and lastly strong feedback systems operating either in the frequency or time domains. These different cures and their technological developments are reviewed in this short paper, more details can be found in [1].
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Frequency domain analysis; Synchrotrons; Time domain analysis; Coupled bunch instabilities (CBI); Storage rings

Authors: Steck M., Blasche K., Eickhoff H., Franczak B., Franzke B., Groening L., Winkler T.
Title: Improved performance of the GSI heavy ion accelerator complex with cooled synchrotron beams
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steck, M., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Blasche, K., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Eickhoff, H., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Franczak, B., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Franzke, B., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Groening, L., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Winkler, T., GSI Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Electron cooling at the injection energy of the heavy ion synchrotron SIS results in beam pulses of higher intensity and exceptional quality. The beam parameters after cooling have been measured and verify a reduction of the phase space volume by more than three orders of magnitude. Beam transfer of the cooled ion beam is much easier because of the reduced emittance. The time required to fill the storage ring ESR with highly charged ions has been reduced from minutes to seconds.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Ion beams; Particle beam injection; Phase space methods; Storage rings; Electron cooling systems; Synchrotrons

Authors: Wilson Robert D., Randall Russell R., Meisner James E., Boles Jason L., Reynolds Kent D.
Title: Moisture logging in cased boreholes using capture gamma-ray spectroscopy
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, Robert D., Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States; Randall, Russell R., Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States; Meisner, James E., Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States; Boles, Jason L., Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States; Reynolds, Kent D., Waste Management Federal Services, Inc, Richland, United States
Abstract: A nuclear logging tool has been developed that determines the moisture content of subsurface earth formations by measuring the gamma rays produced by thermal neutron capture in hydrogen. The tool employs a 252Cf fast neutron source and a hyperpure germanium gamma-ray detector. The tool has demonstrated excellent sensitivity to changes in formation moisture content when used in air-filled boreholes cased with steel. The tool is also sensitive to other elements the produce neutron capture gamma rays, such as silicon, calcium, aluminum, sodium, chlorine, chromium, cadmium and mercury. Extensive computer modeling of the tools has been done to aid in its design and in the interpretation of logging data taken under a variety of conditions. The logging tools has been calibrated for its moisture and chlorine response in a set of physical models and is now in use logging boreholes at the U. S. Department of Energy Hanford Site.
Index Keywords: Boreholes; Computer aided design; Computer simulation; Gamma rays; Moisture determination; Neutron logging; Neutron sources; Formation moisture content; High level radioactive liquid storage tanks; Moisture logging; Radiation detectors

Authors: Kortbawi D., Childers F.K., Price H.D.
Title: Testing of the MITL and POS for the Decade Quad
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Maxwell Physics Int, San Leandro, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kortbawi, D., Maxwell Physics Int, San Leandro, United States; Childers, F.K., Maxwell Physics Int, San Leandro, United States; Price, H.D., Maxwell Physics Int, San Leandro, United States
Abstract: The Decade Quad is a modular nuclear weapons effects simulator that uses an inductive energy store and operating switch as the final stage of pulse compression. Decade Module 2 (DM2) is used to test the final design of the magnetically insulated transmission line (MITL) and plasma opening switch (POS) for this system. This test showed improved operation of the POS compared to previous experiments and demonstrated as interesting effect of current asymmetry feeding the POS.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric switches; Magnetically insulated transmission lines (MITL); Modular nuclear weapons effects simulators; Plasma opening switches (POS); Plasma devices

Authors: Lisitsyn I.V., Inoue H., Katsuki S., Akiyama H., Nishizawa I.
Title: Drilling and demolition of rocks by pulsed power
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lisitsyn, I.V., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Inoue, H., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katsuki, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Akiyama, H., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Nishizawa, I., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: There are various methods of rock drilling and demolition. Recently, a method utilizing pulsed power technology has appeared. This method is based on the difference of the dynamic breakdown field strength of liquid and solid dielectrics. The applicability of this method was examined. The features of the rock destruction have been studied. The mechanism explaining the breakdown of the dielectrics with high intrinsic inhomogeneity like natural rocks and concrete is proposed and proved experimentally. Inductive energy storage - opening switch system for the destruction of solid materials is designed allowing higher destruction efficiency. The experimental results using advanced diagnostics such as image converter camera and x-ray computer tomography of samples are presented. High pulse energy experiments (up to 60 kJ in pulse) have been conducted.
Index Keywords: Demolition; Dielectric materials; Energy storage; Pulsed power; Rock drilling

Authors: Nara K., Hayashi Y.
Title: Solution algorithm based on multi-stage tabu search for nested combinatorial optimization problem
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nara, K., Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Hayashi, Y., Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, the authors propose a new solution algorithm to solve a combinatorial optimization problem which determines installation and operation of Dispersed Energy Storages and Generators (DSG) in the electrical power system. Since the problem to determine the installation of DSG includes a problem which determines the operation of DSG. In the solution algorithm, temporarily determining the installation of DSG by TS, the operation of DSG is also determined by TS. The proposed algorithm consists of nested use of TS which can obtain approximate optimal solutions for the both combinatorial optimization problems (installation and operation). To demonstrate the validity of the algorithm, several numerical results are shown.
Index Keywords: Dispersed energy storage and generators; Tabu search; Electric energy storage; Electric fault currents; Electric generators; Electric power systems; Installation; Optimization; Algorithms

Authors: Ware K., Gullickson R., Pierre J., Schneider R., Vitkovitsky I.
Title: Technologies for development of more affordable large X-ray simulators
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ware, K., Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States; Gullickson, R., Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States; Pierre, J., Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States; Schneider, R., Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States; Vitkovitsky, I., Defense Threat Reduction Agency, Alexandria, United States
Abstract: Pulsed power conditioning elements between the energy-storing capacitor banks and the radiation loads have been the major cost driver for large simulators. The cost is driven by the pulsed power requirements needed to provide the necessary spectral and temporal characteristics of the radiation output for Nuclear Weapons Effects Testing (NWET), as well as for assuring efficient production of the radiation. During the past forty years, the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) has developed pulsed power elements and systems that are lowering the cost of x-ray simulators. This paper discusses these technologies.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Pulse generators; X rays; Nuclear weapons effects testing (NWET); Pulsed power systems; X ray simulators; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Gao J.
Title: Cure for the energy spread increasing related bunch lengthening in electron storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: LAL, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Gao, J., LAL, Orsay, France
Abstract: Having revealed the cause of the energy spread increasing and the corresponding bunch lengthening in electron storage rings in ref. 1, in this paper, we will propose a cure for the suppression of these collective effects. It is suggested to install an active rf cavity in the ring with the working rf wavelength about four to five times the rms bunch length. The limitation about this cure is also discussed. Finally, in the postscript, we will give an empirical bunch lengthening equation and compare the analytical results with some experimental results.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Numerical analysis; Bunch lengthening; Storage rings

Authors: Kim Eun-San, Sessler Andrew M., Wurtele Jonathan S.
Title: Longitudinal instability in a 50 GeV×50 GeV muon collider ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Eun-San, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Sessler, Andrew M., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Wurtele, Jonathan S., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Simulations of the longitudinal dynamics in a 50 GeV×50 GeV muon collider ring have been performed. Operation of the ring close to the slippage factor η1≈10-6, such that synchrotron motion is frozen, minimizes the need for rf to maintain the bunch length. Without appropriate rf compensation, however, the bunch wake induces an intolerable head-to-tail energy spread. This paper demonstrates that the bunch wake may be compensated by two rf cavities with low rf voltages. With this rf setup the small energy spread of the beam (δE/E = 3×10-5) in the 50 GeV×50 GeV muon collider ring can ba maintained during the 1000 turn lifetime of the muons. These studies were made at the nominal design point, and sensitivities to errors were explored. The simulation also demonstrates that the computation of the wake field using bins of variable width (each with a constant number of macroparticles) accurately reproduces the wake and yields reduced computing time compared to the evaluation of the wake as the direct sum over the wakes of all preceding macroparticles.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Particle beam dynamics; Storage rings; Muon collider rings; Particle beam instabilities; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Frame B.J.
Title: Characterization and process development of cyanate ester resin composites
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frame, B.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Cyanate ester resins offer advantages as composite matrices because of their high thermal stability, low outgassing, low water absorption, and radiation resistance. This paper describes the results of a processing study to develop a high-strength hoop-wound composite by the wet-filament winding method using Toray T1000G carbon fiber and YLA RS-14A cyanate ester resin as the constituent materials. The study shows that the cyanate ester resin has a broad process envelope but that an inert-atmosphere cure is essential for obtaining optimum resin and composite properties. Minimizing moisture exposure prior to and during cure is also crucial as it affects the glass transition temperature of the resin and composite. Composite cylinders wound and cured with these methods yielded excellent ring tensile strengths both at room and elevated temperature. A summary of the measured mechanical and thermal property data for these composites is presented. Potential applications for these materials include flywheel energy storage systems for space and satellite structures.
Index Keywords: Carbon fibers; Curing; Glass transition; Mechanical properties; Moisture; Resins; Temperature; Tensile strength; Thermodynamic properties; Advanced composites; Cyanate ester resins; High strength hoop wound composite; Inert atmosphere cure; Wet filament winding method; Composite materials

Authors: Wu Hong J., Bhattacharya Surya, Krishnamurthy Shyam, Sharma Umesh
Title: MeV implantation introduced damage at the LOCOS bird's beak in 0.35 μm Flash Memory devices
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Ion Implantation Technology
Affiliations: Rockwell Semiconductor Systems, Newport Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Hong J., Rockwell Semiconductor Systems, Newport Beach, United States; Bhattacharya, Surya, Rockwell Semiconductor Systems, Newport Beach, United States; Krishnamurthy, Shyam, Rockwell Semiconductor Systems, Newport Beach, United States; Sharma, Umesh, Rockwell Semiconductor Systems, Newport Beach, United States
Abstract: This paper reports on the impact of high energy (MeV) retrograde well implants on the reliability of Flash Memory devices. These implants are shown to severely damage the oxide at the LOCOS bird's beak edge. The degree of SiO2 amorphization caused by the high-energy ion implantation is shown to be enhanced by the LOCOS structure. The amorphization causes accelerated oxide loss during subsequent oxide etch-backs. Both performance and reliability of Flash Memory cells is degraded due to this damage. We demonstrate a technique for reducing the implant induced damage and thereby improve device performance and reliability.
Index Keywords: Amorphization; Composition effects; Etching; Ion implantation; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; Semiconductor storage; Silica; Flash memory devices; Semiconducting silicon compounds

Authors: Dressler O., Feikes J.
Title: Operational experiences with the BESSY II injection system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BESSY, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dressler, O., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Feikes, J., BESSY, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: During the commissioning of the BESSY II storage ring, the highly and stable performance of the BESSY II injection system was a major support. The system consists of four identical kicker magnets, grouped symmetrically around the injection point and two septum magnets built into the same septum tank. Reliable performance was achieved at three different storage ring energies: 0.9, 1.7 and 1.9 GeV. Some specific observations which showed up in the routine operation of the system are reported.
Index Keywords: Particle beam injection; Reliability; Kicker magnets; Storage rings

Authors: Codner G., Dugan G., Lou W., Welch J.
Title: Quench protection for superconducting IR magnets in CESR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Codner, G., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Dugan, G., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Lou, W., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Welch, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: Analysis and design details are provided on quench protection for the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) Phase III interaction region (IR) superconducting magnets. The proposed scheme extracts much of the stored energy thereby reducing thermal stress on the magnets and mitigating liquid helium loss. Protection is somewhat complicated by the fact that each cold mass consists of quadrupole, skew quadrupole and dipole windings, and that each cryostat contains two magnet units.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electric windings; Electron ring accelerators; Quenching; Superconducting magnets; Thermal stress; Cornell electron storage rings (CESR); Quadrupole windings; Storage rings

Authors: Litvinenko V.N., Park S.H., Pinayev I.V., Wu Y., Emamian M., Hower N., Morcombe P., Oakeley O., Swift G., Wang P.
Title: Deep-UV operation of the OK-4/Duke storage ring FEL
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States
Authors with affiliations: Litvinenko, V.N., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Park, S.H., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Pinayev, I.V., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Wu, Y., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Emamian, M., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Hower, N., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Morcombe, P., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Oakeley, O., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Swift, G., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States; Wang, P., Duke Univ Durham, Durham, United States
Abstract: In this paper we present the result of the deep-UV lasing with the OK-4/Duke storage ring FEL. The OK-4 FEL was initially commissioned in the near-UV at Duke Free Electron Laboratory in November, 1996 followed by a year-long shutdown. After re-establishing the storage ring operation in early 1998, the OK-4 FEL lasing was demonstrated in the wavelength range of 217 to 256 nm in 1998. A number of lasing modes with electron energies ranging from 300 to 750 MeV have been established to accommodate application research. Starting September, 1998, the coherent deep-UV radiation is used for applications in cornea surgery, cell biology, surface physics, and nuclear physics. In this paper we report the results of the deep-UV lasing with the OK-4/Duke storage ring FEL as well as our plans to advance towards the VUV.
Index Keywords: Free electron lasers; Ultraviolet radiation; Deep ultraviolet lasers; Storage rings

Authors: Danilov V., Galambos J., Jeon D., Holmes J., Olsen D., Fitzgerald D., Macek R., Plum M.
Title: Integrable optics lens for the PSR and SNS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Danilov, V., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Galambos, J., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Jeon, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Holmes, J., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Olsen, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Fitzgerald, D., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Macek, R., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States; Plum, M., ORNL SNS Project, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: This is a study to increase the threshold of the Los Alamos LANSCE Proton Storage Ring (PSR) to the electron-proton (e-p) instability. The approach is to use a solenoid lens system to increase the Landau damping and betatron tune spread, without producing betatron resonances or energy spread that would necessitate increased aperture. This study rests upon the concept of integrable optics, which is a branch of Hamiltonian dynamics that determines how to modify dynamic systems to obtain integrable Hamiltonians having regular phase space maps and no chaos. For such cases, the particle trajectories, when integrated as functions of time and initial conditions, follow invariant surfaces. In essence, the maps are similar to linear maps with the addition of a betatron tune spread; however, the magnetic fields required to obtain such maps are complicated.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Damping; Particle optics; Electron-proton instability; Proton storage ring (PSR); Storage rings

Authors: Fratta A., Guglielmi P., Pellegrino G.M., Scapino F., Villata F.
Title: Efficient modulation technique and NL control of H-bridge boost converters for battery-supplied AC motor drives
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fratta, A., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Guglielmi, P., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Pellegrino, G.M., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Scapino, F., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Villata, F., Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
Abstract: Previous works have shown the design effectiveness of novel two-phase H-bridge dc-dc boost conversion in battery-supplied ac motor drives, increasing the exploitation of power components through dc-link voltage adaptation to ac load. In this work the highest performances of real-time voltage control are investigated, as needed to minimize the dc-link capacitor size and to allow for efficient dc voltage tracking of ac load need. New low-capacitance high-rms-current film power capacitors are adopted accordingly. Unusual power conversion performances are derived, as related to the very low-energy storage in both the dc-link capacitor and the peculiar coupling reactor. A new modulation strategy is also defined to exploit peculiar discontinuous current modes, thus minimizing power loss at light load for further improvement of EV city-drive autonomy. A novel non-linear complete control strategy is proposed to fulfill steady-state and transient performances by simple cheap realization. Outstanding performances have been obtained by the 30kW prototype converter, partially shown in the experimental report.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Capacitors; Pulse width modulation; Variable speed drives; Voltage control; Boost converters; Voltage supplied inverter; Electric inverters

Authors: Ogden J.M.
Title: Prospects for building a hydrogen energy infrastructure
Source title: Annual Review of Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Ctr. for Ener. and Environ. Studies, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ogden, J.M., Ctr. for Ener. and Environ. Studies, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Abstract: About two-thirds of primary energy today is used directly as transportation and heating fuels. Any discussion of energy-related issues, such as air pollution, global climate change, and energy supply security, raises the issue of future use of alternative fuels. Hydrogen offers large potential benefits in terms of reduced emissions of pollutants and greenhouse gases and diversified primary energy supply. Like electricity, hydrogen is a premium-quality energy carrier, which can be used with high efficiency and zero emissions. Hydrogen can be made from a variety of feedstocks, including natural gas, coal, biomass, wastes, solar sources, wind, or nuclear sources. Hydrogen vehicles, heating, and power systems have been technically demonstrated. Key hydrogen end-use technologies such as fuel cells are making rapid progress toward commercialization. If hydrogen were made from renewable or decarbonized fossil sources, it would be possible to have a large-scale energy system with essentially no emissions of pollutants or greenhouse gases. Despite these potential benefits, the development of a large-scale hydrogen energy infrastructure is often seen as an insurmountable technical and economic barrier. Here we review the current status of technologies for hydrogen production, storage, transmission, and distribution; describe likely areas for technological progress; and discuss the implications for developing hydrogen as an energy carrier.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Environmental protection; Fuel cells; Gas emissions; Greenhouse effect; Energy distribution; Energy transmission; Hydrogen fuels

Authors: Migliorati M., Palumbo L., Dattoli G., Mezi L.
Title: Saw tooth instability model in storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Rome, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Migliorati, M., Univ of Rome, Roma, Italy; Palumbo, L., Univ of Rome, Roma, Italy; Dattoli, G., Univ of Rome, Roma, Italy; Mezi, L., Univ of Rome, Roma, Italy
Abstract: The time evolution of the energy spread above the microwave instability threshold in a storage ring is described by means of two coupled non linear differential equations. The results are in agreement with a time domain simulation code. The model equations are combined to those accounting for the storage ring Free Electron Laser dynamics, in order to study the interplay between the FEL and the storage ring instability dynamics.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Differential equations; Free electron lasers; Mathematical models; Nonlinear equations; Time domain analysis; Saw tooth instability; Storage rings

Authors: Ieiri Takao, Obina Takashi
Title: Measurement of longitudinal instability threshold in the PF-AR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ieiri, Takao, KEK, Ibaraki, Japan; Obina, Takashi, KEK, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: A single bunch longitudinal instability was experimentally investigated in the PF-AR under the condition that the number of cavity-cell which greatly contributed to longitudinal impedance was changed. The bunch length was measured as a function of the bunch current. Hysteresis phenomena in bunch lengthening process were discovered in the former condition of fully installed cavities. The present condition of reduced cavity-cells to 3/4 indicated an abrupt increase of the bunch length together with the energy spread at a bunch current. The instability threshold current was measured as a function of the bunch length. Measured results are consistent with Oide's criterion.
Index Keywords: Electric current measurement; Functions; Hysteresis; Instability threshold current; Storage rings

Authors: Bhardwaj R.C.
Title: Repetitive pulse power characteristics of batteries made with thin metal film (TMF) technology
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: BOLDER Technologies Corp, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhardwaj, R.C., BOLDER Technologies Corp, Golden, United States
Abstract: Energy storage devices for pulse-power applications must be able to deliver a high current for significant periods of time with a stable voltage. The time response must be very rapid and the waveform voltage distortion must be minimal. Most energy storage devices such as super-capacitors and conventional batteries suffer with several drawbacks, which include dropping voltage during discharge, low in specific energy, expensive for most applications, or are under development stage. The ideal candidate for pulse power would be an energy-storage device capable of delivering extremely high currents with good voltage performance and rapid recharge capability without temperature excursion. BOLDER Technologies Corporation (BOLDER) has developed an ultra-thin plate, valve-regulated, lead-acid battery based on their patented TMF technology that meets or exceeds many of the above requirements. In addition to being valve regulated, it differs from conventional lead acid batteries in that it has been developed primarily to deliver and accept extremely high-power levels without significant increase in temperature. The purpose of this paper is to present pulse power delivery characteristics of TMF technology. The repetitive pulse-power characteristic from 1 A to 1000 A along with temperature profiles of single cell and 12 V battery will be presented in this paper representing applications such as engine start, power tools, flash camera, and other portable devices.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Metallic films; Thin films; Lead acid battery; Thin metal film (TMF); Electric batteries

Authors: Holmes P.A.
Title: High integrity can design for degraded nuclear fuel
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Idaho Technologies, Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., PO Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-5106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holmes, P.A., Lockheed Martin Idaho Technologies, Idaho Natl. Eng. and Environ. Lab., PO Box 1625, Idaho Falls, ID 83415-5106, United States
Abstract: A high integrity can (HIC), designed to meet the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code (Section III, Div. 3, static conditions) is proposed for the interim storage and repository disposal of Department of Energy (DOE) spent nuclear fuel. The HIC will be approximately 5 3/8 inches (134.38 mm) in outside diameter with 1/4 inch (6.35 mm) thick walls, and have a removable lid with a metallic seal that is capable of being welded shut. The opening of the can is approximately 4 3/8 inches (111.13 mm). The HIC is primarily designed to contain items in the DOE SNF inventory that do not meet acceptance standards for direct disposal in a geologic repository. This includes fuel in the form of particulate dusts, sectioned pieces of fuel, core rubble, melted or degraded (non-intact) fuel elements, unclad uranium alloys, metallurgical specimens, and chemically reactive fuel components. The HIC is intended to act as a substitute cladding for the spent nuclear fuel, further isolate problematic materials, provide a long-term corrosion barrier, and add an extra internal pressure barrier to the waste package. The HIC will also delay potential fission product release and maintain geometry control for extended periods of time. For the entire disposal package to be licensed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a HIC must effectively eliminate the disposal problems associated with problem SNF including the release of radioactive and/or reactive material and over pressurization of the HIC due to chemical reactions within the can. Two HICs were analyzed to envelop a range of can lengths between 42 and 101 inches. Using Abacus software, the HIC's were analyzed for end, side, and corner drops. Hastelloy C-22 was chosen based upon structural integrity, corrosion resistance, and neutron absorption properties.
Index Keywords: Computer aided analysis; Computer software; Geological repositories; Radioactive waste disposal; Spent fuels; Standards; Structural analysis; High integrity cans (HIC); Software package ABACUS; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Pokryvailo A., Maron V., Melnik D.
Title: Review of opening switches for long-charge fieldable inductive storage systems
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pokryvailo, A., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Maron, V., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Melnik, D., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: Opening switches (OS) applicable to fieldable inductive storage systems with long charge time of the inductor are reviewed. Main characteristics, required from the OS, are formulated. General requirements are reliable repetitive operation and compactness. For systems with a long charge time, e.g., for battery-based power supplies intended for driving electrothermal loads, typical parameters are fractions of a second conduction time, peak current of several tens of kA and the opening time less than 0.5 ms at a voltage of several kV. No off-the-shelf OS possessing such characteristics are available. Comparison of switches' types and architectures was made. It brought to a conclusion that the hybrid technology is appropriate for long-charge inductive storage. Mechanical switches, e.g., vacuum and SF6 circuit breakers, are suitable as the first stage, while a stack of semiconductor devices seems to be an optimal solution for the second stage of the OS. A novel approach allowing the enhancement of an order of magnitude of the turn-off capability of fully-controlled semiconductor devices, such as GTOs and GCTs, is offered. Preliminary test results are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric power systems; Power inductors; Long-charge fieldable inductive storage systems; Opening switches (OS); Electric switches

Authors: Divan Deepak, Brumsickle William E.
Title: Powering the next millennium with power electronics
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Soft Switching Technologies, Middleton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Divan, Deepak, Soft Switching Technologies, Middleton, United States; Brumsickle, William E., Soft Switching Technologies, Middleton, United States
Abstract: Reliable electrical power is a cornerstone of modern society. Power electronics is the key technology for enabling renewable power generation, steering power through the transmission and distribution network, dispatching distributed generation, and improving load-side efficiency. Looking forward we see photovoltaic arrays, with integrated converters and coupled energy storage devices, as a primary world-wide energy source. Although market and political forces will dictate the demand for power electronics, we can see several developing trends: Power quality correction devices will fill the gap between reliable bulk power and the reality of lower power quality on distribution systems. Voltage source inverters, now a commodity, will continue to be replaced by soft-switching inverters which inherently avoid the problems of EMI and dv/dt-caused motor damage. Modular soft-switching inverters will be tomorrow's building block, even for multi-megawatt inverters and rectifiers. The underlying trend will continue to be cost reduction through modular construction and increased manufacturing volume.
Index Keywords: Electric inverters; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Electromagnetic wave interference; Industrial applications; Power converters; Photovoltaic arrays; Power quality correction devices; Soft switching inverters; Voltage source inverters; Power electronics

Authors: Chen Jiann-Fuh, Chiang Luy-Yin, Chu Ching-Lung, Lee Yong-Lung, Liang Tsorng-Juu
Title: Study and implementation of the single-phase three-wire photovoltaic energy conversion system
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Jiann-Fuh, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Chiang, Luy-Yin, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Chu, Ching-Lung, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Lee, Yong-Lung, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Liang, Tsorng-Juu, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: A single-stage single-phase three-wire (1φ3W) photovoltaic energy conversion system connected with utility power system was presented in this paper. The DC power generated by the solar cells was converted into AC power by a 1φ3w inverter with an auxiliary LC filter and was fed directly to the utility line. Since the output characteristics of the solar cells were highly affected by the environment and lumen of sun, the PV energy conversion system was adapted to track the maximum power operation point. The size and weight of PV conversion system can be largely reduced without energy storage devices, dc to dc converter, and center-tapped transformer. Finally, a 1 kW experimental prototype was built to demonstrate the performance of the proposed technique.
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Electric filters; Electric inverters; Electric lines; Electric power systems; Performance; Power converters; Solar cell arrays; Energy storage devices; Photovoltaic energy conversion system; Solar cells

Authors: Livshiz Yuri, Gafri Oren
Title: Technology and equipment for industrial use of pulse magnetic fields
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Pulsar Ltd, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Livshiz, Yuri, Pulsar Ltd, Yavne, Israel; Gafri, Oren, Pulsar Ltd, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: The pulse magnetic method is used for assembling, welding, cutting, and forming the details of products in various branches of industry. Pulse magnetic industrial machines were developed and produced heaving energy storage 5, 10, 20, and 30 kJ, working voltages of 6, 10, and 25 kV, own frequency up to 100 kHz, and productivity of up to 400 pulse/hour. High vacuum switches, Ignitrons and low vacuum switches are used in the said machines. Also done were industrial pulse magnets that could work with fields up to 40-50 Tl and their design life is more than 30000 pulses with pulse repletion rates said above. Achieved were electrical connectors assembling of cross-sections up to 2000 mm sq., that tested to comply to existing press-made standards. Magnetic pulse welding of Cu-Al, Cu-St, and Al-St items was achieved as well, with part diameters of up to 100 mm and wall thickness up to 5 mm. The technology for pulse magnetic cut-out and perforation of items of a very elastic alloys, of thickness of about 0.2-0.3 mm and aperture of 1.5 mm were also done for industrial use.
Index Keywords: Cutting; Electric connectors; Electric switches; Forming; Vacuum technology; Welding; Pulse magnetic fields; Magnetic field effects

Authors: Scholz T., Winsor P., Hudis M.
Title: Development of a high energy density storage capacitor for NIF
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: AEROVOX, INC, New Bedford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scholz, T., AEROVOX, INC, New Bedford, United States; Winsor, P., AEROVOX, INC, New Bedford, United States; Hudis, M., AEROVOX, INC, New Bedford, United States
Abstract: The capacitor requirement of the National Ignition Facility (NIF) calls for 85 kJ energy discharge capacitors to be operated at 24 kVDC and 30,000 amps peak current per discharge, with 20,000 charge-discharge cycles as the design life. Metallized-Kraft (MK) OPP capacitors (Aerovox type KM) submitted for qualification have exceeded these requirements, but with energy density limited to 0.77 J/cc. Significant cost reductions can be had with the development of an increased energy density capacitor, however, increased energy density is obtained at the cost of life. Results to date for engineering development of a higher energy density capacitor is summarized in this paper. Several electrode-dielectric configurations were evaluated by fabrication and testing of miniature scale, single section, capacitors. From these trials, we selected an alternative approach employing a rough metallized polypropylene (MPP) dielectric system. This rough MPP dielectric-electrode system yields a >10% gain in energy density, which results in a substantial cost reduction over the qualification KM type. Validation of NIF capacitor requirements by comprehensive testing of 1/6-scale full voltage (24 kVDC) capacitors came close to meeting the required shot life. Engineering development is proceeding on a MK high energy density capacitor that can yield the same cost reduction.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric currents; Metallizing; Polypropylenes; High energy density storage capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Koval'chuk E.P., Skolozdra O.M.
Title: Magnesium primary batteries

Abstract: Polyaniline, aniline and o-NO2-aniline copolymer were synthesized using (NH4)2S2O8 as oxidant in 1 M HCl water solution. By means of IR, Raman spectroscopy, gravimetric and microanalysis it was confirmed that the obtained product is oxydized emeraldine. We developed Mg | 2 M MgCl2 (H2O + CH3) (3:1) | co-polymer (polyaniline) prismatic-type cells. The highest specific charge and energy were observed for cell with co-polymer AN:o-NO2-AN (8:2) which were 420.74 Ah kg-1 and 424.95 Wh kg-1, respectively.
Index Keywords: Ammonium compounds; Cathodes; Copolymers; Gravimetric analysis; Hydrochloric acid; Infrared spectroscopy; Magnesium; Microanalysis; Raman spectroscopy; Electrochemical energy storage; Magnesium primary batteries; Oxydized emeraldine; Polyaniline; Primary batteries

Authors: Rim Geun-Hie, Lee Hong-Sik, Pavlov E.P., Kim Won-Ho, Cho Chu-Hyun, Choi Young-Wook
Title: Fast high voltage pulse generation using nonlinear capacitors
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Rim, Geun-Hie, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea; Lee, Hong-Sik, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea; Pavlov, E.P., Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea; Kim, Won-Ho, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea; Cho, Chu-Hyun, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea; Choi, Young-Wook, Korea Electrotechnology Research, Inst, South Korea
Abstract: Many pulsed power applications require short high voltage pulses with high repetition rate. Conventional high-voltage discharge pulse-switches such as thyratrons, spark gap switches, vacuum tube switches have short lifetime, whereas the semiconductor switches have long lifetime and high reliability. The semiconductor switches, however, can not be directly applied to fast high voltage pulsed power generation due to their limited operating voltage ratings despite their relatively long switching times. Therefore they are used with a voltage amplification and a pulse compression stages. This paper describes two pulse generators using the semiconductor switches and nonlinear capacitors: One is based on an opening switch (IGBT) and an inductive energy storage. The other is a combination of a closing switch (RSD) and a capacitive energy storage.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Capacitors; Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Semiconductor switches; Inductive energy storage systems; Insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT); Nonlinear capacitors; Pulse generators

Authors: Kim Hyosung, Akagi Hirofumi
Title: Instantaneous power theory on the rotating p-q-r reference frames
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Cheonan Technical Coll, Cheonan, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Hyosung, Cheonan Technical Coll, Cheonan, South Korea; Akagi, Hirofumi, Cheonan Technical Coll, Cheonan, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposed the rotating p-q-r reference frames where one instantaneous active power p, and two instantaneous reactive powers qq, qr were defined in 3-phase 4-wire systems. The three power components are linearly independent, so that compensating for the two instantaneous reactive powers leads to control the two components of the current space vector independently. With the theory, this paper shows that the neutral current of a 3-phase 4-wire system can be eliminated by only compensating for the instantaneous reactive power using no energy storage element. Simulation results verify the theory very well.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric current control; Electric power systems; Reactive power; Vectors; Active power; Current space vector; Neutral current; Power compensator; Three phase system; Power electronics

Authors: Huang Minchao, Ying Jianping, Xu Dehong, Lin Weixun

Abstract: The full-bridge current mode high frequency link inverter based on the Flyback topology consists of a HF inverter, a HF transformer and a cycloconverter. Its HF transformer enables energy storage as well as electrical isolation and voltage level adjustment. The inherent voltage surge problem in voltage mode HF link inverters is solved and switch loss of the cycloconverter is reduced in this inverter. Its basic operation principles, the instantaneous voltage control scheme, and brief design procedure are described in the paper. Simulation and experimental results of the experimental prototype verified that it has following advantages such as compact topology, simple HF transformer structure, simple control scheme, good dynamic response, nonlinear load capacity and low voltage stress of switches.

Affiliations: LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Chung, Yong-Ho, LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea; Yang, Chun-Suk, LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea; Kim, Han-Joon, LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea; Burkhart, Craig P., LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea; Bayless, John R., LG Industrial Systems Co Ltd, KyungKiDo, South Korea
Abstract: This paper describes an all solid-state switched pulser for air pollution control system. The proposed pulser can produce 20 kV, 500 A, 100 ns pulses at repetition rates up to 10 kHz, and it is composed of 30 series connections of power circuit card assembly which contains paralleled MOSFETs, energy storage capacitors and pulse transformer. Higher pulse voltages and currents can easily be obtained by increasing the numbers of series and parallel connections of power circuit card and MOSFETs, respectively. This paper puts emphasis on the over-voltage and the over-current protections including short circuit condition for the reliable operation in real situations. Experimental results show that the proposed pulser is very efficient in air pollution control application and could be useful for other applications such as synthesis of nanosize powders and non-thermal food processing.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Capacitors; MOSFET devices; Overcurrent protection; Overvoltage protection; Short circuit currents; Solid-state switched pulser; Semiconductor switches

Authors: Corlier M., Besson J.-C., Brunelle P., Claverie J., Godefroy J.-M., Herbeaux C., Lefebvre D., Marcouille O., Marlats J.-L., Marteau F., Michaut J., Peaupardin P., Petit A., Sommer M., Veteran J., Nahon L.
Title: Commissioning of OPHeLIE: The new electromagnetic crossed overlapped undulator at Super-ACO
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Abstract: OPHeLIE, the first electromagnetic Onuki-type undulator has been installed on the 0.8 GeV storage ring Super-ACO in February 1998. It consists in two identical 9-period crossed overlapped undulators whose magnetic fields (up to 0.12 T) are produced by conventional electromagnets. This insertion device is able to produce any kind of polarization in the VUV range with a potential polarization switching rate of 1 Hz. Measurements of focusing and closed orbit distortion show a very good agreement with magnetic measurements. A compensation scheme has been developed in order to make the operation of the insertion device as user-friendly as possible. First results obtained on photon beam are very promising. Photon energy calibration, flux optimization and polarization measurements are in progress.
Index Keywords: Electric distortion; Electromagnetism; Magnetic field effects; Optimization; Polarization; Electromagnetic crossed overlapped undulators; Storage rings

Authors: Ogawa Y.
Title: Commissioning status of the KEKB linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ogawa, Y., KEK, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: After entering into the full-commissioning phase of the KEKB linac in May, 1998, we have established two linac injection modes for the KEKB ring: an 8-GeV electron beam and a 3.5-GeV positron beam, as well as beam modes for the rings of the synchrotron light sources. All modes are easily switched for almost one minute without any trouble. The linac beam characteristics have been substantially improved by introducing several fine-tuning procedures, while key features concerning stable operation have been pursued by employing, for instance, energy-feedback loops. We report on the present status of the linac commissioning while especially emphasizing the operational characteristics.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Light sources; Particle beam injection; Positrons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Electron-positron linacs; Linear accelerators

Authors: Ohnishi Y., Akai K., Akasaka N., Enomoto A., Flanagan J., Fukuma H., Funakoshi Y., Furukawa K., Hiramatsu S., Hosoyama K., Huan N., Ieiri T., Iida N., Kamitani T., Kato S.
Title: Lattice diagnostics using single kick closed orbit at KEKB
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohnishi, Y., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Akai, K., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Akasaka, N., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Enomoto, A., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Flanagan, J., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Fukuma, H., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Funakoshi, Y., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Furukawa, K., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Hiramatsu, S., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Hosoyama, K., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Huan, N., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Ieiri, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Iida, N., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Kamitani, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Kato, S., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: KEKB, an asymmetric-energy, double-ring electron/positron collider, employs a pair of superconducting quadrupole magnets for the final focusing of the two beams. The gradient errors of these magnets were estimated using two methods. Beta functions were measured using single kick closed orbit and measurements were compared with the model lattice and gradient errors were extracted in a beta beat. Gradient errors were also obtained by changing strength of steering magnets and measuring beam positions. Both methods were effective and yielded model calculations that can well reproduce the measured beta functions and the measured closed orbit.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Error analysis; Error correction; Focusing; Functions; Magnetic lenses; Mathematical models; Particle optics; Positrons; Superconducting magnets; Beta functions; Electron-positron colliders; Quadrupole magnets; Storage rings

Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kramer, S.L., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Murphy, J.B., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The VUV storage ring at the National Synchrotron Light Source was used to study the impact of changes in the momentum compaction factors over a large range from positive to negative values. Changes in bunch length and synchrotron tune were measured versus current and RF parameters for these different lattices. By controlling both the first and second-order momentum compaction factors, a lattice was developed in which a pair of alpha buckets was created within the energy aperture of the vacuum chamber and beam was stored simultaneously in both buckets.
Index Keywords: Alpha particle spectrometers; Synchrotrons; Momentum compaction lattice; Storage rings

Authors: Evans L.R.
Title: LHC accelerator physics and technology challenges
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Evans, L.R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) incorporates many technological innovations in order to achieve its design objectives at the lowest cost. The two-in-one magnet design, with the two magnetic channels integrated into a common yoke, has proved to be an economical alternative to two separate rings and allows enough free space in the existing (LEP) tunnel for a possible future re-installation of a lepton ring for e-p physics. In order to achieve the design energy of 7 TeV per beam, with a dipole field of 8.3 T, the superconducting magnet system must operate in superfluid helium at 1.9 K. This requires further development of cold compressors similar to those first used at CEBAF. The LHC will be the first hadron machine to produce appreciable synchrotron radiation which, together with the heat load due to image currents, has to be absorbed at cryogenic temperatures. Finally, the LHC is the first major CERN accelerator project built in collaboration with other laboratories. A brief review of the machine design is given and some of the main technological and accelerator physics issues are discussed.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Superfluid helium; Synchrotron radiation; Electron-proton colliders; Hadron colliders; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Staples J.W., Ayers J.J., Cheng D.W., Greer J.B., Hoff M.D., Ratti A.
Title: SNS four-phase LEBT chopper
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Staples, J.W., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Ayers, J.J., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Cheng, D.W., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Greer, J.B., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Hoff, M.D., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Ratti, A., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The Spallation Neutron Source front end incorporates a beam chopper in the LEBT that will remove a 295 ns section of beam at a 1.118 MHz rate (65% transmission) with less than 50 ns rise/falltime. The H- beam pulse length is one ms at a 60-Hz rate (6% duty factor). The LEBT is all-electrostatic, and the chopper incorporates four 3-kV solid-state switches during an einzel lens, split into quadrants, with a 4-phase chopping waveform. The suppressed beam is targeted on a four-segment Faraday cup which provides on-line intensity and steering diagnostics. Results of proton beam tests will be reported.
Index Keywords: Electrostatic accelerators; Neutron sources; Protons; Storage rings; Low-energy beam transport (LEBT); Linear accelerators

Authors: Safranek J., Donald M.H.

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SLAC, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Safranek, J., SLAC, Stanford, United States; Donald, M.H., SLAC, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The linear optics of both the high energy ring (HER) and low energy ring (LER) for SLAC's PEP-II B-Factory were characterized with two algorithms: analysis of the measured closed orbit response matrix and analysis of betatron phase advance measurements. The results of the two analyses were in good agreement. When the HER was first run in a low β optics in autumn 1997, the measured β functions showed more than a factor of two discrepancy from the design. The source of the optics distortion was diagnosed and corrected using these methods.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Betatrons; Matrix algebra; Particle optics; Storage rings; High-energy rings (HER); Low-energy rings (LER); Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Aceves S.M., Martinez-Frias J., Garcia-Villazana O.
Title: Evaluation of insulated pressure vessels for cryogenic hydrogen storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES

Authors with affiliations: Aceves, S.M., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, 7000 East Avenue, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Martinez-Frias, J., Ctro. de Ing. y Desarrollo Indust., Queretaro, Qro., Mexico; Garcia-Villazana, O., FIMEE, University of Guanajuato, Salamanca, Gto., Mexico
Abstract: This paper presents an analytical and experimental evaluation of the applicability of insulated pressure vessels for hydrogen-fueled light-duty vehicles. Insulated pressure vessels are cryogenic-capable pressure vessels that can be fueled with liquid hydrogen (LH2) or ambient-temperature compressed hydrogen (CH2). Insulated pressure vessels offer the advantages of liquid hydrogen tanks (low weight and volume), with reduced disadvantages (lower energy requirement for hydrogen liquefaction and reduced evaporative losses). The purpose of this work is to verify that commercially available aluminum-lined, fiber-wrapped vessels can be used for cryogenic hydrogen storage. The paper reports on previous and ongoing tests and analyses that have the purpose of improving the system design and assure its safety. The analytical and experimental results carried out until now indicate that it may be possible to use fiber-wrapped aluminum-lined vessels for operation at LH2 temperature and high pressure. Required future tests are described that will assure vessel safety under daily operating conditions.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Evaporation; High pressure effects; Light weight vehicles; Liquefaction; Pressure vessels; Cryogenic hydrogen storage; Hydrogen fueled light duty vehicles; Insulated pressure vessels; Hydrogen

Engineering Center, 3-3-1, Minatomirai, Nishi-ku, Yokohama, 220-8401, Japan
Abstract: It is planned to use hydrogen extensively as a source of clean energy in the next century. As part of our investigation for an International Clean Energy Network Using Hydrogen Conversion (WE-NET), we have been studying to establish a safety scheme to ensure that both existing and new hydrogen technologies are implemented without endangering public safety. In this plan, we consider the transport and storage of a large quantity of hydrogen in a large tank. First we must evaluate the consequence of the postulated accident of liquid hydrogen. Since we have developed the multi-phase hydrodynamics analysis code (CHAMPAGNE), we apply the code to simulate the formation and dispersion of hydrogen vapor clouds. In the present paper we have improved the calculation model in two ways. We added a function to CHAMPANGE for solving evaporation phenomena realistically, made many parametric calculations and planned the small-scale hydrogen dispersion experiments for the validation of this model. Another improvement is the turbulent mixing of evaporated liquid hydrogen. Now we have completed the basic functions of our simulation code. And these models of CHAMPANGE code must be verified by the experimental data.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Computer simulation; Hydrodynamics; Hydrogen; Liquefied gases; Liquid hydrogen; Multiphase hydrodynamic analysis code; Software Package CHAMPAGNE; Energy resources

Abstract: This study demonstrates how the lubricant thickness, carbon overcoat composition and lubricant process time influence the surface energy of magnetic recording disks. The interactions at the lubricant-overcoat interface are ascertained by studying the surface energy of the disk.
