Authors: Barrett R.C., Deloff A.
Title: Strong interaction effects in kaonic deuterium
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 5XH, United Kingdom; Soltan Institute for Nuclear Studies, Hoza 69, Warsaw, 00-681, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Barrett, R.C., Physics Department, University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 5XH, United Kingdom; Deloff, A., Soltan Institute for Nuclear Studies, Hoza 69, Warsaw, 00-681, Poland
Abstract: High precision measurements of kaonic hydrogen x rays and also, for the first time, of kaonic deuterium are under way within the DEAR project using the [Formula Presented] storage ring at Frascati. The values of the strong interaction [Formula Presented] level shift and width in kaonic deuterium cannot be simply predicted by relating them, via the Deser-Trueman formula, to the [Formula Presented] scattering length because the latter is not known experimentally: it cannot be obtained by adding the [Formula Presented] and [Formula Presented] scattering lengths but involves the solution of a complicated multichannel three-body problem. We give results of calculations of the kaonic deuterium strong interaction shift and width using an [Formula Presented] interaction [Formula Presented] that fits the available low-energy scattering data. The [Formula Presented] level shift in kaonic deuterium comes out negative and both the shift and the width are estimated to be about 1 keV. The [Formula Presented] capture rate is estimated to be smaller than the [Formula Presented] x-ray transition rate. This information is of importance for the planned experiment as it indicates that most of the kaons should reach the lowest [Formula Presented] level. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 15th Advanced ICFA Beam Dynamics Workshop on Quantum Aspects of Beam Physics 1998
Source title: Advanced ICFA Beam Dynamics Workshop on Quantum Aspects of Beam Physics
Abstract: The proceedings contain 65 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Quantum Aspects of Beam Physics. The topics include: Coherent and collective states in beam-radiation interaction; electron and proton spin polarisation in storage rings - an introduction; the permissible equilibrium polarisation distribution in a stored proton beam; on radiation reaction and the consistency of classical electrodynamics with quantum electrodynamics; longitudinal electron spin polarisation at 27.5 gev in Hera; a formula for the integration of radiation using Yoshida’s lie methods; simulation of synchrotron radiation in an electron storage ring; quantum effects in tracking; bunch-to-bunch diffusion in an electron storage ring; stochasticity limit and turbulent motion of phase-space fluid; photon-electron interaction and condense beams; electron-photon interactions in high energy beam production and cooling; coherent atomic beams from Bose condensates; transverse laser cooling of fast ion beams at the storage ring TSR; classical theory of ultrahigh-intensity relativistic scattering of electrons and photons in vacuum; a polarized laser beam as “an anisotropic crystal” for high-energy photons and electrons; simulation of the Laser-Compton scattering; stimulated photon-photon elastic scattering in the optical domain; high quantum yield, low emittance electron sources; positron production in single crystals by 1.2GeV electrons; efficient, high brightness sources of polarized neutrons and photons and their uses; modeling coherent Cherenkov radio emissions from high energy electromagnetic showers; stimulated emission of coherent radiation from a relativistic hydrogen-like ion beam; status of the laser electron accelerator project; laser acceleration in vacuum utilizing the au high power co laser and electron beams.

Authors: Spencer J.E.
Title: Efficient, high brightness sources of polarized neutrons and photons and their uses
Source title: Advanced ICFA Beam Dynamics Workshop on Quantum Aspects of Beam Physics
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA  94309, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spencer, J.E., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, CA  94309, United States
Abstract: There are many applications that could benefit from an easily accessible source of monochromatic, high brightness, polarized gammas and neutrons. A compact and comparatively inexpensive system is discussed based on a low-energy, electron storage ring with undulators that is expected to provide 1011 epithermal n/s and 1015 γ Is. This method could provide a more efficient, cleaner way to produce epithermal neutrons than conventional means. Technical innovations that make it feasible are described together with some fundamental and practical applications that also take advantage of developments in the field of high power lasers. © 1999 by World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.

Authors: Astrade L., Bravard J.
Title: Energy gradient and geomorphological processes along a river influenced by neotectonics (the Saône river, France)
Affiliations: UMR 5600 « environnement, ville, société », 18, rue Chevreul, Lyon, 69007, France; Département de géographie, Université Paris-lV-Sorbonne, 1, rue Victor-Cousin, Paris, 75230, France
Authors with affiliations: Astrade, L., UMR 5600 « environnement, ville, société », 18, rue Chevreul, Lyon, 69007, France; Bravard, J., Département de géographie, Université Paris-lV-Sorbonne, 1, rue Victor-Cousin, Paris, 75230, France
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to link the sediment transit and the flood plain storage of the Saône to hydromorphological characteristics of the hydrosystem, which exemplifies a new approach to sediment dynamics. The study of suspended sediment concentration in terms of temporal evolution, together with sediment deposition in terms of spatial variability, is a way to record the longitudinal evolution of the sediment load, which expresses the available energy gradient from upstream to downstream in hydrosystem. The Saône river is a 480-km-long Rhone tributary, with an oceanic pluvial regime, and an average yearly discharge of 440 ms at Lyons. The watercourse is characterised by very gentle slopes controlled by the neotectonics of the Bresse trough and by Holocene fluvial dynamics. Sediments were sampled during the December 1993-January 1994 flood (2 375 m3 s−1) and the 1995 January-February flood (1 826 m3 s−1). A fine partition into homogeneous sectors, using stream power as well as shear stress, has been realized on a 400 km reach using longitudinal and cross-sections at one kilometre intervals. This partition, compared with the results of the field sampling, shows that the amount of energy is closely connected to the hydromorphological characteristics of the river. © Elsevier, Paris. © 1999 Elsevier, Paris.
Author Keywords: Energy gradient; France; Saône river; Sediment load; Stream power

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Repetitive Systems
Source title: Advances in Imaging and Electron Physics
Abstract: Repetitive beam optical systems such as synchrotrons and storage rings have represented one of the major tools for high-energy physics studies. Recently, synchrotron radiation from electron storage rings has been increasingly used in fields, such as condensed matter physics, chemistry, and biological sciences. All these repetitive devices require that the particles remain confined in the ring. The description of these repetitive systems in terms of maps relating initial phase space co-ordinates to final phase co-ordinates is much the same as for the case of single-pass systems. To understand this fundamentally important effect qualitatively, this chapter considers a repetitive system that is well behaved, in the sense that the particles are stable. It also considers the motion of one particle through the Poincare map, and records its phase space position over many turns. © 1999, Martin Berz Elsevier Inc.

Authors: Papic I., Zunko P., Krajnc A., Povh D., Schultheis T., Weinhold M., Zurowski R.
Title: 300 kW battery energy storage system using an IGBT converter
Source title: 1999 IEEE Power Engineering Society Summer Meeting, PES 1999 - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia; TAB Meiica, MeZica, Slovenia; Siemens AG, EV NP, Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Papic, I., Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Zunko, P., Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Krajnc, A., TAB Meiica, MeZica, Slovenia; Povh, D., Siemens AG, EV NP, Erlangen, Germany; Schultheis, T., Siemens AG, EV NP, Erlangen, Germany; Weinhold, M., Siemens AG, EV NP, Erlangen, Germany; Zurowski, R., Siemens AG, EV NP, Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: Increasing automation in modern industry and deregulation have changed the requirements on power quality. Computer and process control equipment as well as drive converters are sensitive to deviations of the line voltage from the ideal sinusoidal. Voltage sags, harmonic distortion, flicker and interruption of power supply are the most common problems. In an increasing number of cases, where conventional equipment cannot solve these problems, PWM converter-based shunt- and series connected power conditioners named DSTATCOM (distribution static synchronous compensator) and DVR (dynamic voltage restorer) have been introduced. With energy storage added to the power conditioner even more flexibility in system operation and planning is provided for utilities and industry. This paper describes such a 300 kW power conditioner with a chemical battery and its benefits to an industrial plant. If, for example, load demand exceeds the power rating of the supplying transformer or the negotiated power with the utility only at certain times of day, the excessive active power demand can be provided by the power conditioner. In addition, the power conditioner can be used for reactive power compensation or other tasks, if it is not fully used for charging or discharging. The new technology can therefore be used to postpone or avoid major investments and to optimize energy consumption costs. © 1999 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery Energy Storage System - BESS; DSTATCOM; IGBT converter; peak-load leveling

Authors: Nara K., Hasegawa J.
Title: Configuration of new power delivery system for reliable power supply
Source title: 1999 IEEE Power Engineering Society Summer Meeting, PES 1999 - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Dept. of Systems Eng, Ibaraki University, Hitachi, Japan; Div. of Systems and Information Eng, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nara, K., Dept. of Systems Eng, Ibaraki University, Hitachi, Japan; Hasegawa, J., Div. of Systems and Information Eng, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan
Abstract: The optimal network configuration method of a new power delivery system is discussed from a viewpoint of power supply reliability. The new power delivery system can realize unbundled power quality services by utilizing dispersed generators and energy storage (DGS) on the demand side. The system is named FRIENDS (Flexible, Reliable, and Intelligent Electrical energy Delivery System). The main idea of the system is to introduce so-called quality control center (QCC) into the system. FRIENDS consists of a network of QCC connections. To find the optimal network configuration of FRIENDS, the tabu search method is employed. To demonstrate the validity of the algorithm, several numerical examples are shown. © 1999 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Dispersed energy storage; Dispersed generator; Distribution planning; Distribution system; Power quality; Unbundled power quality services

Authors: Tsai J.-S., Yoshikawa K., Iwahashi T., Kawai K.
Title: Thermal performance of a high-temperature air combustion boiler
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Science and Technology, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 1259 Nagatsuta. Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8502, Japan; CREST, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsai, J.-S., Department of Environmental Science and Technology, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 1259 Nagatsuta. Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8502, Japan, CREST, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan; Yoshikawa, K., Department of Environmental Science and Technology, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 1259 Nagatsuta. Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8502, Japan, CREST, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan; Iwahashi, T., Department of Environmental Science and Technology, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 1259 Nagatsuta. Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8502, Japan; Kawai, K., Department of Environmental Science and Technology, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 1259 Nagatsuta. Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8502, Japan
Abstract: A regenerative type of high-temperature air combustion boiler is developed and tested in Tokyo Institute of Technology. The main design feature of the boiler is to use honeycomb heat storage material to heat up the combustion air up to ROO C and use the hightemperature air to combust with the fuel to generate the thermal energy inside the boiler combustion zone. It is known that with the combustion of high-temperature air, the flame temperature is higher and temperature distribution of the combustion zone is more even. Thus the heat transfer efficiency of the boiler can be promoted. Also. with high-temperature air combustion, the combustion can be sustained without much input of excess air, and this combustion feature would also lead to the reduction of the NOx emission during the combustion process. In this study, it is found that this type of boiler can burn all kind of fuel smoothly range from 5000 Kcal/m3 to 10000 Kcal/m3. Also, the heat transfer rate between the flame zone and the water tube can be 25% higher than the traditional boiler. For the NOx emission. this new type of boiler can always keep the flue gas NOx level below that 30 PPM. With the test results. it is believed that this new type boiler is not only can provide good heat transfer character but also low pollutant emission. © 1999 The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Boilers; Fuel storage; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Nitrogen oxides; Combustion pro-cess; Heat transfer efficiency; Heat transfer rate; High temperature air; High temperature air combustion; Pollutant emission; Thermal Performance; Tokyo Institute of Technology; Combustion

Authors: Gundlach J.F.
Title: Unmanned solar-powered hybrid Airsphips for mars exploration
Affiliations: Blacksburg, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gundlach, J.F., Blacksburg, VA, United States
Abstract: This paper details a study for a self-launching aerobot capable of supporting a Mars ground rover. Ground vehicles have little information of the terrain beyond the next boulder but an aerobot can detect geological features of interest for the Mars-bound rover to investigate. Several design studies have been performed on autonomous aircraft, free-floating balloons and even blimps for Mars exploration vehicles, but none of these are well suited to the proposed mission. Aircraft tend to have complex articulation mechanisms for storage in small aeroshells, and most are designed to fly in a demanding transonic low-Reynolds number flight regime. In addition, data transmission rate limitations dictate high data link power requirements for typical flight velocities or the aircraft must survive a high-speed landing so that data can be transferred over longer periods of time. Balloons are at the mercy of the winds and cannot intentionally fly directly towards targets of interest. A reasonable compromise, it would seem, is the autonomous blimp. However, the minimum size feasible blimp design has a prohibitive launch mass. Hybrid airships have many strengths of blimps and aircraft and few of their weaknesses. This inflatable vehicle is similar in layout to the Deltoid Aerobody developed by the Aereon Corporation in 1971. It is heavier than air so it generates its lift from both buoyant and aerodynamic means. This configuration's large planform area gives it a light wing loading and ample solar array collection area. Thrust vectoring propulsion pods located laterally from the center of gravity give the vehicle VTOL capabilities much like the V-22 Osprey. Recent advances in thin-film Gallium Arsenide solar cells, efficient brushless DC electric propulsion systems, Low Reynolds number propeller aerodynamics and advanced composite bag materials permit this new class of autonomous vehicle to take flight. © by the American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Carlin P.W., Fingersh L.J.
Title: Some analyses of energy production from the NWTC variable speed test bed
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO  80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carlin, P.W., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO  80401, United States; Fingersh, L.J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO  80401, United States
Abstract: Using the NREL 20-kilowatt, direct-drive, variable-speed wind turbine test bed, we used to collected data to examine differences between constant-speed and variable-speed wind turbine operation. The assigned goal of the variable-speed control algorithm we used was to adjust continuously the turbine rotor speed so that its tip-speed ratio (TSR) stays as close as possible to a precalculated optimum value. To examine the success of the variable-speed control, histograms of tip-speed ratio root-mean-square (rms) error for each data set were calculated and plotted. The resulting histograms of both constant and variable-speed control algorithms were compared. The results validated the expected conclusion that lower rms TSR errors are associated with higher measured wind turbine power coefficients. A second comparison was made between variable-speed histograms and synthesized constant-speed histograms for the same wind. The decrease in rms TSR error of the variable-speed case was used to quantify the observed improvement in TSR tracking brought by the variable-speed control. © l998 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc.

Authors: Mitlitsky F., Weisberg A.H., Carter P.H., Dittman M.D., Myers B., Humble R.W., Kare J.T.
Title: Water rocket - Electrolysis propulsion and fuel cell power
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Astronautics Department, United States Air Force Academy, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Kare Technical Consulting, San Ramon, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mitlitsky, F., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Weisberg, A.H., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Carter, P.H., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Dittman, M.D., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Myers, B., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-174, Livermore, CA  94551-0808, United States; Humble, R.W., Astronautics Department, United States Air Force Academy, Colorado Springs, CO, United States; Kare, J.T., Kare Technical Consulting, San Ramon, CA, United States
Abstract: Water Rocket is the collective name for an integrated set of technologies that offer new options for spacecraft propulsion, power, energy storage, and structure. Low pressure water stored on the spacecraft is electrolyzed to generate, separate, and pressurize gaseous hydrogen and oxygen, These gases, stored in lightweight pressure tanks, can be burned to generate thrust or recombined to produce electric power. As a rocket propulsion system, Water Rocket provides the highest feasible chemical specific impulse (-400 seconds). Even higher specific impulse propulsion can be achieved by combining Water Rocket with other advanced propulsion technologies, such as arcjet or electric thrusters. With innovative pressure tank technology, Water Rocket’s specific energy [wh/kg] can exceed that of the best foreseeable batteries by an order of magnitude, and the tanks can often serve as vehicle structural elements. For pulsed power applications, Water Rocket propellants can be used to drive very high power density generators, such as MHD devices or detonation driven pulse generators. A space vehicle using Water Rocket propulsion can be totally inert and non-hazardous during assembly and launch. These features are particularly important for the timely development and flight qualification of new classes of spacecraft, such as microsats, nanosats, and refuelable spacecraft. © 1999 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Munroe W.D., Walker G., McConaghy R., Andersen J., Raqué S.M.
Title: A solar stirling power system for scientific balloons
Affiliations: Munroe Machinery Co., P.O. Box 860, Quincy, FL  32353-0860, United States; New Machine Co., 12121 NE 66th St., Kirkland, WA  98033, United States; Andersen Manufacturing Inc., 3126 N. Yellowstone Hwy., Idaho Falls, ID  83401, United States; NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Wallops Flight Facility, Wallops Island, VA  23337, United States
Authors with affiliations: Munroe, W.D., Munroe Machinery Co., P.O. Box 860, Quincy, FL  32353-0860, United States; Walker, G., Munroe Machinery Co., P.O. Box 860, Quincy, FL  32353-0860, United States; McConaghy, R., New Machine Co., 12121 NE 66th St., Kirkland, WA  98033, United States; Andersen, J., Andersen Manufacturing Inc., 3126 N. Yellowstone Hwy., Idaho Falls, ID  83401, United States; Raqué, S.M., NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Wallops Flight Facility, Wallops Island, VA  23337, United States
Abstract: An innovative power system for long duration scientific balloon missions is under development. This small lightweight compact power system utilizes solar energy input and a Stirling engine thermal converter to drive an electrical power generator. A high temperature thermal storage system is provided to allow continued operation of the engine and electric power production in the dark hours. A rigid high precision parabolic dish solar collector/concentrator focusses a concentrated solar beam on the aperture of a Helmolz cavity absorber partially immersed in the thermal storage bath of molten aluminum. Heat is transferred from the absorber to the molten aluminum and thence to the heater tubes of the four cylinder Stirling engine driving the electric generator. During the dark hours heat is drawn from the energy storage system to maintain operation of the Stirling engine generator. Helium is used as the working fluid in the engine with hydrogen as an option for high performance versions operating at higher speeds and pressures. Contemporary materials development allow the possibility of much higher maximum cycle temperatures. This offers increased power density and conversion efficiency with a decreased cooling requirement. © l999 American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics.

Abstract: To switch load duration curve and to decrease demand charge, a 20000 BTU ice storage air conditioning system used for room size 4×4 m2 is designed and constructed. Working time of ice storage system is divided into 2 processes. The first process is freeze mode, ice on coil, which is only produced by R22. This process takes approximately 11 hours, from 9 p.m.To 8 a.m. The other cooling mode brings ice storage energy in an ice storage tank for use in an air conditioning system. This process is made up of a glycol system and water system, which can provide air conditioning within business hours from 9 a.m.To 5 p.m. As a result the electrical load chart is changed. The mini ice storage system is useful both for the conservation of energy and the reduction of monthly electricity payment. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Electric energy storage; Conservation of energy; Design and construction; Electrical load; Ice storage tanks; Ice-storage air-conditioning; Ice-storage system; Load duration curves; Working time; Ice

Authors: Ribeiro P.F.
Title: SMES for enhanced flexibility and performance of FACTS devices
Source title: 1999 IEEE Power Engineering Society Summer Meeting, PES 1999 - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: BWX Technol. Inc., Lynchburg, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ribeiro, P.F., BWX Technol. Inc., Lynchburg, VA, United States
Abstract: This paper reviews the possible utility industry applications of SMES and discusses a number of technical issues and tradeoffs resulting from the design optimization process for SMES utility applications. The power electronics interfaces are discussed. Among the potential performance benefits are improved system reliability, dynamic stability; enhanced power quality; transmission capacity enhancement; and area protection. SMES devices may also have a positive cost and environmental impact by reducing fuel consumption and emissions through reduced losses and reduced generation availability for frequency stabilization. FACTS (flexible AC transmission systems) which handle both real and reactive power to achieve improved transmission and distribution system performance are multi-MW proven electronic devices now being introduced in the utility industry. In this environment, SMES is a logical addition to the expanding family of advanced power devices. The design of the SMES coil and power conversion system are very much dependent on the application. Although coil refrigeration and thermal insulation at low temperature present design challenges, the cryogenic system comprised of a refrigerator and cryostat storage vessel is a function primarily of the coil refrigeration requirements and consequently are sized for each application. Designing the SMES to operate at the voltages used by utilities can further reduce the cost of the power conversion system and related interfaces and the superconducting coil. An attractive option is the addition of energy storage to existing FACTS and Custom Power. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cost reduction; Electric power transmission; Electron devices; Environmental impact; Refrigeration; Superconducting coils; Temperature; Thermal insulation; Frequency stabilization; Generation availabilities; Performance benefits; Power conversion systems; Power electronics interface; Real and reactive power; Transmission and distribution systems; Transmission capacities; Flexible AC transmission systems

Authors: Plönjes E., Palm P., Lee W., Chidley M.D., Adamovich I.V., Lempert W.R., William Rich J.
Title: Vibrational energy storage in high-pressure mixtures of diatomic molecules
Affiliations: Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States
Authors with affiliations: Plönjes, E., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Palm, P., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Lee, W., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Chidley, M.D., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Adamovich, I.V., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Lempert, W.R., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; William Rich, J., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States
Abstract: CO/N2, CO/Ar/O2, and CO/N2/O2 gas mixtures are optically pumped using a continuous wave CO laser. Carbon monoxide molecules absorb the laser radiation and transfer energy to nitrogen and oxygen by vibration-vibration energy exchange. Infrared emission and spontaneous Raman spectroscopy are used for diagnostics of optically pumped gases. The experiments demonstrate that strong vibrational disequilibrium can be sustained in diatomic gas mixtures at pressures up to 1 atm, with only a few Watts laser power available. At these conditions, measured vibrational temperatures of diatomic species are in the range Tv=2000-3000 K for N2, Tv=2500-4000 K for CO, and Tv=2500-3000 K for O2. Translational-rotational temperature of the gases does not exceed T=700 K. Line-of-sight averaged CO vibrational level populations up to v=40 are inferred from infrared emission spectra. Vibrational level populations of CO(v=0-8); N2(v=0-4), and O2(v=0-8) near the axis of the focused CO laser beam are inferred from the Rarnan spectra of these species. Analysis of CO Raman spectra also suggests a possibility of vibrational level population inference up to level v~40. The results demonstrate a possibility of sustaining stable nonequilibrium plasmas in atmospheric pressure air seeded with a few per cent of carbon monoxide. The obtained experimental data are compared with modeling calculations that incorporate both major processes of molecular energy transfer and diffusion of vibrationally excited species across spatially nonuniform excitation region, showing reasonable agreement. © 1999, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric pressure; Carbon monoxide; Digital storage; Emission spectroscopy; Energy transfer; Gas mixtures; Gases; Laser beams; Magnetohydrodynamics; Molecules; Opacity; Optically pumped lasers; Pumping (laser); Atmospheric pressure air; Infrared emission spectrum; Molecular energy transfer; Non-uniform excitations; Nonequilibrium plasmas; Rotational temperature; Vibrational temperature; Vibrationally excited; Vibration analysis

Abstract: The proceedings contain 111 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Plasmadynamic and Lasers. The topics include: Plasma flow through a localized heat release region; a detailed contaminant transport model for facility hazard assessment in urban areas; further consideration of compressibility effects on shear layer optical distortion; experimental characterization of shock dispersions in weakly ionized nonequilibrium plasmas; flow visualization in a supersonic nonequilibrium plasma wind tunnel; ionization mechanisms in two-temperature air plasmas; control of stability and electron removal rate in optically pumped RF discharges; large-scale laser-pumped optical discharges; new types of electron beam generated electric discharge in dense gases; time-resolved fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy of optically pumped carbon monoxide; deep space one investigations of ion propulsion plasma interactions; large scale multidisciplinary electromagnetics computations; evaluation and design of advanced navy topside communication systems using eiger; magnetogasdynamic modeling of plasma expansion in magnetic field; parallel simulations of turbulent reacting sprays; progress in alpha laser characterization; large-eddy simulation of fuel-air mixing and chemical reactions in swirling flow combustor; numerical simulation of a constant current density discharge in a flowing air plasma; experimental and computational determination of the VKI plasmatron operating envelope; development of low power hall thrusters; interaction of shock waves with a pulse electrical discharge; vibrational energy storage in high-pressure mixtures of diatomic molecules and characterization of plasma disturbances in a hall discharge using a double probe.

Authors: Olsen A.D., Cady E.C., Jenkins D.S., Hastings L.
Title: Solar thermal upper stage cryogen system engineering checkout test
Affiliations: Advanced Space Propulsion The Boeing Company, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States; NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL  35812, United States
Authors with affiliations: Olsen, A.D., Advanced Space Propulsion The Boeing Company, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States; Cady, E.C., Advanced Space Propulsion The Boeing Company, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States; Jenkins, D.S., Advanced Space Propulsion The Boeing Company, Huntington Beach, CA  92647, United States; Hastings, L., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL  35812, United States
Abstract: The Solar Thermal Upper Stage Technology Demonstrator (STUSTD) program is a solar thermal propulsion technology program cooperatively sponsored by a Boeingled team and by NASA MSFC[1]. A key element of this technology program is development of a liquid hydrogen (LH2) storage and supply system which employs multilayer insulation, liquid acquisition devices, active and passive thermodynamic vent systems, and variable resistance 40W tank heaters to reliably provide near-constant pressure LH2 to a solar thermal engine in the lowgravity environment of space operation. The LH2 storage and supply system is designed to operate as a passive, pressure fed supply system at a near-constant pressure of 45 psia. During operation of the solar thermal engine over a small portion of the orbit, the LH2 storage and supply system propulsively vents through the engine at a controlled flow-rate. During the long coast portion of the orbit, the LH2 tank is locked up (unvented). Thus, all of the vented H2 flow is used in the engine for thrust, and none is wastefiilly vented overboard. The key to managing the tank pressure and therefore the H2 flow to the engine, is to manage and balance the energy flow into the LH2 tank (via the MLI and tank heaters) with the energy flow out of the LH2, tank (to the engine) through the active and passive thermodynamic vent systems. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Thio Y.C.F., Freeze B., Kirkpatrick R.C., Landrum B., Gerrish H., Schmidt G.R.
Title: High-energy space propulsion based on magnetized target fusion
Affiliations: NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States; Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; University of Alabama, Huntsville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thio, Y.C.F., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States; Freeze, B., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States; Kirkpatrick, R.C., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, United States; Landrum, B., University of Alabama, Huntsville, United States; Gerrish, H., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States; Schmidt, G.R., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States
Abstract: A conceptual study is made to explore the feasibility of applying magnetized target fusion (MTF) to space propulsion for omniplanetary travel. Plasma-jet driven MTF is not only highly amenable to space propulsion, but also has a number of very attractive features it has for this application: 1) The pulsed fusion scheme provides in situ a. very dense hydrogenous liner capable of moderating the neutrons, converting more than 97 % of the neutron energy into charged particle energy of the fusion plasma available for propulsion. 2) The fusion yield per pulse can be maintained at an attractively low level (< 1 GJ) despite a respectable gain in excess of 70. A compact, low-weight engine is the result. An engine with a jet power of 25 GW, a thrust of 66 kN, and a specific impulse of 77, 0 s, can be achieved with an overall engine mass of about 41 metric tons, with a specific power density (α) of 605 kW/kg, and a specific thrust density of 1.6 N/kg. The engine is rep-rated at 40 Hz to provide this power and thrust level. At a practical rep-rate limit of 200 Hz, the engine can deliver 128 GW jet power and 340 kN of thrust, at specific power and thrust density of 1, 141 kW/kg and 3 N/kg respectively. 3) It is possible to operate the magnetic nozzle as a magnetic flux compression generator in this scheme, while attaining a high nozzle efficiency of 80% in converting the spherically radial momentum of the fusion plasma to an axial impulse. 4) A small fraction of the electrical energy generated from the flux compression is used directly to recharge the capacitor bank and other energy storage equipment, without the use of a high- voltage DC power supply. A separate electrical generator is not necessary. 5) Due to the simplicity of the electrical circuit and the components, involving mainly inductors, capacitors, and plasma guns, which are connected directly to each other without any intermediate equipment, a high rep-rate (with a maximum of 200 Hz) appears practicable. 6) All fusion related components are within the current state of the art for pulsed power technology. Experimental facilities with the required pulsed power capabilities already exist. 7) The scheme does not require prefabricated fuel target and liner hardware in any esoteric form or state. All necessary fuel and liner material are introduced into the engine in the form of ordinaiy matter in gaseous state at room temperature, greatly simplifying their handling on board. They are delivered into the fusion reaction chamber in a completely standoff manner. © 1999 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Charged particles; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Engines; Fusion reactions; HVDC power transmission; Magnetic nozzles; Magnetoplasma; Materials handling; Plasma jets; Spacecraft propulsion; Electrical circuit; Electrical generators; Experimental facilities; High voltage DC power supplies; Magnetic flux compression generators; Magnetized target fusion; Reaction chambers; Space propulsions; Pulsed power technology

Authors: Howe S.D., Smith G.A.
Title: Enabling exploration of deep space: High density storage of antimatter
Affiliations: Synergistic Technologies, Inc., 19 Karen Circle, Los Alamos, NM  87544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howe, S.D., Synergistic Technologies, Inc., 19 Karen Circle, Los Alamos, NM  87544, United States; Smith, G.A., Synergistic Technologies, Inc., 19 Karen Circle, Los Alamos, NM  87544, United States
Abstract: Space is big. Over the next few decades, humanity will strive to send probes farther and farther into space to establish long baselines for interferometry, to visit the Kuiper Belt, to identify the heliopause, or to map the Oort cloud. In order to solve many of the mysteries of the universe or to explore the solar system and beyond, one single technology must be developed - high performance propulsion. In essence, future missions to deep space will require specific impulses between 50, 0 and 200, 000 seconds and energy densities greater than 1014j/kg in older to accomplish the mission within the career lifetime of an individual, 40 years. Only two technologies available to mankind offer such performance -fusion and antimatter. Currently envisioned fusion systems are too massive. Alternatively, because of the high energy density, antimatter powered systems may be relatively compact The single key technology that is required to enable the revolutionary concept of antimatter propulsion is safe, reliable, high-density storage. Under a grant from the NASA Institute of Advanced Concepts, we have identified two potential mechanisms that may enable high capacity antimatter storage systems to be built. We will describe planned experiments to verify the concepts. Development of a system capable of storing megajoules per gram will allow highly instrumented platforms to make fast missions to great distances. Such a development will open the universe to humanity. © 1999 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: NASA; Solar system; Warehouses; Energy density; Future mission; High energy densities; Key technologies; Long base line; Potential mechanism; Specific impulse; Storage systems; Propulsion

Authors: Hodge K.F., Crofoot T.A., Nelson S.
Title: Gelled propellants for tactical missile applications
Affiliations: TRW Space and Technology Division, Redondo Beach, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodge, K.F., TRW Space and Technology Division, Redondo Beach, CA, United States; Crofoot, T.A., TRW Space and Technology Division, Redondo Beach, CA, United States; Nelson, S., TRW Space and Technology Division, Redondo Beach, CA, United States
Abstract: There exists a family of gelled hypergolic propellants which have been shown to meet insensitive munitions requirements, can be stored and fired with existing propulsion technology, and are inherently safer than either neat liquid propellants or any known solid propellant system due to their unique viscosity and chemical characteristics. Gelled propellants provide comparable density impulse to the most capable solid propellant systems while delivering the mission duty cycle flexibility of a liquid system and meeting Insensitive Munitions (IM) requirements-an achievement which no current solid propulsion system has been able to equal. A gelled bipropellant propulsion system provides exceptional mission flexibility by permitting on-off modulation and/or continuous throttling of thrust during missile time-of-flight. When combined with advanced seekers, G&C electronics and (optional) in-flight command targeting updates, a "smart" mission capability is achieved with the following benefits: • missile effective range can be extended via energy management (fly longer due to reduced drag at lower speed), • throttling capability enables control of maximum acceleration levels across a range of payload and environmental variables, lessening the requirements on certain types of seekers and guidance units, • enables lock-on-after-launch through re-targeting maneuvers after launch, • higher turning rates are achievable at the same missile approach speed (by thrusting on demand at high sideslip angles), thereby enabling more effective intercepts against moving targets, • terminal velocity can be controlled on demand, and • identical units may be used for training and operational purposes merely by loading less propellant in the training units at the production, with no costly changes to the missile design. A gel propulsion system also results in a deployable missile that is IM-compliant (per MIL-STD-2105B), has improved storage & handling safety and is easily decommissioned/inerted, thereby significantly lowering the overall life-cycle cost of a given missile system. This paper will describe the applications, capabilities, and current state-of-the-art of gelled propulsion systems. A comparative discussion of the most important features of solid, liquid, and gelled propellants will include pertinent technology issues such as toxicity, safety, detonability, packaging, disposal, storability, and materials compatibility. Finally, we will review TRW’s experience and demonstrated capabilities in component testing, system testing, and hardware development with gelled propulsion systems and assess the status and readiness of the current generation of hardware for advanced tactical and strategic defense missiles and interceptors. © 1999 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Air navigation; Ammunition; Design; Gelation; Hardware; Life cycle; Liquid propellants; Liquids; Missiles; Packaging materials; Propellants; Solid propellants; Bi-propellant propulsion systems; Chemical characteristic; Environmental variables; Hypergolic propellants; Insensitive munitions; Lock on after launches; Maximum acceleration; Propulsion technology; Propulsion

Authors: Ibarra Pico F., Cuenca Asensi S.
Title: An associative neural network and its special purpose pipeline architecture in image analysis
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Departamento de Tecnología lnformàtica y Computación, Universidad de Alicante, Campus de San Vicente, Alicante, 03080, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Ibarra Pico, F., Departamento de Tecnología lnformàtica y Computación, Universidad de Alicante, Campus de San Vicente, Alicante, 03080, Spain; Cuenca Asensi, S., Departamento de Tecnología lnformàtica y Computación, Universidad de Alicante, Campus de San Vicente, Alicante, 03080, Spain
Abstract: There are several approaches to texture analysis and classification. Most have limitations in accurate discrimination or complexity in time calculation. A first phase is the extraction of texture features and later we classify it. Texture features should have the followings properties: be invariant under Ihe transformations of translation, rotation, and scaling; a good discriminating power; and take the non-stationary nature of texture account. In Our approach we use Orthogonal Associative Neural Networks to Texture identification. It is used in the feature extraction and classification phase (where its energy function is minimized). Due his low computational cost and his regular computational structure the implementation of a real-time texture classifier based on this algorithm is feasible. There are several platforms to implement Artificial Neural Networks (VLSI chips, PC accelerator cards, multiboard computers.,..). The election relies on the type of neural model, their application, the response time, capacity of storage, type of communications, and so on. In this paper we present a pipeline architecture, where precision, cost and speed are optimally trade off. In addition we propose CPLD (Complex I'rogrammahle Logic Device) chips to complete realization of the system. CPLD chips have a reasonable density and performance at low cost. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1999.
Author Keywords: Computer vision; Neural nets; Real-time quality control; Texture recognition

Authors: Klečková J.
Title: Storing prosody attributes of spontaneous speech
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of West Bohemia, Univerzitní 22 PLZEŇ306 14, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Klečková, J., Department of Computer Science, University of West Bohemia, Univerzitní 22 PLZEŇ306 14, Czech Republic
Abstract: The paper deals with the problem of the storage of the prosody attributes which have been used in the Czech dialog system. In Czech language featured by a free-word-ordering the prosody serves a critical information for the recognition and understanding system. For some sentences the intonation is essential to determine the core of a communication, beeing used by a speaker who to emphasize a meaning of a sentence. The prosodic characteristics included in the sentence (features describing fundamental frequency F0, voice energy, the length of a pause behind and before the word, the speaking rate, flags indicating word finality and the lexical word accent) are stored in the database and consequently exploited by the linguistic module as an additional information used for recognizing and understanding the spontaneous speech. In case of storing digital speech signal in database we meet a problem of its high redundancy. Another problem is choosing cut points for segmenting speech. Suitable points are pauses, but they are not often present in the fluent speech. Instead a coarticulation between phonemes makes the placement of the cut points difficult. Their suitably for segmenting speech should be dependent on a context information. Having processed the characteristics by usual methods of statistics the database can also be used to generate answers in the dialog system. The module was implemented in the C language and supported by the ORACLE database. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1999.
Index Keywords: C (programming language); Computational linguistics; Database systems; Co-articulation; Context information; Digital speech signal; Free word order; Fundamental frequencies; High redundancy; Oracle database; Spontaneous speech; Speech

Authors: Pitrone A., Pitrone A., Pitrone N.
Title: On-line management and control of distributed renewable energy power plants
Source title: International Conference on Electric Power Engineering, PowerTech Budapest 1999
Affiliations: Enichem, Sassari, Italy; Intelit, Rome, Italy; Engineering Faculty D.E.E.S., Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Pitrone, A., Enichem, Sassari, Italy; Pitrone, A., Intelit, Rome, Italy; Pitrone, N., Engineering Faculty D.E.E.S., Catania, Italy
Abstract: In the competitive environment due to the deregulation, the electric distribution systems must drastically improve their performance levels in terms of high reliability and quality in order to meet the customer demand. Flexible, Reliable and Intelligent Electric Energy Delivery Systems FRIENDS) will utilise Dispersed Generators (PhotoVoltaic equipments) and Dispersed Energy Storage Systems. Sophisticated systems will require advanced software and hardware technologies for on-line management and control. A suitable logic for the distribution automation must be (developed) adopted. Recently, a flexible and reliable logic for the automation of a hybrid power plant has been presented: it is based on the use of an expert system, fuzzy logic theory, neural networks and programmable logical controllers. On this basis, looking to the distribution automation in the paper a preliminary structure of the management and on-line control of a high quality distribution system with dispersed generation is presented.

Title: Test validation of flamelet model predictions of NOx
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: R and D Center ECOLEN, Moscow, Russian Federation; PTA, Media, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buriko, Yu., R and D Center ECOLEN, Moscow, Russian Federation; Zakharov, V., R and D Center ECOLEN, Moscow, Russian Federation; Belokon, A., R and D Center ECOLEN, Moscow, Russian Federation; Opdyke, G., PTA, Media, PA, United States
Abstract: Calculations of NOx emissions were made for the original high pressure combustor and for the original and a modified design of the low pressure combustor used in a Compressed Air Energy Storage (CABS) plant All were typical diffusion flame combustors. Since a CABS plant has an independent air supply, the relationship between combustor inlet temperature and pressure is not typical for gas turbines, and the pressure level for the HP combustor is unusually high (up to 4.5 MPa). Vitiated air from HP combustor exhaust is used as combustion air in the LP combustor. The NO, emissions prediction method, which was used, for calculations is based on a flamelet model which takes detailed kinetic schemes for fuel oxidation, NOx generation and turbulence/chemistry interaction into account Site measurements over the entire load curve confirmed the numerical predictions for both the original combustors and the newly developed LP combustor design. Copyright © 1999 by ASME.

Authors: Bianchi M., Gadda E., Peretto A.
Title: Energy comparison among load following hydro storage and two-shift operation strategies for intermediate fossil fuel power units
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: DIEM, University of Bologna, Viola Risorgimento, 2, Bologna, 40136, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bianchi, M., DIEM, University of Bologna, Viola Risorgimento, 2, Bologna, 40136, Italy; Gadda, E., DIEM, University of Bologna, Viola Risorgimento, 2, Bologna, 40136, Italy; Peretto, A., DIEM, University of Bologna, Viola Risorgimento, 2, Bologna, 40136, Italy
Abstract: During the night hours, to match the lowest load demand by a power generation system, many different strategies can be employed: unit load following, unit shutdown and hydro storage. Obviously, the utilized strategy influences the power production (gas turbines, hydro turbines, etc.) during the peak load demand. In this paper, the energy comparison among the above different strategies is carried out as a function of the load demand, the heat rate of the peaking units, the hydro storage total efficiency and the hydro stored energy. In particular, two sets of intermediate load fossil fuel power units (conventional and advanced) are considered. For the sets considered and relatively to the variable costs, the two-shift operation proved to be the most convenient strategy. Copyright © 1999 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Fossil fuels; Fuel storage; Heat transfer; Hydroturbines; Load following; Peak load demand; Power generation systems; Power production; Shift operations; Total efficiency; Variable costs; Gas turbines

Authors: Cohn A., Ehrlich S., Darguzas J., Giermac E.
Title: Compressed air storage with humidification: An economic analysis
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: EPRL, 3412 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA  94304, United States; EHRLICH ASSOCIATES, 755 Northampton Dr., Palo Alto, CA  94303, United States; Sargent and Lundy, 55 East Monroe Street, Chicago, IL  60603, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cohn, A., EPRL, 3412 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA  94304, United States; Ehrlich, S., EHRLICH ASSOCIATES, 755 Northampton Dr., Palo Alto, CA  94303, United States; Darguzas, J., Sargent and Lundy, 55 East Monroe Street, Chicago, IL  60603, United States; Giermac, E., Sargent and Lundy, 55 East Monroe Street, Chicago, IL  60603, United States
Abstract: A large, 530 MW, Compressed Air Storage with Humidification (CASH) cycle was configured as an energy-storage plant utilizing as the low pressure expander the turbine of the Siemens-Westinghouse W-501F2 with a firing temperature of about 2400°F (1315C) and a 1600°F (870C) high pressure Dresser turbine. A selling price for electricity was developed for this CASH plant and compared with that for power produced by simple and combined cycle power plants of similar size. At 90°F ambient, where cycling power is most necessary, the specific capital cost of the CASH plant was calculated to be 405 s/kW while the simple and combined cycle were 403 and 489 S/kW respectively. The CASH plant has a much lower incremental cost than does the simple cycle. These factors result in the CASH plant having lower overall costs than the simple cycle for operation of over about 400 hr/yr. and lower than the combined cycle for operation of less than about 4000 hr/yr. Copyright © 1999 by ASME.

Authors: Kapetanakis E., Normand P., Tsoukalas D., Beltsios K., Travlos T., Gautier J., Palun L., Jourdan F.
Title: Structure and memory effects of low energy Ge-Implanted Thin SiO2 Films
Affiliations: IMEL, Slovakia; MESL, IMS, NCSR Demokritos, Aghia Paraskevi, 5310, Greece; LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France
Authors with affiliations: Kapetanakis, E., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France; Normand, P., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France; Tsoukalas, D., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France; Beltsios, K., IMEL, Slovakia; Travlos, T., MESL, IMS, NCSR Demokritos, Aghia Paraskevi, 5310, Greece; Gautier, J., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France; Palun, L., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France; Jourdan, F., LETI (CEA), 17 rue des Martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 9, 38054, France
Abstract: Thin SiO2 films have been implanted with Ge+ ions and subsequently annealed. Transmission electron microscopy results indicate that after annealing at 950°C Ge remains distributed in a band and not in separate pockets. The charge storage effects of the Ge-implanted gate oxide of MaS capacitors have been studied for accumulation conditions through J- V and C-V measurements. A high positive' voltage pulse leads to a positive shift . of the capacitance-voltage curve, while a low positive voltage stress results in a small negative drift. The jlatband voltage (VFB) shift mechanism is attributed to the traplike behaviour of the implanted Ge.

Authors: Foreman M.H., Moore W.P.
Title: Data requirements for HWBEG studies
Source title: Waterpower 1999: Hydro's Future: Technology, Markets, and Policy
Affiliations: Louis Berger and Associ., Inc., 75 2nd Ave., Needham, MA 02494, United States; Harza Engineering Co., 233 South Wacker Dr., Chicago, IL 60606-6392, United States
Authors with affiliations: Foreman, M.H., Louis Berger and Associ., Inc., 75 2nd Ave., Needham, MA 02494, United States; Moore, W.P., Harza Engineering Co., 233 South Wacker Dr., Chicago, IL 60606-6392, United States
Abstract: The Headwater Benefits Energy Gains (HWBEG) assessment process requires a great deal of data from both headwater and hydropower project owners. For example, a twelve-year study involving eight headwater and six downstream hydropower projects requires a total of 87,660 individual data points of flow, generation, and headwater project daily storage change, as well as several pieces of annual project cost information. Assembling these data can be time consuming, especially if data received from the project owners require a great deal of correction, analysis, and interpretation. The purpose of this paper is to note HWBEG study data requirements in the context of their ultimate usage. Five major types of data will be highlighted: Headwater Project, Headwater Operations, Hydropower Project, Headwater Cost, and Hydropower Replacement Cost. For each data type, we discuss require information and potential difficulties in analysis, with the intent of informing hydropower and headwater project owners of what data should be supplied to reduce HWBEG assessment time and effort. Copyright © 2014 ASCE.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Costs; Hydroelectric power; Assessment process; Data requirements; Energy gain; Hydropower projects; Project cost; Project owners; Replacement costs; Storage changes; Digital storage

Authors: Oshima K., Kawai J., Otsuka S., Wada T., Imano H.
Title: Development of pump-turbine for seawater pumped storage power plant
Source title: Waterpower 1999: Hydro's Future: Technology, Markets, and Policy
Affiliations: Hitach, Ltd., Hitachi Works, 1-1 Saiwai-cho 3-chome, Hitachi-shi Ibaraki-ken, 317-8511, Japan; Electric Power Development Co., Ltd., 15-1, Ginza 6-chome, Chuo-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oshima, K., Hitach, Ltd., Hitachi Works, 1-1 Saiwai-cho 3-chome, Hitachi-shi Ibaraki-ken, 317-8511, Japan; Kawai, J., Hitach, Ltd., Hitachi Works, 1-1 Saiwai-cho 3-chome, Hitachi-shi Ibaraki-ken, 317-8511, Japan; Otsuka, S., Electric Power Development Co., Ltd., 15-1, Ginza 6-chome, Chuo-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Wada, T., Electric Power Development Co., Ltd., 15-1, Ginza 6-chome, Chuo-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Imano, H., Hitach, Ltd., Hitachi Works, 1-1 Saiwai-cho 3-chome, Hitachi-shi Ibaraki-ken, 317-8511, Japan
Abstract: Acquiring a pumped storage power generation site utilizing river water recently faces several restrictions due to environmental assessment. On the other hand, there are many sites favorable for constructing a pumped storage power plant utilizing seawater in Japan, which is surrounded by the sea. Seawater pumped storage power plants have several advantages such as lower civil construction cost and lower power distribution cost due to their proximity to nuclear or steam turbine power plants." Seawater pump turbines are used under the condition where the corrosion environment is noticeably severe, rather than conventional river water pump turbines. In addition, the pump turbines have many narrow spaces between parts and their major parts are embedded, so that it would be very difficult to apply proper corrosion prevention measures. The problem cannot be solved only by the conventional corrosion preventive engineering." The Agency of Natural Resources and Energy of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry entrusted Electric Power Development Co., Ltd. with the construction of the world's first seawater pumped storage pilot plant in Kunigami Village in Okinawa Prefecture in Japan, to execute verification tests for five years after the completion of the construction. The pilot plant is now under field testing, and is scheduled to be put into operation in March, 1999. Copyright © 2014 ASCE.

Authors: Falaki F., Lee P.
Title: Pump modernization program: California Department of water resources
Source title: Waterpower 1999: Hydro's Future: Technology, Markets, and Policy
Affiliations: California Department of Water Resources, Sacramento, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Falaki, F., California Department of Water Resources, Sacramento, CA, United States; Lee, P., California Department of Water Resources, Sacramento, CA, United States
Abstract: The California State Water Project (SWP) consists of 29 storage facilities, 18 pumping plants, four pump-generating plants, five hydroelectric power plants, and approximately 600 miles of canals and pipelines extending over two-thirds the length of California. The project requires 13,700 megawatt-hours of electricity a year to deliver the water. Because of the amount of energy needed to pump water, the SWP is the largest single user of electricity in California. This has magnified the importance of upgrading and maintaining all pump and turbine units to their peak efficiencies. This paper will present a discussion of design, fabrication, construction, testing and results of replacing vertical centrifugal pumps impellers at six pumping plants. The majority of the original equipment, placed in service from 1968 to 1972, was made of carbon steel with very little or no stainless steel components and 1960's technology. Continuing impeller deterioration, along with dropping efficiencies prompted the Department in the late 1980's to develop a pump modernization program. This program upgraded thirty pumps, with modern more efficient components made of state of art materials, to increase unit efficiencies to the highest extent possible. Copyright © 2014 ASCE.
Index Keywords: Carbon steel; Commerce; Hydroelectric power plants; Impellers; Pumping plants; California department of water resources; California State; Peak efficiency; Pump modernization; Steel components; Storage facilities; Unit efficiency; Water projects; Pumps

Authors: Sarma V.Y., Cover C.K., Bao Y.S.
Title: Headwater benefits methodology simplification
Source title: Waterpower 1999: Hydro's Future: Technology, Markets, and Policy
Affiliations: Engineering Section, Office of Hydropower Licensing, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC 20426, United States; Environmental Services Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarma, V.Y., Engineering Section, Office of Hydropower Licensing, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC 20426, United States; Cover, C.K., Engineering Section, Office of Hydropower Licensing, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC 20426, United States; Bao, Y.S., Environmental Services Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Abstract: Headwater benefits are the additional energy generation possible at a downstream hydropower project from the regulation of streamflows by an upstream storage reservoir. Federal Power Act (FPA) requires the owners of downstream hydropower projects to reimburse the owners of headwater project for part of the benefits it receives. This paper summarizes various methods the Commission uses to determine the energy gains and explores methods to simplify the analysis while providing a reasonable estimate of energy gains for small non-complex river basins. The procedures for determining headwater benefits have changed over the years. Prior to 1970, energy gains realized at a downstream hydropower project were assumed to be directly related to increases in usable flow for power generation. After 1970, statistical methods were applied to calculate energy gains. Empirical equations to model the operation of the downstream project were developed from a graphical plot of daily reported generation versus discharge values for a period of record. The Commission developed a Headwater Benefits Energy Gains (HWBEG) computer model to compute energy gains on a daily basis in the 1970's. In the 1990's, the Commission began using a Flow Duration Analysis (FDA) methodology to determine energy gains in non-complex river basins, where the use of the HWBEG model may not result in significant improvements in modeling accuracy. Use of FDA methodology reduced the costs of headwater benefits investigations considerably. To further reduce the costs headwater benefits determinations, the Commission has investigated statistical approaches, with multiple-regression equations relating headwater benefits to stream flow and hydro turbine parameters to determine whether the FDA methodology could be further simplified. Copyright © 2014 ASCE.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Hydroelectric power; Stream flow; Watersheds; Computer modeling; Empirical equations; Energy generations; Graphical plots; Hydropower projects; Model accuracy; Statistical approach; Storage reservoirs; Cost reduction

Authors: Karamouz M., Zahraie B., Torabi S., Shahsavarie M.
Title: Integrated water resources planning and management for Tehran metropolitan area in Iran
Affiliations: Amir Kabir University, Tehran Polytechnic, Tehran, Iran; Jamab Consulting Engineers, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Karamouz, M., Amir Kabir University, Tehran Polytechnic, Tehran, Iran; Zahraie, B., Amir Kabir University, Tehran Polytechnic, Tehran, Iran; Torabi, S., Amir Kabir University, Tehran Polytechnic, Tehran, Iran; Shahsavarie, M., Jamab Consulting Engineers, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Excessive demand for water due to growing population, agricultural, and industrial development along with the climate change and depletion of nonrenewable resources, intensities the need for integrated water resources management and optimal use of water resources as a sustainable source of energy. In this paper, a system approach to water resources management in Tehran Metropolitan Area, with its complex system of water supply and demands is discussed. Water resources in this region include water storage in Lar, Latyan, and Karaj reservoirs, Tehran aquifer, as well as water discharge in local rivers and in drainage channels (mainly supplied by urban runoff and wastewater). Framework of a Decision Support System for Tehran reservoir system, as a tool for managers and operators of this multifaceted system are also presented in this paper. The main priority is to provide over 800 million cubic meters of water per year for domestic consumption of 6.7 million population of Tehran. More than 60 percent of this water returns to Tehran aquifer through traditional absorption wells. Some part of this sewage is drained into local Firouz-abad and Sorkheh-hesar rivers and Yakhchi-abad channel. A good portion of these low quality resources are used for irrigation in southern part of Tehran, resulted in a significant rise in water table and considerable environmental problems causing adverse social and sanitation predicaments. A wastewater collection and treatment project is underway and the effects of this project on water recharge of Tehran aquifer have been considered in this study. Reallocation of surface water resources, as well as an improved agricultural development scheme are also considered and discussed in this paper. © 1999 American Society of Civil Engineers.
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Aquifers; Artificial intelligence; Climate change; Decision support systems; Sewage; Surface water resources; Water absorption; Water resources exploration; Water supply; Agricultural development; Environmental problems; Industrial development; Integrated Water Resources Management; Non-renewable resource; Water resources management; Water resources planning and managements; Water supply and demands; Reservoirs (water)

Authors: Cerulli J., Melotte G., Peele S.
Title: Operational experience with a superconducting magnetic energy storage device at Owens Corning Vinyl Operations Fair Bluff, North Carolina
Source title: 1999 IEEE Power Engineering Society Summer Meeting, PES 1999 - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: American Superconductor Corporation, Westborough, MA, United States; American Superconductor Corporation, Middleton, WI, United States; Carolina Power and Light Company, Raleigh, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cerulli, J., American Superconductor Corporation, Westborough, MA, United States; Melotte, G., American Superconductor Corporation, Middleton, WI, United States; Peele, S., Carolina Power and Light Company, Raleigh, NC, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the operational and power quality monitoring results for twenty-one months operating experience of a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) device used to mitigate power quality disturbances at the Owens Corning Vinyl Operations in Fair Bluff, North Carolina, a vinyl siding manufacturer. The SMES unit at Owens Corning provides sag and momentary interruption ride-through for the plant's extrusion lines. Prior to SMES installation, power disturbances caused frequent production interrupts, which resulted in extensive extrusion line cleanup and contributed to other maintenance problems. Two SMES units have provided 233 carry-overs as of March 2, 1999. The recorded power disturbance data corroborates previously published power quality data indicating that the overwhelming majority of voltage sag and interruption power quality disturbances were less than two seconds in duration. © 1999 IEEE.

Title: Flow visualization in a supersonic nonequilibrium plasma wind tunnel
Affiliations: Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Visiting Scholar from Institute für Angewandte Physik, University of Bonn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Yano, R., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Contini, V., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Plönjes, E., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States, Visiting Scholar from Institute für Angewandte Physik, University of Bonn, Germany; Palm, P., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States, Visiting Scholar from Institute für Angewandte Physik, University of Bonn, Germany; Merriman, S., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Aithal, S., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Adamovich, I., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Lempert, W., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Subramaniam, V., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States; Rich, J.W., Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Laboratory, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH  43220-1107, United States
Abstract: The paper discusses experiments conducted in a new, small-scale, nonequilibrium plasma wind tunnel recently developed at Ohio State. The facility provides a steady-state supersonic flow of cold nonequilibrium plasma with well-characterized, near uniform, properties. The steady-state operation is an advantage compared with short runtime available in shock tubes and ballistic ranges. The plasma is produced in aerodynamically stabilized high-pressure glow discharge that forms the plenum of the supersonic nozzle. Experiments in supersonic flowing nitrogen and helium afterglow using this facility demonstrate a novel technique for supersonic flow visualization. It allows identifying all key features of the supersonic flow, including shocks, boundary layers, flow separation regions, and wakes by recording intense visible radiation of the weakly ionized plasmas. Interpretation of radiation intensity distributions in nonequilibrium supersonic flowing afterglow may provide information on key mechanisms of energy storage and ultraviolet radiation in high-altitude rocket plumes. In addition, these flow visualization experiments can be used for validation of multidimensional computer flow codes used for internal flow simulation. © 1999, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Authors: DeMuth S.
Title: A cost comparison of organic versus inorganic ion exchange resin for remediation of high-level waste
Affiliations: Los Alamos National laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: DeMuth, S., Los Alamos National laboratory, United States
Abstract: Ion exchange (IX) can be used to aid in the remediation of underground storage tank (UST) radioactive waste at the U.S. Department of Energy's Hanford site in the state of Washington. In particular, IX can be used to concentrate the radionuclides in liquid-based waste prior to immobilization for final disposal. Concentration of the radionuclides can significantly reduce the final immobilized high-level waste volume and consequent overall remediation cost. Organic and inorganic IX resins each have unique advantages and disadvantages regarding the remediation process. This study presents a comparison of the remediation cost for UST waste at Hanford for a phenol-formaldehyde type organic resin versus crystalline silico-titanate inorganic resin. It was determined that with optimum processing conditions such as waste blending and sludge washing, remediation with the inorganic resin would be less expensive than the organic resin. Assuming baseline remediation conditions, the use of inorganic rather than organic IX resin for UST remediation at Hanford can save approximately $383 million. A limited sensitivity analysis was performed as pan of this study and is reported in the following. © 1999 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company.

Authors: Roberts W.J., Specca D.
Title: The Burlington County research and development greenhouse
Affiliations: Department of Bioresource Engineering, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, W.J., Department of Bioresource Engineering, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Specca, D., Department of Bioresource Engineering, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Abstract: A research and development greenhouse has been constructed at the Burlington County Resource Recovery Facility in Mansfield Township, near Columbus, New Jersey. A primary purpose of the facility is to demonstrate STTPS, the Single Truss Tomato Production System concept developed at Rutgers University. The main greenhouse is 77 meters wide with 7 bays at 11 m with each bay being 52 m long. The headhouse, 14.6 m wide and 62 m long, is placed between the main greenhouse area and the nursery production facility which is 11 m wide and 27.4 m long. Energy for the heating system will be supplied from methane gas extracted from the adjacent Resource Recovery facility when the methane collection system is completely operational. The gas is now being flared. A floor energy storage system and sidewall and overhead 50 mm hot water steel pipe constitute the heating system for the facility. Ventilation is accomplished through mechanical ventilation provided by electric fans. A screened and calibrated ventilation inlet provides control of incoming air and excludes insects from the growing area. Evaporative cooling is provided by a high pressure fog system with nozzles placed at the inlet window vent and along the central aisle in each greenhouse section. Currently three sections are glazed with glass and four sections are glazed with two layers of polyethylene film. Tomatoes in the STTPS are grown on transportable benches and are moved to the workers for pruning, inspection and harvest. Hives of bees located strategically throughout the growing area provide pollination for the crop. Supplemental lighting for year round production is provided by 430 watt HID (high intensity discharge) high-pressure sodium lamps at 92 watts per square meter. Electric power for the lights, currently supplied from the grid, will ultimately be supplied by a large co-generation unit which will provide power for the entire resource recovery operation. Rejected heat from the co-generation engine will be stored in the floor through the floor heating system.
Index Keywords: Apoidea; Hexapoda; Lycopersicon esculentum

Authors: Golacki K.A., Rybczyfiski R., Dobrzaiiski B.
Title: Water potential and failure parameters of apple flesh during storage
Affiliations: Faculty of Agricultural Engineering, University of Agriculture in Lublin, Doświadczalna 50a, Lublin, Poland; Institute of Agrophysic, Polish Academy of Sciences, Doświadczalna 4, Lublin, Poland

Abstract: Three varieties of apple (Gloster, Jonagold and Idared) picked in October were used to study the relationships between water potential, compression tests and fruit quality during storage. Compression tests were made on cylindrical samples of fruit flesh taken after three periods of storage in January, February and March. Failure parameters like stress, strain and energy at three rates of deformation were determined. For each sample water potential was also measured. The results show that water potential may be an indicator of the physical state of apple fruit during storage.

Abstract: TEPCO R&D Centers are engaged in various efforts that aim to achieve a creative research environment with lower energy consumption and to contribute to create a pleasant environment in surrounding areas. Work being undertaken includes a fusion of architectural planning and system planning, the development of a cold air distribution system using ice storage, and the promotion of energy conservation without loss of comfort in perimeter zones (window) by controlling heat and light. Furthermore, thanks to a next-generation building control system and precise energy operation management by the building operation working group, annual energy consumption is now about 1356 MJ/m2, showing an energy saving of 35%. © 1999 IEEE.
