Authors: Burba G.G., Verma S.B., Kim J.
Title: Energy fluxes of an open water area in a mid-latitude prairie wetland
Affiliations: School of Natural Resource Sciences, Ctr. Laser-Analyt. Studs. Trace G., University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, United States; Global Environ. Lab. Dept. A., Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Burba, G.G., School of Natural Resource Sciences, Ctr. Laser-Analyt. Studs. Trace G., University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, United States; Verma, S.B., School of Natural Resource Sciences, Ctr. Laser-Analyt. Studs. Trace G., University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, United States; Kim, J., Global Environ. Lab. Dept. A., Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Concurrent measurements of the surface energy balance components (net radiation, heat storage, and sensible and latent heat fluxes) were made in three communities (open water, Phragmites australis, Scirpus acutus) in a wetland in north-central Nebraska, U.S.A., during May-October, 1994. The Bowen ratio - energy balance method was used to calculate latent and sensible heat fluxes. This paper presents results from the open water area. The heat stored in water (G) was found to play a major role in the energy exchange over the water surface. During daytime, G consumed 45-60% of R(n), the net radiation (seasonally averaged daytime G was about 127 W m-2). At night, G was a significant source of energy (seasonally averaged nighttime G was about -135 Wm-2). The diurnal pattern of latent heat flux (λE) did not follow that of R(n). On some days, λE was near zero during midday periods with large R(n). The diurnal variability in λE seemed to be significantly affected by temperature inversions formed over the cool water surface. The daily evaporation rate (E) ranged from 2 to 8 mm during the measurement period, and was generally between 70 and 135% of the equilibrium rate.
Author Keywords: Evaporation; Heat storage; Inversion; Marsh

Source title: Artificial Cells, Blood Substitutes, and Immobilization Biotechnology
Authors with affiliations: Kee, C.Y.C.; Hassan, M.; Ramachandran, K.B.
Abstract: The objective of this research was to study the kinetics of synthesis of a commercially important ester - Isopropyl Palmitate (IPP) using immobilized lipase (Lipozyme IM). It was studied in a packed bed differential reactor. In order to establish the kinetics of the reaction, parameters such as linear velocity of the fluid through the reactor, particle size, substrate concentration, substrate molar ratio, temperature and water activity were studied. Operational and storage stability of the enzyme were also assessed. The reaction followed Michaelis-Menton kinetics as observed from the relationship of initial rate of the reaction as a function of substrate concentration. It was found that the optimum substrate concentration was 0.15M palmitic acid and isopropyl alcohol in 1:1 stoichiometric ratio. Inhibition by excess of isopropyl alcohol has been identified. The optimum temperature for the esterification reaction was found to be around 50°C. The activation energy of this process was determined to be 43.67 kJ/mol. The optimum water content was 0.50%. The reaction rates were measured in the absence of any significant external diffusional limitations. Since internal diffusional limitations could not be eliminated, the kinetics observed is only apparent.
Author Keywords: Esterification; Immobilized Lipase; Kinetics; Lipozyme; Packed Bed Reactor
Index Keywords: 2 propanol; immobilized enzyme; palmitic acid; palmitic acid isopropyl ester; triacylglycerol lipase; article; bioreactor; chemical reaction kinetics; concentration response; enzyme activity; esterification; fatty acid synthesis; Michaelis Menten kinetics; particle size; reaction analysis; stoichiometry; Isopropyl palmitate; Lipase; Activation energy; Bioreactors; Enzyme inhibition; Enzyme kinetics; Esterification; Esters; Packed beds; Biosynthesis

Authors: Gorb S.N.
Title: Serial elastic elements in the damselfly wing: Mobile vein joints contain resilin
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Inst. Entwicklungsbiol., Spemannstrasse 35, D-72076 Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gorb, S.N., Max-Planck-Inst. Entwicklungsbiol., Spemannstrasse 35, D-72076 Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Two main types of joints occur in the damselfly wing: mobile and immobile. Some longitudinal veins (RP2-, RP3and4-, and MP-) are elastically joined with cross veins, whereas other longitudinal veins (IR1+, IR2+, MA+, CuA'+) are firmly joined with cross veins. In this study we mapped the distribution of serial elastic elements in the wing. The occurrence of resilin, a rubberlike protein, in mobile joints suggests that the automatic twisting mechanism of the leading edge by aerodynamic force works not by flexibility but by the elasticity of these joints. First, it should result in elastic energy storage in the distal areas of the wing. Second, serial elastic elements of wing presumably act as dampers of an aerodynamic force, which are responsible for gradual twisting of the leading edge.
Index Keywords: insect protein; resilin; unclassified drug; article; elasticity; flying; insect; joint; joint function; microscopic anatomy; nonhuman; vein

Authors: Zhang Yumin, Hu Xiaobo, Chen Danny Z.
Title: Low energy register allocation beyond basic blocks
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Yumin, Univ of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States; Hu, Xiaobo, Univ of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States; Chen, Danny Z., Univ of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, United States
Abstract: An approach of doing register allocation beyond basic blocks for low energy is presented in this paper. With careful analysis of boundary conditions between consecutive blocks, our approach achieves the allocation results benefiting the whole program. By allowing the allocation results to propagate down block by block without backtracking, we avoid excessive computational cost.

Authors: Dubovenko K.V.
Title: Performance Simulation of Pulsed Power Supply System for Electrothermal Launcher
Affiliations: Institute of Pulse Research and Engineering, 43a Zhovtnevy Prospekt, 327018, Mykolayiv, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Dubovenko, K.V., Institute of Pulse Research and Engineering, 43a Zhovtnevy Prospekt, 327018, Mykolayiv, Ukraine
Abstract: Computer simulation of electrical discharges in high-pressure chambers of electrothermal launcher pulsed power supply systems containing homopolar generators (HPGs), storage inductors (Sis) and two-stage opening switches with mechanical and explosive circuit breakers has been carried out at the chamber radii of (0.02-0.1) m and various values of the gap spacing (0.1-0.8) m. Space-time dependences of pressure and temperature in the chambers as well as energy fesses in the circuit elements'are calculated. Up to 40 per cent of the HPG energy is shown to line delivered to the plasma load. Taking it into account the volume and tine mass of a transportable pawer supply providing the energy input to the load at the level of 5 MJ anp consisting of two 6.5 MJ HPGs connected in parallel, a 9 MJ SI, a rotating mechanical circuit breaker as well as an explosive one operating fee to the current conducting thin metal cylinder destruction by annular cumulative jets are evaluated. Simulation results of the medium heating and pressure oscillations in the chamber operating at. the currents of 200-300 SsA through each HPG and energies of 100-300 kJ per short are presented. © 1999 IEEE.
Author Keywords: High pressure chamber; Plasma load discharge characteristics; Pulsed power supply systems with homopotor generators and storage inductors; Two-stage opening switch
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric circuit breakers; Electric discharges; Electric inductors; Electric power systems; Electrothermal launcher; High pressure chamber; Homopolar generators; Pulsed power supply system; Storage inductors; Two stage opening switch; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Wang Y.
Title: EML technology research in China
Affiliations: Ordnance Engineering College, 97 West Heping Road, Shijiazhuang, Hebei, 050003, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y., Ordnance Engineering College, 97 West Heping Road, Shijiazhuang, Hebei, 050003, China
Abstract: In the last 20 years, electromagnetic launch (EML) technology has been developed in the U.S. and Europe, and the electromagnetic (EM) launcher has been regarded as a prospective equipment of propulsion. In early 1980s, experiments about the EML technology were done in some Chinese laboratories, and a lot of work has been finished in order to systematize the theory of EML technology in some universities and institutes. One result is that the Chinese book Principles of Electric Guns was one of the first publications of its kind in the world. Now, there are seven organizations which are participating in the research or experiments in China. They are the Southwest Institute of Fluid Physics (SWIFP), the Institute of Plasma Physics (IPP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing University of Science and Technology (NUST), Huazhong University of Science and Technology (MUST), Ordnance Engineering ColIege(OEC), Xidian University (XU) and Institute 208 of Chinese Ordnance Industry (I208COI). The invention patents relating to the EML technology have been applied for; three books which directly relate to the EML technology have been published; some papers have been translated, compiled and published internally. The 15 papers submitted to this symposium involve the rail gun, the coil gun, the electrothermal-chemical (ETC) gun, pulsed power conditioning, energy storage, and an overview. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic launchers; Electromagnetic propulsion; Energy storage; Patents and inventions; Societies and institutions; Coil gun; Electrothermal chemical gun; Pulsed power conditioning; Rail guns

Authors: Itoh Masahide, Mitsuhashi Toshiyuki, Kuroda Kazuo, Yatagai Toyohiko
Title: Adaptive optical system for monitoring synchrotron radiation beam profile
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: A beam profile monitoring system for the synchrotron radiation is designed to evaluate distribution of a cross section of the electron beam in a high-energy accelerator storage ring in real-time. The Shack-Hartmann wavefront sensor is adopted for the measurement of the wavefront error caused by deformation of an extraction beryllium mirror for the visible synchrotron radiation. The correction of the measured wavefront distortion is also described.
Index Keywords: Adaptive systems; Electron beams; Electron ring accelerators; Real time systems; Sensors; Synchrotron radiation; Monitoring system; Wavefront sensor; Optical systems

Authors: Kaygusuz K.
Title: Utilization of solar energy and waste heat
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Karadeniz Technical University, Trabzon, Turkey; Department of Chemistry, Karadeniz Technical University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kaygusuz, K., Department of Chemistry, Karadeniz Technical University, Trabzon, Turkey, Department of Chemistry, Karadeniz Technical University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey
Abstract: A heat pump and thermal energy storage unit were combined in an experimental setup to utilize solar energy and waste heat efficiently at low temperatures (10-50°C). The calcium chloride hexahydrate was used as the thermal energy storage medium and water was used as the working liquid between storage tank and collectors. The performance of the experimental setup at different heat source temperatures for space heating in a laboratory building in Trabzon, Turkey, were investigated both experimentally and theoretically. The fraction of the space heating load that was supplied by the solar-assisted system was determined as a function of collector area and storage volume from a developed numerical method and results were compared with experimental results. Copyright © 1999 Taylor & Francis.

Authors: Weck W., Ehrhart P., Müller A.
Title: Demonstration of a superconducting inductive pulsed power supply at simulated load conditions
Affiliations: Hermann Scholderle Evi Sturm M., Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weck, W., Hermann Scholderle Evi Sturm M., Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany; Ehrhart, P., Hermann Scholderle Evi Sturm M., Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany; Müller, A., Hermann Scholderle Evi Sturm M., Petersbrunner Str. 2, D-82319 Starnberg, Germany
Abstract: A laboratory set-up of a 0.5 MJ superconducting pulsed power supply is described. This combination of a superconducting inductive energy storage system with a superconducting pulse switch is performed using standard NbTi technology. Two principles of laboratory pulse loads are introduced, which simulate voltage and current conditions similar to those of ETC applications. The experimental results of pulse discharge experiments confirm good compatibility of inductive energy storage and the load simulators. Further experimental results demonstrate the possibility of pulse conditioning by sequential discharge of storage modules. © 1999 IEEE.

Authors: Poirier A., Ross G.G., Bertrand P., Wiertz V.
Title: Modification of wetting property of polycarbonate by means of ion beam implantation and storage in different gas environments
Affiliations: Universite du Quebec, Varennes, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Poirier, A., Universite du Quebec, Varennes, Canada; Ross, G.G., Universite du Quebec, Varennes, Canada; Bertrand, P., Universite du Quebec, Varennes, Canada; Wiertz, V., Universite du Quebec, Varennes, Canada
Abstract: The wetting property of polymers is very important in different applications such as biomaterials, textiles, aerospace (fluid management and materials processing in microgravity), and thin film adhesion. Therefore, there is a strong interest in the development of a new technology for the modification at will of this property. The use of low energy ion beams allows the modification of the first surface atomic layers. Nitrogen ions of 500 eV/at. were used to bombard the surface of polycarbonate (PC) samples to a fluence of 5×1016 at/cm2. Five different environments (oxygen, nitrogen, argon, dry air and vacuum) were used to store the samples for some hours (1 to 24 hours) after the implantation. Aging studies of the contact angle (advancing and receding) have shown that the environment gas influences the long term value of the contact angle and helps to maintain the stability of the treated surfaces with the passage of time. XPS and ToF-SIMS have been used to study the chemical effects of both N2+ ion irradiation and storage gas surrounding the samples. The results show faster aging in the case of the samples stored in vacuum, a harmful effect of nitrogen gas on the treatment and the formation of new chemical species for all treatments.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Argon; Contact angle; Ion implantation; Nitrogen; Oxygen; Secondary ion mass spectrometry; Surface treatment; Wetting; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Low energy ion beams; Polycarbonates

Authors: Wang Li, Tseng Hong-Yih
Title: Suppression of common-mode torsional oscillations of nonidentical turbine-generators using SMES
Affiliations: Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Li, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan; Tseng, Hong-Yih, Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper presents the analyzed results of damping improvement of common-mode torsional oscillations of a power system containing series-capacitor compensation using a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit. The studied power system consists of two sets of nonidentical turbine-generators connected to an infinite bus through a common series-capacitor compensated line. A unified approach based on modal control theory is employed to design a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) damping controller using speed deviations of both generators as stabilizing signals. Frequency-domain approach based on eigenvalue analyses and time-domain approach based on nonlinear model simulations under disturbance conditions are both performed. It can be concluded from the simulated results that the proposed SMES can effectively stabilize common-mode torsional oscillations.
Index Keywords: Control system synthesis; Damping; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Electric energy storage; Frequency domain analysis; Mathematical models; Oscillations; Superconducting devices; Three term control systems; Time domain analysis; Common-mode torsional oscillations; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Turbogenerators

Authors: Kanamori Yasuo, Uno Seinosuke, Suzawa Chizuru, Watanabe Michihiko, Isojima Shigeki
Title: Study on high temperature superconducting coil for SMES
Affiliations: Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanamori, Yasuo, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan; Uno, Seinosuke, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan; Suzawa, Chizuru, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan; Watanabe, Michihiko, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan; Isojima, Shigeki, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: We have been undertaking studies regarding high temperature superconducting wire application to a coil for Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES). As a result, we succeeded in developing an SMES coil using BSCCO2223 silver-sheathed multifilamentary wire. In liquid nitrogen this coil, comprising 10 pancake coils, has an energy storage capacity of 100 J with DC of 34.2 A, and can operate without difficulty at a peak triangular current of 34.2 A with 2 Hz, simulating SMES operation. However, 100 J is too small for practical SMES use. To increase this amount, we investigated liquid neon as a coolant, as well as the magnetic and tensile stress dependence of the wire's critical current density in liquid neon. In addition, we measured the cooling ability and dielectric breakdown voltage of liquid neon.
Index Keywords: Critical current density (superconductivity); Electric breakdown of liquids; Electric coils; Electric energy storage; Helium; High temperature superconductors; Neon; Nitrogen; Oxide superconductors; Tensile stress; Double pancake coil; Silver-sheated multifilamentary wire; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Superconducting wire

Authors: Barlow S., Carr N., Wise M.
Title: Development of the Nirex 4-metre Box for large items of decommissioning waste
Authors with affiliations: Barlow, S.; Carr, N.; Wise, M.
Abstract: The Nirex 4-meter Box is provided with internal shielding and is designed to meet the requirements specified in IAEA SS6 for an IP-2 freight container. The box is both a transport and a disposal package, and is suitable for waste materials that can be classed as low specific activity or surface contaminated objects. It is particularly suited for packaging decommissioning wastes, especially where the packager wishes to minimize the amount of size reduction required. The design, manufacture and test of a prototype Nirex 4-meter Box is described, including details on the factors that led to the container being identified for the packaging of waste from proposed decommissioning projects at various UK Atomic Energy Authority sites.
Index Keywords: Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Radiation shielding; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Specifications; Standards; Decommissioning wastes; Geological repositories

Authors: Desideri U., Paolucci A.
Title: Performance modelling of a carbon dioxide removal system for power plants
Affiliations: Università di Perugia, Dipto. Ingegneria Industriale, V., Perugia, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Desideri, U., Università di Perugia, Dipto. Ingegneria Industriale, V., Perugia, Italy; Paolucci, A., Università di Perugia, Dipto. Ingegneria Industriale, V., Perugia, Italy
Abstract: In this paper, a carbon dioxide removal and liquefaction system, which separates carbon dioxide from the flue gases of conventional power plants, was modelled. The system is based on an amine chemical absorption stripping system, followed by a liquefaction unit to treat the removed CO2 for transportation and storage. The effect of the main parameters on the absorption and stripping columns is presented. The main constraints set for the model are a capture efficiency of 90% and the use of an aqueous solution with a maximum 30% amine content by weight. The goal of this study is to remove the CO2 with minimum energy requirements for the process when it is integrated in a fossil fuel fired power plant. Results of the simulation are compared to experimental and literature data from feasibility studies and existing plants. The power plant to which the removal system is connected is a 320 MW steam power plant with steam reheat and 8 feedwater heaters. Two different fossil fuels were considered: coal and natural gas. The effect of the modifications necessary to integrate the CO2 removal system in the power plant is also studied. The capital cost of the removal and liquefaction system is estimated, and its influence on the cost of generated electricity is calculated.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Air pollution control; Amines; Carbon dioxide; Coal liquefaction; Electric power generation; Electric power plants; Flue gases; Natural gas; Steam power plants; Stripping (removal); Carbon dioxide removal system; Fossil fuel power plants

Authors: Case M.J., Schoeman J.J.
Title: Minimum component photovoltaic array maximum power point tracker
Authors with affiliations: Case, M.J.; Schoeman, J.J.
Abstract: This paper proposes to present a simple circuit that will extract maximum power from a PV array at high efficiency based on the observation that the voltage across a photovoltaic cell at maximum power output is a nearly constant fraction of the open-circuit voltage. This observation is confirmed by a detailed examination of the characteristic equations of a PV cell. In addition, this proposal uses a minimum of components both small signal and power, which is important in aerospace applications. In particular, the paper shows that an energy storage capacitor is unnecessary for a PV controller.
Index Keywords: Electric potential; Networks (circuits); Photovoltaic cells; Photovoltaic array maximum power point trackers; Solar cell arrays

Authors: Kulkarni C., Moolenaar D., Nachtergaele L., Catthoor F., De Man H.
Title: System-level energy-delay exploration for multimedia applications on embedded cores with hardware cache
Source title: Journal of VLSI Signal Processing Systems for Signal, Image, and Video Technology
Affiliations: IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Kulkarni, C., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Moolenaar, D., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Nachtergaele, L., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, F.; De Man, H.
Abstract: Program transformations are a powerful way of optimizing given applications for lower power and higher performance. In this paper, we explore avenues for power reduction by program transformations using the real-time constraints. In the sequel, we discuss the effects of our methodology, for optimization of power, on cache related performance aspects. Our target applications are in the real-time multimedia applications domain implemented on programmable multimedia or DSP processors. The effectiveness of our approach in obtaining a low power implementation and real-time performance is illustrated on three real-life applications, viz. a MPEG-2 decoder, a QSDPCM video codec and a Voicecoder application. Our experimental results indeed show that we are able to obtain lower power and still achieve a real-time performance.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Computer systems programming; Multimedia systems; Optimization; Real time systems; System level energy delay exploration; Embedded systems

Authors: Sakai Kiyomi, Tani Masahiko, Hangyo Masanori, Tonouchi Masayoshi
Title: Terahertz optoelectronics in high-Tc superconductors
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: M.P.T., Hyogo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, Kiyomi, M.P.T., Hyogo, Japan; Tani, Masahiko, M.P.T., Hyogo, Japan; Hangyo, Masanori, M.P.T., Hyogo, Japan; Tonouchi, Masayoshi, M.P.T., Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: A new type of superconducting optical flux-trap memory using the terahertz (THz) radiation from magnetic flux trapped states is described. The structure of the memory cell and the change of the waveform with the bias current and the laser spot position is presented. The direction of the magnetic flux trapped in the hole can be changed by the combination of the bias current direction and the laser spot position. The polarity of the THz radiation reflects the direction of the magnetic flux. By integrating the memory cell two-dimensionally, it is possible to make a new type of superconducting optical flux-trap memory.
Index Keywords: Electron energy levels; Electron traps; High temperature superconductors; Magnetic flux; Optical data storage; Superconducting devices; Waveform analysis; Superconducting flux-trap memory; Terahertz radiation; Optoelectronic devices

Authors: Costello Thomas P., Mikhael Wasfy B.
Title: Adaptively-fit, space-variant point spread function model for a spherical lens optical system
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States
Authors with affiliations: Costello, Thomas P., Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States; Mikhael, Wasfy B., Univ of Central Florida, Orlando, United States
Abstract: An analytical model is presented that accurately represents the space-variant (SV) point-spread-function (PSF) of an optical system consisting of a single spherical lens with a rectangular aperture. The model is useful for applying certain SV restoration methods to digital images formed by simple optical systems, since it significantly reduces the memory required to store PSF sample functions. The proposed model describes a SV PSF over a range of field angles with only four parameters for any specific position. The model is adapted to PSFs developed from diffraction theory, using an adaptive system with gradient descent parameter adjustment. Data is presented that characterizes the accuracy of the adapted model to a physical PSF as a function of field angle. An example is also presented that demonstrates the use of the model for restoration of a SV image formed by a single-lens optical system, resulting in a 7.5 dB improvement in normalized error energy (NEE).
Index Keywords: Adaptive systems; Data storage equipment; Functions; Image reconstruction; Integral equations; Mathematical models; Optical instrument lenses; Digital images; Point spread function; Space variant restoration methods; Optical systems

Authors: Malone James P.
Title: US utilities prepare for DOE delays
Affiliations: NAC Int, Norcross, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malone, James P., NAC Int, Norcross, United States
Abstract: A contract signed by United States utilities in 1982 required the Department of Energy (DOE) to take spent fuel from them as of 31 January 1998. DOE has not met this obligation. Addressing this problem, utilities are devising plans to prepare for what they perceive as the worst-case scenario.
Index Keywords: Fuel storage; Industrial management; Nuclear materials safeguards; Nuclear reactor licensing; Regulatory compliance; Spent fuels; Strategic planning; Alternative storage strategies; Dry spent fuel storage; Political factors; Reracking spent fuel pools; Nuclear industry

Authors: Fornaciari William, Sciuto Donatella, Silvano Cristina
Title: Power estimation for architectural exploration of HW/SW communication on system-level buses
Source title: Hardware/Software Codesign - Proceedings of the International Workshop
Affiliations: Politecnico di Milano, Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fornaciari, William, Politecnico di Milano, Milano, Italy; Sciuto, Donatella, Politecnico di Milano, Milano, Italy; Silvano, Cristina, Politecnico di Milano, Milano, Italy
Abstract: The power consumption due to the HW/SW communication on system-level buses represents one of the major contributions to the overall power budget. A model to estimate the switching activity of the on-chip and off-chip buses at the system-level has been defined to evaluate the power dissipation and to compare the effectiveness of power optimization techniques. The paper aims at providing a framework for architectural exploration of a system design, focusing on the power consumption estimation of memory communication. Experimental results, conducted on bus streams generated by a real microprocessor and a stream generator, show how the variation of cache parameters and the introduction of bus encoding at the different levels on the memory hierarchy can affect the system power dissipation. Therefore, the proposed model can be effectively adopted to appropriately configure the hierarchy and the system bus architecture from the power standpoint.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Computer peripheral equipment; Computer systems programming; Data communication systems; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Microprocessor chips; System-level buses; Computer architecture

Authors: Wu H.-J., Feng W.-S.
Title: Efficient simulation of switched networks using reduced unification matrix
Affiliations: IEEE; Department of Electrical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan; Department of Electrical Engineering, LungHwa Institute of Technology, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Department of Electronic Engineering, ChangGung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wu, H.-J., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan, Department of Electrical Engineering, LungHwa Institute of Technology, Taoyuan, Taiwan; Feng, W.-S., IEEE, Department of Electrical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan, Department of Electronic Engineering, ChangGung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan
Abstract: A new and simple formulation method for switched networks in the numerical time domain is presented. Unification models of switching devices, companion models of energy-storage elements, and several straightforward circuit-manipulated operations are used in obtaining a reduced unification matrix (RUM). The feature of the constant formulated RUM is clarified, and the selection of the main parameters of unification models is illustrated. A condition of reducibility is proposed to determine how small the dimensions of a modified nodal matrix (MNM) can be reduced to. Simulation results using the RUM method demonstrate its superiority over the commonly used MNM method, not only for memory requirements, but also for computational speed. A large circuit example shows that the RUM method offers a 76.32% time savings in computation. Additionally, the RUM method possesses the merits of easy formulation, easy programming and more realistic switch modeling, as well as greater accuracy and higher time efficiency when compared with commonly used state-space approaches. These combined advantages should make the proposed RUM method very attractive in the time-domain simulation of switched networks. For large switched networks, the decided advantages are very great.
Index Keywords: Computer programming; Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Matrix algebra; State space methods; Time domain analysis; Modified nodal matrix; Reduced unification matrix; Switched networks; Switching networks

Authors: Sadeghzadeh S.M., Ehsan M., Said N.H., Feuillet R.
Title: Transient stability improvement of multi-machine power systems using on-line fuzzy control of SMES
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Shahed University, 76 Taleghani Ave, Hafez Cross-roads, 15986 Tehran, Iran; Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Ave, Tehran, Iran; L.E.G., ENSIEG, Rue de la Houille Blanche, 38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Sadeghzadeh, S.M., Faculty of Engineering, Shahed University, 76 Taleghani Ave, Hafez Cross-roads, 15986 Tehran, Iran; Ehsan, M., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Ave, Tehran, Iran; Said, N.H., L.E.G., ENSIEG, Rue de la Houille Blanche, 38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France; Feuillet, R., L.E.G., ENSIEG, Rue de la Houille Blanche, 38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France
Abstract: Fuzzy control of the super-conducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is proposed here to improve the transient stability and damping requirements of multi-machine power systems. The effects of the SMES control on the line power transfer are considered in the design of the fuzzy controller. A theoretical realisation of the proposed control scheme is presented and a simulation study on the New-England test system is carried out. A practical implementation, based on local measurements, is explained. The improvement of the system's critical clearing time, and also the system damping requirements, are clearly demonstrated. Finally, a conclusion is provided. © 1999 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fuzzy control; Local control; On-line control; Stability limits; Transient stability

Authors: Chan D.K., Misquitta S.F., Ying J.F., Martner C.C., Hermsmeier B.D.
Title: Chemical depth profiling on submicron regions: A combined focused ion beam/scanning electron microscope approach
Affiliations: Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States; MMC Technology, Inc., 2001 Fortune Drive, San Jose, CA 95131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chan, D.K., Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States, MMC Technology, Inc., 2001 Fortune Drive, San Jose, CA 95131, United States; Misquitta, S.F., Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States; Ying, J.F., Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States; Martner, C.C., Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States; Hermsmeier, B.D., Materials Analysis Department, MMC Technology, Inc., San Jose, CA 95131, United States
Abstract: The combination of focused ion beam (FIB) milling and field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with x-ray energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) makes possible high-spatial-resolution (<1 μm) element-specific depth profiling. The depth profile resolution is controlled via the FIB to <5 nm sputter depths. Depth profiles through thin-film hard disk media on NiP substrates and through similar film structures deposited on a carbon-coated substrate are presented. The high spatial resolution of the FIB/SEM depth profile is not necessary for blanket films, and depth profiles through them are used to benchmark the spatial and depth resolution of the technique using a field emission SEM. Energy depth profiles that use increasing primary electron beam voltages in the spectrometer are shown on the same samples in comparison to FIB depth profiles. A brief overview of this technique in relation to XPS, AES and SIMS illustrates applications where FIB depth profiling analysis offers some advantages.
Index Keywords: Electric potential; Electron beams; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Hard disk storage; Ion beams; Magnetic thin film devices; Nickel compounds; Scanning electron microscopy; Spectrometers; Depth profiling; Focused ion beam (FIB) method; Nickel phosphide; Spatial variables measurement

Authors: Matsuki N., Nakano Y., Miyanaga T., Yokoo N., Oka T.
Title: Performance of radiant cooling system integrated with ice storage

Abstract: The purpose of this study is to design a hybrid system which is a combination of radiant cooling and low temperature air conditioning integrated with ice storage system. This paper reports the observed thermal environment of the chamber and results of experiments with subjects to grasp the optimum temperature and humidity of the room. In addition, a feasibility analysis for the hybrid system using conditioned air as a refrigerant was also studied with a computer calculations. This system produces comfortable environment and it is also possible to save energy consumption due to the reduction of electricity that could have been used on a fan.

Authors: Trelewicz J.Q., Siefker Andrew J.
Title: Burst error compensation for a two-dimensional channel
Source title: ICASSP, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing - Proceedings
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States
Authors with affiliations: Trelewicz, J.Q., Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States; Siefker, Andrew J., Arizona State Univ, Tempe, United States
Abstract: In an optical channel for a digital holographic data storage system, burst errors, in the form of severe amplitude compression, are experienced in the vicinity of dust and other optical aberrations in the channel. The locations of these burst errors are approximately fixed over a range of perturbations in magnification and vertical-horizontal position. In a calibrated channel, lower error rates can be realized by allocating energy in the modulation code based on a measurement of the approximate location of these effects. This paper discusses theoretical bounds on the energy inside the distortion region, and the modulation code which is used to approach this bound.
Index Keywords: Aberrations; Communication channels (information theory); Error compensation; Holography; Digital holographic data storage system (DHDSS); Digital storage

Authors: Huckaby J.L., Evans J.C., Olsen K.B., Antoniak Z.I., Julya J.L., Sklarew D.S.
Title: He and SF6 as tracers for determining ventilation rates of high-level radioactive waste tanks
Affiliations: Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huckaby, J.L., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Evans, J.C., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Olsen, K.B., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Antoniak, Z.I., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Julya, J.L., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Sklarew, D.S., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, PO Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Abstract: Helium (He) and sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) were used as tracers to determine passive ventilation rates of eight high-level radioactive waste storage tanks at the US Department of Energy's Hanford Site. Measurements of passive ventilation rates are needed for resolution of several safety issues, including rates of flammable gas ventilation, drying rates of organic salt-nitrate salt mixtures, and estimation of organic liquid waste surface area. Both He and SF6 met the criteria of having low background levels in the tank headspaces, being rapidly dispersed in the headspace, and remaining well-mixed for the duration of the experiments. However, SF6 was lost at a faster rate than He from higher-temperature tanks. This accelerated loss was attributed to beta radiolysis of the SF6 associated with its large electron-capture cross-section. Thus, SF6 is not a reliable tracer in these high-level radioactive waste storage tanks. Passive ventilation rates were significantly different among the tanks studied and also exhibited temporal variation within given tanks. Ventilation rates were higher than expected based on modelling of barometric pressure fluctuations. Rates may be influenced by a combination of factors, including wind scavenging, temperature differentials, and available airflow pathways.
Index Keywords: Helium; High temperature effects; Mathematical models; Radioactive wastes; Sulfur compounds; Tanks (containers); Ventilation; High level radioactive waste tanks; Sulphur hexafluoride; Ventilation rates; Radioactive tracers

Authors: Acebal R.
Title: Energy Storage Capabilities of Rotating Machines Including A Comparison of Laminated Disk and Rim Rotor Composite Designs
Affiliations: Science Applications International Corporation, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Acebal, R., Science Applications International Corporation, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: High speed rotating machines are being employed as energy storage devices to provide both pulsed and load leveling power to future electric weapon and/or electric drive vehicle systems. The ability to store as much energy as possible for the least weight is of paramount importance to these systems. The rotor configurations employed in these machines can vary greatly in shape, physical properties and stress distribution, as defined by the rotor's shape factor. This paper employs a unique approach to discriminate between vastly different rotor configurations based on a completely general derivation for the shape factor of constant thickness spinning rotors. The shape factor is used in conjunction with the rotor's maximum allowable operational stress and effective density to determine the maximum stored energy density of an individual rotating machine. These predictive techniques are then used to compare two composite rotor designs which have been built for electromagnetic pulsed power generation. These two machines are the laminated disk built by Kaman and the rim rotor built by CEM. Our analyses have determined that the true discriminator between these two designs is the allowable stress each can operate at since they both have about the same shape factor and composite density. The laminated disk design is limited by the interlaminar shear strength of the epoxy bond, while the rim rotor design is able to take full advantage of the strength limit of the composite fiber. These predictions are compared to test results for both machines. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric vehicles; Laminated composites; Rotating disks; Rotors; All electric combat vehicle; Laminated disk; Rim rotor composite designs; Rotating machinery

Authors: Kalogirou S.A., Panteliou S., Dentsoras A.
Title: Modeling of solar domestic water heating systems using Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: Dept. of Mech. and Mar. Engineering, Higher Tech. Inst., P.O. B., Nicosia, Cyprus; Machine Design Laboratory, Dept. Mech. Eng. Aero., Univ. P., Patras, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Kalogirou, S.A., Dept. of Mech. and Mar. Engineering, Higher Tech. Inst., P.O. B., Nicosia, Cyprus; Panteliou, S., Machine Design Laboratory, Dept. Mech. Eng. Aero., Univ. P., Patras, Greece; Dentsoras, A., Machine Design Laboratory, Dept. Mech. Eng. Aero., Univ. P., Patras, Greece
Abstract: Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) are widely accepted as a technology offering an alternative way to tackle complex and ill-defined problems. They can be trained to predict results from examples, are fault tolerant, are able to deal with non-linear problems, and once trained can perform prediction at high speed. ANNs have been used in diverse applications and they have shown to be particularly useful in system modeling and for system identification. The objective of this work was to train an ANN to learn to predict the useful energy extracted and the temperature rise in the stored water of solar domestic water heating (SDHW) systems with the minimum of input data. An ANN has been trained based on 30 known cases of systems, varying from collector areas between 1.81 m2 and 4.38 m2. Open and closed systems have been considered both with horizontal and vertical storage tanks. In addition to the above, an attempt was made to consider a large variety of weather conditions. In this way the network was trained to accept and handle a number of unusual cases. The data presented as input were the collector area, storage tank heat loss coefficient (U-value), tank type, storage volume, type of system, and ten readings from real experiments of total daily solar radiation, mean ambient air temperature, and the water temperature in the storage tank at the beginning of a day. The network output is the useful energy extracted from the system and the temperature rise in the stored water. The statistical R2-value obtained for the training data set was equal to 0.9722 and 0.9751 for the two output parameters respectively. Unknown data were subsequently used to investigate the accuracy of prediction. These include systems considered for the training of the network at different weather conditions and completely unknown systems. Predictions within 7.1% and 9.7% were obtained respectively. These results indicate that the proposed method can successfully be used for the estimation of the useful energy extracted from the system and the temperature rise in the stored water. The advantages of this approach compared to the conventional algorithmic methods are the speed, the simplicity, and the capacity of the network to learn from examples. This is done by embedding experiential knowledge in the network. Additionally, actual weather data have been used for the training of the network, which leads to more realistic results as compared to other modeling programs, which rely on TMY data that are not necessarily similar to the actual environment in which a system operates. © Elsevier Science Ltd.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Learning systems; Neural networks; Solar collectors; Weather forecasting; Solar domestic water heating (SDHW) systems; Solar water heaters

Authors: Caldwell John T., Jones Stephanie A., Lucero Randy F.
Title: Non-destructive boxed transuranic (TRU) waste assay systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: BNFL Instruments Inc, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Caldwell, John T., BNFL Instruments Inc, Los Alamos, United States; Jones, Stephanie A., BNFL Instruments Inc, Los Alamos, United States; Lucero, Randy F., BNFL Instruments Inc, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: A brief history of boxed waste assay systems (primarily those developed at Los Alamos National Laboratory - LANL) is presented. The characteristics and design process involved with current generation systems - as practiced by BII - are also discussed in some detail. Finally, a specific boxed waste assay system and acceptance test results are presented. This system was developed by BII and installed at the Waste Receiving and Packaging (WRAP) facility in Hanford, Washington in early 1997. The WRAP system combines imaging passive/active neutron (IPAN) techniques with gamma-ray energy analysis (GEA) to assay crates up to 2.5 m×2.5 m×6.5 m in size. (Systems that incorporate both these methodologies are usually denoted IPAN/GEA types.) Two separate gamma-ray measurements are accomplished utilizing 16 arrayed NaI detectors and a moveable HPGe detector, while 3He detectors acquire both active and passive neutron data. These neutron measurements employ the differential die-away technique and coincidence analysis, respectively. Both neutron measurements use BII's proprietary imaging methodology. Acceptance testing of the system was conducted at Hanford in January 1998. The system's operating performance was evaluated based on accuracy and sensitivity requirements for three different matrix types. Test results indicate an average 13% active mode accuracy for 10 nCi/g loadings of Pu waste and 5% passive mode accuracy for 10 g loadings of Pu waste. Sensitivity testing demonstrated an active mode lower limit of detection (LLD) of less than 5 nCi/g of 239Pu for the medium matrix and less than 20 pCi/g of fission and activation products at 3σ above background.
Index Keywords: Assays; Gamma rays; Imaging techniques; Neutron detectors; Nondestructive examination; Plutonium; Boxed transuranic waste assay systems; Coincidence analysis; Detection limit; Differential die-away technique; Gamma-ray energy analysis (GEA); Imaging passive/active neuron (IPAN) techniques; Nondestructive assay (NDA) systems; Waste receiving and packaging (WRAP) systems; Radioactive waste storage

Abstract: An account is given on two ambient-temperature molecule-based magnets, which are the result of research to identify factors in synthesis that control the magnetic properties of compounds. Authors: Venediktov M.D., Krutyakov Yu.A., Plotnikov M.I.
Title: High sensitive converters of a TV-type
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Venediktov, M.D.; Krutyakov, Yu.A.; Plotnikov, M.I.
Abstract: High sensitive converters of a TV-type was developed based on a novel method of energy radiation image conversion within a wide spectral range into an electrical signal. The method is based on a microchannel plate operating at the same time as the receiver, an amplifier, and a two-sided storage target on reading out. The proposed conversion method was evaluated successfully in the frames of research and development work at VNIIOFI in 1994-1995.

Authors: Kilkis I.B.
Title: Utilization of wind energy in space heating and cooling with hybrid HVAC systems and heat pumps
Affiliations: Geoenergy International Consortium, 3131, West Chestnut Expwy, Springfield, MO 65802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kilkis, I.B., Geoenergy International Consortium, 3131, West Chestnut Expwy, Springfield, MO 65802, United States
Abstract: Approximately one-third of the primary energy resources are consumed in space heating, cooling, and air-conditioning with a very low exergetic efficiency. The depleting nature of primary energy resources, negative environmental impact of fossil fuels and low exergetic efficiencies obtained in conventional space heating and cooling are the main incentives for developing alternative heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) techniques which can employ low density and interrupted energy sources. In this respect, in spite of difficulties primarily encountered in coupling wind energy with conventional space heating and cooling equipment, wind energy seems to be an exciting alternative provided that synectic combinations are pursued and applied. In this paper, a new wind turbine coupled hybrid HVAC system is presented, which consists of an optimum combination of convective and radiant heating and cooling systems with in-space thermal energy storage. A design case for a single family home is presented. In this study a 6 kW(e) wind turbine drives a ground source heat pump (GSHP) which is coupled to a hybrid HVAC system to satisfy the thermal loads of a 100 m2 home. In this example, sensible heating and cooling loads are satisfied by the high mass radiant floor which matches the daily peak demand and the available peak wind energy. Latent heating and cooling loads, along with ventilation requirements are satisfied by a forced-air system. Variable radiant and convective split type of control is implemented, and both systems are served by the same GSHP which also satisfies the domestic hot water (DHW) demand.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Heat pump systems; Thermal load; Ventilation; Wind power; Exergetic efficiency; Hybrid panel systems; Space heating

Authors: Kohno S., Teramoto Y., Lisitsyn I.V., Katsuki S., Akiyama H.
Title: Cable guns as a plasma source in a plasma opening switch
Affiliations: Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kohno, S., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Teramoto, Y., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Lisitsyn, I.V., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Katsuki, S., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Akiyama, H., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan
Abstract: The characteristics of a plasma generated by cable plasma guns have been studied by a laser interferometer. Cable plasma guns are frequently used as a plasma source in plasma opening switches. In our experiments, the plasma source consists of eight coaxial cable guns mounted on the outer electrode of concentric coaxial electrodes. The reproducibility of the gun in subsequent shots is found to be better than 10%, and the gun-to-gun difference is less than 15%. Assuming a symmetry of eight guns, the contour maps of the electron plasma density are plotted as function of time. The plasma density becomes maximum near the gun nozzle and near the inner coaxial electrode. The plasma density is low in the area between the coaxial electrodes during the early time of the discharge. At a later time, the plasma fills the space between the two guns more uniformly. Still photographs of the plasma luminosity show a good correspondence with the plasma density plots which were taken 10 μs after the discharge initiation. The plasma gun system is designed for use in a 400-kA inductive voltage adder with the inductive energy storage system.
Index Keywords: Coaxial cables; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric switchboards; Electrodes; Interferometers; Interferometry; Laser applications; Plasma density; Plasma devices; Plasma sources; Cable guns; Inductive energy storage; Plasma opening switches; Plasma guns

Authors: Kaygusuz K., Ayhan T.
Title: Experimental and theoretical investigation of combined solar heat pump system for residential heating
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Karadeniz Tech. University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey; Mechanical Engineering Department, Karadeniz Tech. University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kaygusuz, K., Chemistry Department, Karadeniz Tech. University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey; Ayhan, T., Mechanical Engineering Department, Karadeniz Tech. University, 61080, Trabzon, Turkey
Abstract: In order to investigate the performance of the combined solar-heat pump system with energy storage in encapsulated phase change material (PCM) packings for residential heating in Trabzon, Turkey, an experimental set-up was constructed. Also, a comparative study of the performance of this system has been undertaken theoretically. Simulations have been made with BASIC computer program of three basic combined configurations, as well as conventional solar and conventional heat pump systems in Trabzon by using meteorological data. The experimental results were obtained from December to May during the heating season for four heating systems. These systems are a conventional solar system, a series heat pump system, a parallel heat pump system and a dual source heat pump system. The experimentally obtained results are used to calculate the collector efficiency, heat pump coefficient of performance (COP), seasonal heating performance, the fraction of annual load met by free energy, storage and collector efficiencies and total energy consumption of the systems during the heating season.
Index Keywords: BASIC (programming language); Computer simulation; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Free energy; Heat storage; Solar heating; Space heating; Combined solar-heat pump system; Phase change material packings; Residential heating; Heat pump systems

Engineering, School of Science and Engineering, Saga University, 1 Honjo-machi, Saga 840-8502, Japan
Abstract: The spatial current distribution in the switch region of a plasma opening switch (POS) with coaxial configuration was observed using pick-up coils. Three pick-up coils were positioned along the axial direction of the conductor in the switch region. From experimental results, it was found that the conduction starts at generator side of the switch region, and current is transferred from the generator side to the load side in the opening operation during conduction operation. Also, it is possible that the spatial current distribution formed just after or before the opening operation at the load end of the switch region strongly affects the efficiency of energy transfer toward the load. © 1999 Publication Board, Japanese Journal of Applied Physics.

Authors: F.alferov D., P.ivanov V., A.sidorov V.
Title: HIGH-Current vacuum switching devices for power energy storages
Affiliations: All-Russian Electotechiucal Institute (VEI), Krasnokazarmerinaya 12, 111250 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: F.alferov, D., All-Russian Electotechiucal Institute (VEI), Krasnokazarmerinaya 12, 111250 Moscow, Russian Federation; P.ivanov, V., All-Russian Electotechiucal Institute (VEI), Krasnokazarmerinaya 12, 111250 Moscow, Russian Federation; A.sidorov, V., All-Russian Electotechiucal Institute (VEI), Krasnokazarmerinaya 12, 111250 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The series of new vacuum switching devices for commutation of power energy storages has been developed. To provide reliable and fast commutation of capacitor type energy storages a new type of triggered vacuum switch (TVS) of sealed off design has been developed - RVTJ-43. This switch provides commutation of current pulses with peak value up to 250 kA at working voltage up to 25 kV, with transferred charge In a pulse up to 120 C. Wide range of operating voltage and low switching voltage level permit to use RVU-43 in the crowbar operation mode to apply mono-polar pulses in the inductance load. Small straggling of triggering delay tune provides synchronous parallel switching of TVS on a load, and also series connection of TVS's. Results of TVS tests are presented. The opportunity to increase its limit parameters is discussed. Several types of DC vacuum circuit- breakers were developed to provide commutation of power inductive energy storages with switched currents up to 50 kA with voltage 30-100 kV. Possibility of series and parallel connections of DC circuit-breakers were investigated. Index Terms - Triggered vacuum switch, DC vacuum circuit-breakers, vacuum arc. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric circuit breakers; Electric potential; Energy storage; Switches; Vacuum applications; DC vacuum circuit breakers; High current vacuum switching devices; Triggered vacuum switch; Vacuum arc; Electromechanical devices

Authors: Antonopoulos K.A., Koronaki E.
Title: Envelope and indoor thermal capacitance of buildings
Affiliations: Natl. Technical University of Athens, Mech. Eng. Dept., Thermal S., Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Antonopoulos, K.A., Natl. Technical University of Athens, Mech. Eng. Dept., Thermal S., Athens, Greece; Koronaki, E., Natl. Technical University of Athens, Mech. Eng. Dept., Thermal S., Athens, Greece
Abstract: The real or effective thermal capacitance of buildings quantifies the energy stored within and differs considerably from the apparent thermal capacitance, which results by adding distributed specific heats of building elements into a lumped value. In the present study, a method is developed for analyzing the total effective capacitance into components concerning the building envelope or parts of it (e.g. ceiling, floor, etc.), the interior partitions, the furnishings, etc. The developed procedure is based on a finite-difference solution of a set of differential equations describing the transient heat conduction in all elements of a building. Applications are made to 21 types of buildings with 15 and 10 wall and roof compositions, respectively, and floor area from 50 m2 to 2500 m2. For example, it is found that for typical fully-insulated, one-storey, detached houses, the envelope, interior partitions and furnishings effective heat capacitances are 78.1%, 14.5% and 7.4%, respectively, of the total effective thermal capacitance. Also, a correlation is developed, which links the effective to the easily-calculated apparent thermal capacitance of buildings.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Differential equations; Finite difference method; Heat conduction; Heat storage; Transients; Building envelopes; Specific heat

Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, San #56-1, Shillim-Dong, Kwanak-Ku, Seoul, 151-742, South Korea; Lee, S.Y., Semiconductor R and D Center, Samsung Electronics Company, San #24, Nongseo-Lee, Kiheung-Eup, Yongin-Si, Kyungki-Do, 463-060, South Korea; Park, S.O., Semiconductor R and D Center, Samsung Electronics Company, San #24, Nongseo-Lee, Kiheung-Eup, Yongin-Si, Kyungki-Do, 463-060, South Korea
Abstract: Structure and composition of the ferroelectric Pb(Zr, Ti)O3 layers in a capacitor of the ferroelectric random-access memory (FeRAM) device having a density of 64 k were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) together with the energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) technique. The 250 nm thick PZT layer derived by the sol-gel route showed a 2-3% Pb-deficient, 3-4% Ti-deficient, and 5-7% Zr-excess composition at the top electrode interface compared to the bulk composition when they were as-fabricated. The local compositional nonuniformity became more critical as the integration process proceeded, which seriously degraded the ferroelectric hysteresis and the device yield. The major cause of the compositional variation was the outward diffusion of Pb through the capping barrier TiO2 layer during annealing at 650°C. The AlN capping barrier layer was also not effective in suppressing the diffusion of Pb. However, the Al2O3/TiO2 double capping layer was very effective in suppressing the outward diffusion of Pb, and excellent ferroelectric characteristic was expected.
Index Keywords: Annealing; Capacitors; Diffusion; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Ferroelectric devices; Ferroelectric materials; Hysteresis; Random access storage; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; Structure (composition); Titanium oxides; Transmission electron microscopy; Capping barrier layers; Compositional variation; Ferroelectric hysteresis; Intermetal dielectric; Structural variation; Semiconducting lead compounds

Abstract: X-ray photoelectron and X-ray excited Auger electron spectra (XPS and XAES, respectively) of a partially dehydrofluorinated PVDF film were measured and compared to those recorded in 1990. The prolonged storage of the film in air resulted in accumulation of oxygen in the film surface. The partial desorption of both oxygen and fluorine occurred under X-ray irradiation during ca. 180 min in a high-vacuum chamber of a spectrometer. This led to a significant modification of the C 1s line shape. The increase in the intensity of both the line itself and its satellite was observed, while the valence band XPS intensity remained unchanged.

Authors: Elshatshat R., Kazerani M., Salama M.M.A.
Title: ADALINE-based controller for active power-line conditioners
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Elshatshat, R., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont, Canada; Kazerani, M., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont, Canada; Salama, M.M.A., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont, Canada
Abstract: Active power-line filters based on the injection method, depend on the distorted line current signal and the voltage signal at the point of injection. These signals are used by the control circuit to make the converter inject the proper compensating current and regulate the dc-side current or voltage of the converter. In this paper, a new adaptive linear neuron (ADALINE)- based control scheme for a modular single-phase active power-line conditioner is proposed. Two ADALINEs are used to process the signals obtained from the line. The first ADALINE (the Current ADALINE) estimates the discrete Fourier coefficients of the distorted line current signal which will be used to construct the modulating signals of a number of current-source inverter (CSI) modules, each dedicated to eliminate a specific harmonic. The second ADALINE (the Voltage ADALINE) estimates the fundamental component of the line voltage signal to be used as the synchronizing signal for the regulation of the Idc of the CSI modules. This information can also be used in the compensation of the voltage sags and swells in a more advanced phase of the project. Both ADALINEs have the ability to track the variations in the system frequency. Power losses are reduced by adjusting the Idc in each CSI module according to the magnitude of the corresponding harmonic current. Fast response and accuracy of the ADALINE combined with fast response and low dc energy storage requirement of CSI topology, makes the above scheme a suitable on-line technique for high power applications. The theoretical expectations are verified by digital simulation using EMTDC simulation package.
Index Keywords: Active filters; Computer simulation; Electric current control; Electric inverters; Electric network topology; Fourier transforms; Harmonic generation; Linear control systems; Neural networks; Online systems; Active power filter; Active power line conditioners; Adaptive linear neuron based controller; Current source inverter; Discrete Fourier coefficients; Distorted line current; Harmonic current; Line voltage signal; Voltage sags; Adaptive control systems
