Abstract: We report on the first measurement of spin-correlation parameters in quasifree electron scattering from vector-polarized deuterium. Polarized electrons were injected into an electron storage ring at a beam energy of 720˜MeV. A Siberian snake was employed to preserve longitudinal polarization at the interaction point. Vector-polarized deuterium was produced by an atomic beam source and injected into an open-ended cylindrical cell, internal to the electron storage ring. The spin correlation parameter A^V_(ed) was measured for the reaction \pol(2H)(\pol(e), e’n)p at a four-momentum transfer squared of 0.21 (GeV/c)^2 from which a value for the charge form factor of the neutron was extracted. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Groop L.C.
Title: Insulin resistance: The fundamental trigger of type 2 diabetes
Affiliations: Department of Endocrinology, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Department of Endocrinology, Lund University, University Hospital Malmö, S-216 16 Malmö, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Groop, L.C., Department of Endocrinology, Lund University, Lund, Sweden, Department of Endocrinology, Lund University, University Hospital Malmö, S-216 16 Malmö, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Type 2 diabetes is a heterogeneous condition that is not attributable to a single pathophysiological mechanism. In general, both insulin resistance and impaired insulin secretion are required for the disease to become manifest. Thus, as long as the pancreatic β cells can compensate for the degree of insulin resistance, glucose tolerance remains normal. Clustering of type 2 diabetes in certain families and ethnic populations points to a strong genetic background for the disease. However, environmental factors such as obesity and a sedentary lifestyle are usually required to unmask the genes. Impaired insulin-stimulated glucose metabolism (particularly non-oxidative) in skeletal muscle represents a key feature of type 2 diabetes and is observed early in the pre-diabetic state. It is not clear, though, whether this represents an inherited defect in muscle or whether it develops secondarily, for example, to abdominal obesity. In favour of the latter hypothesis are findings that abdominal obesity and a low metabolic rate seem to precede the development of insulin resistance in offspring of type 2 diabetic patients. According to the thrifty gene hypothesis, individuals living in an environment with an unstable food supply could increase their probability of survival if they could maximize storage of surplus energy, for instance, as abdominal fat. Exposing this energy-storing genotype to the abundance of food typical of westernized societies is detrimental, causing insulin resistance and, subsequently, type 2 diabetes. There are a number of potential thrifty genes, including those that regulate lipolysis or code for the β3-adrenergic receptor, the hormone-sensitive lipase, and lipoprotein lipase. Type 2 diabetes develops as a consequence of a collision between thrifty genes and a hostile affluent environment. Insulin resistance is a key trigger for the disease, and optimal management of type 2 diabetes should therefore aim to ameliorate insulin resistance early.
Index Keywords: beta adrenergic receptor; glycogen synthase; body composition; ethnic group; genetics; human; insulin resistance; lipid metabolism; non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus; review; Body Composition; Diabetes Mellitus, Type 2; Ethnic Groups; Glycogen Synthase; Humans; Insulin Resistance; Lipid Metabolism; Receptors, Adrenergic, beta

Title: Electron collisions with diatomic anions

Authors with affiliations: Pedersen, H.B., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Djurić, N., JILA, University of Colorado, National Institute of Standards and Technology, Boulder, CO, 80309-0440, United States; Jensen, M.J., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Kella, D., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Safvan, C.P., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Schmidt, H.T., Department of Physics, Atomic Physics, Stockholm University, Stockholm, S-10405, Sweden; Vejby-Christensen, L., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Andersen, L.H., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark
Abstract: Electron collisions with negative ions ([Formula Presented] [Formula Presented] [Formula Presented] [Formula Presented] and OH) have been performed in a merged- beams experiment at the heavy-ion storage ring ASTRID (Aarhus Storage Ring, Denmark). Absolute cross sections for detachment [Formula Presented] and detachment plus dissociation [Formula Presented] are reported for energies below 40 eV. For the homonuclear ions, [Formula Presented] [Formula Presented] cross sections are also presented for dissociative reactions leading to an [Formula Presented] particle in the final state. The detachment process is dominant for all investigated systems. The detachment cross section is characterized by an effective threshold larger than the electron binding energy. The shapes of the detachment cross sections are similar for the studied anions pointing to a common nonresonant mechanism for detachment. Also, the cross section for detachment plus dissociation and pure dissociation show regularities pointing to a general nonresonant mechanism. Structures are observed in the detachment cross section of [Formula Presented] and [Formula Presented] and in the dissociation cross section of [Formula Presented] and [Formula Presented] The structures are attributed to short-lived dianions (resonances) formed during the collision process. The results are supported by ab initio calculations, and it is inferred that electronic excitations are important in the resonant reactions. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Wakabayashi Y., Tokeshi M., Jiang D.-L., Aida T., Kitamori T.
Title: Long-term energy storage of dendrimers
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan; Integrated Chemistry Project, Kanagawa Academy of Science and Technology, 3-2-1 Sakado, Kawasaki-shi, Kanagawa 213-0012, Japan; Precursory Research for Embryonic Science and Technology 21, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan; Department of Chemistry and Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wakabayashi, Y., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan; Tokeshi, M., Integrated Chemistry Project, Kanagawa Academy of Science and Technology, 3-2-1 Sakado, Kawasaki-shi, Kanagawa 213-0012, Japan; Jiang, D.-L., Precursory Research for Embryonic Science and Technology 21, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan, Department of Chemistry and Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan; Aida, T., Precursory Research for Embryonic Science and Technology 21, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan, Department of Chemistry and Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan; Kitamori, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan, Integrated Chemistry Project, Kanagawa Academy of Science and Technology, 3-2-1 Sakado, Kawasaki-shi, Kanagawa 213-0012, Japan, Precursory Research for Embryonic Science and Technology 21, Japan Science and Technology Corporation, Japan
Abstract: We have recently reported the anomalous cis-trans isomerization, which induced by 5-photon absorption (5-PA) of a spherical azo-dendrimer (L5AZO) by IR radiation from a nichrom source. In this study, we measured absolute absorption of L5AZO using a calibrated detector in order to investigate these anomalous phenomena. The number of infrared photons absorbed by a L5AZO was estimated as only 10-3 (photons s-1). This result suggests that L5AZO absorbs five photons not simultaneously but sequentially, and suggests the possibility of long-term intramolecular energy storage is anticipated. © 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Azo-dendrimer; Cis-trans isomerization; Long-term intramolecular energy storage

Authors: Cho T., Kohagura J., Hirata M., Sakamoto Y., Numakura T., Minami R., Sasuga T., Nishizawa Y., Okamura T., Tamano T., Yatsu K., Miyoshi S., Hirano K., Maezawa H.
Title: Effects of neutrons on semiconductor x-ray detectors including n-type Joint European Torus and p-type GAMMA 10 tomography detectors
Affiliations: Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Photon Factory, High Ener. Accel. Res. Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Cho, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Kohagura, J., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Hirata, M., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Sakamoto, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Numakura, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Minami, R., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Sasuga, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Nishizawa, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Okamura, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Tamano, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Yatsu, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Miyoshi, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Japan; Hirano, K., Photon Factory, High Ener. Accel. Res. Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Maezawa, H., Photon Factory, High Ener. Accel. Res. Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: Characterization experiments have been carried out so as to investigate the effects of fusion-produced neutrons on the x-ray-energy responses of semiconductor detectors for x-ray tomography in the Joint European Torus (JET) tokamak (n-type silicon) and the GAMMA 10 tandem mirror (p-type silicon). Neutron effects on the x-ray-energy responses of these detectors are studied using synchrotron radiation from a 2.5 GeV positron storage ring at the Photon Factory. Changes in the material properties of the detectors have been investigated using an impedance analyzer to estimate neutron effects on x-ray-sensitive depletion thicknesses. A cyclotron accelerator is employed for well-calibrated neutron irradiation onto these plasma x-ray detectors; a fluence of 2-5 × 1013 neutrons/cm2 is utilized for simulating the effects of fusion-produced neutrons in JET. Modifications of the x-ray responses after neutron exposure due to fusion plasma shots in JET as well as cyclotron-produced neutron irradiations are found to have a functional dependence on x-ray energy. Also, recovery of the detector energy response is found when detector bias is applied. Our theory consistently interprets such properties in terms of the neutron effects on the diffusion length and the resistivity of detectors. © 1999 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Tiong S.C., Ma Z.Y., Wang Z.G.
Title: Static and cyclic creep behaviour of SiC whisker reinforced aluminium composite
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Materials Science, City University of Hong Kong, 83 Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong; State Key Laboratory for Fatigue and Fracture of Materials, Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Tiong, S.C., Department of Physics and Materials Science, City University of Hong Kong, 83 Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Ma, Z.Y., Department of Physics and Materials Science, City University of Hong Kong, 83 Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Wang, Z.G., State Key Laboratory for Fatigue and Fracture of Materials, Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenyang, China
Abstract: Static and cyclic creep tests were carried out in tension at 573-673 K on a 20 vol.-%SiC whisker reinforced aluminium (Al/SiCw) composite. The Al/SiCw composite exhibited an apparent stress exponent of 18.1-19.0 at 573-673 K and an apparent activation energy of 325 kJ mol-1 for static creep, whereas an apparent stress exponent of 19.6 at 623 K and an apparent activation energy of 376 kJ mol-1 were observed for cyclic creep. A cyclic creep retardation (CCR) behaviour was observed for the Al/SiCw composite. The steady state creep rate for cyclic creep was three orders of magnitude lower than that for static creep. Furthermore, the steady state creep rates of the composite tended to decrease continuously with increasing percentage unloading amount. The static creep data of the Al/SiCw composite were rationalised by the substructure invariant model with a true stress exponent of 8 together with a threshold stress. The CCR behaviour can be explained by the storage of anelastic strain delaying non-recoverable creep during the onload cycles. © 1999 IoM Communications Ltd.

Authors: Ekechukwu O.V.
Title: Review of solar-energy drying systems I: An overview of drying principles and theory
Affiliations: Energy Research Centre, University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ekechukwu, O.V., Energy Research Centre, University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Abstract: A comprehensive review of the fundamental principles and theories governing the drying process is presented. Basic definitions are given. The development of contemporary models of drying of agricultural products are traced from the earliest reported sorption and moisture equilibrium models through the single kernel of product models to the thin layer and deep bed drying analyses.
Author Keywords: Deep bed drying; Drying; Drying rates; Moisture content; Moisture equilibrium models; Psychrometric analysis; Safe storage time; Thin layer drying

Authors: Pielichowski K.
Title: Thermal energy storage systems based on poly(vinyl chloride) blends
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. and Technol. of Poly., Technical University, ul. Warszawska 24, 31-155, Kraków, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Pielichowski, K., Dept. of Chem. and Technol. of Poly., Technical University, ul. Warszawska 24, 31-155, Kraków, Poland
Abstract: A series of blends of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) with: (i) poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), or (ii) polyoxymethylene (POM), with poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) as a thermal energy storage material, has been investigated by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) alone, or coupled with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). For the blends under investigation it was found that PEG has a significant effect on their thermal properties. It causes the initial decomposition temperatures to increase by about 70°C for PVC/POM blends, a substantial suppression of the volatile products evolution for PVC/PMMA blends, and for both polymer systems an improvement in the surface morphology in terms of uniformity. Based on the radical decomposition schemes of PEG and PVC a possible radical scavenger action was discussed as a reason for greater thermal stability. © 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
